events.title: Gatsby's Lavish Parties Described
detailed_summary: Music emanated from the neighbour's house during summer nights.
Guests, described metaphorically as moths, frequented his blue gardens amidst conversations, champagne, and stars.
During the day, guests enjoyed diving from a raft tower or sunbathing on his beach.
Gatsby's motorboats traversed the Sound, pulling aquaplanes.
On weekends, his Rolls-Royce transported groups to and from the city continuously, while his station wagon fetched guests from trains.
Every Monday, a large staff, including an extra gardener, worked to repair the weekend's festivities.
Large quantities of oranges and lemons were delivered weekly and juiced by a special machine.
Periodically, caterers set up extensive canvas tents and lighting.
Buffet tables featured elaborate food displays, including ornate salads and roasted meats.
A fully stocked bar with a brass rail offered a wide array of liquors, some unfamiliar to the younger guests.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was music from my neighbour’s house through the summer nights.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In the main hall a bar with a real brass rail was set up, and stocked with gins and liquors and with cordials so long forgotten that most of his female guests were too young to know one from another.

events.text_segment:
There was music from my neighbour’s house through the summer nights. In his blue gardens men and girls came and went like moths among the whisperings and the champagne and the stars. At high tide in the afternoon I watched his guests diving from the tower of his raft, or taking the sun on the hot sand of his beach while his two motorboats slit the waters of the Sound, drawing aquaplanes over cataracts of foam. On weekends his Rolls-Royce became an omnibus, bearing parties to and from the city between nine in the morning and long past midnight, while his station wagon scampered like a brisk yellow bug to meet all trains. And on Mondays eight servants, including an extra gardener, toiled all day with mops and scrubbing-brushes and hammers and garden-shears, repairing the ravages of the night before.
Every Friday five crates of oranges and lemons arrived from a fruiterer in New York—every Monday these same oranges and lemons left his back door in a pyramid of pulpless halves. There was a machine in the kitchen which could extract the juice of two hundred oranges in half an hour if a little button was pressed two hundred times by a butler’s thumb.
At least once a fortnight a corps of caterers came down with several hundred feet of canvas and enough coloured lights to make a Christmas tree of Gatsby’s enormous garden. On buffet tables, garnished with glistening hors-d’oeuvre, spiced baked hams crowded against salads of harlequin designs and pastry pigs and turkeys bewitched to a dark gold. In the main hall a bar with a real brass rail was set up, and stocked with gins and liquors and with cordials so long forgotten that most of his female guests were too young to know one from another.

At high tide in the afternoon I waited with a hundred others on Gatsby’s beach while the phaeton slid out with the four fat men who stopped at the café in West Egg, or Gatsby’s motor-boats stood at the wharf, hour after hour, waiting for the pleasure-launches to come and take them on board. On week-ends his Rolls-Royce became an omnibus, bearing parties to and from the city between nine in the morning and long after midnight, while his station wagon scampered like a brisk yellow bug to meet all trains. At least once in a fortnight a corps of caterers came down with several hundred feet of canvas and enough coloured lights to make a Christmas tree of Gatsby’s enormous garden. On buffet tables, garnished with glistening hors-d’œuvre, spiced baked hams crowded against salads of harlequin designs and pastry pigs and turkeys bewitched to a dark gold. In the main hall a bar with a real brass rail was set up, and stocked with liquors cooler and more obviously imported than any of the grocer’s in the West Egg village.

events.title: The Party Atmosphere Intensifies
detailed_summary: A large orchestra, not a small ensemble, arrived by seven o'clock.
Swimmers returned from the beach to dress, and numerous cars from New York filled the driveway.
Halls and verandas became vibrant with brightly dressed guests, modern hairstyles, and luxurious shawls.
The bar operated at full capacity, with cocktails circulating throughout the garden.
The air filled with lively chatter, laughter, brief introductions, and superficial encounters between strangers.
As night fell, the lights brightened, the orchestra played upbeat music, and conversation grew louder.
Laughter became more frequent and unrestrained.
Social groups formed, dissolved, and reformed rapidly with new arrivals.
Confident young women moved through the crowd, briefly becoming centers of attention before moving on.
One woman impulsively grabbed a cocktail, drank it quickly, and began dancing alone on a platform.
After a brief silence, the orchestra adapted its rhythm for her.
A rumor spread incorrectly that she was a famous dancer's understudy, marking the true commencement of the party.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By seven o’clock the orchestra has arrived, no thin five-piece affair, but a whole pitful of oboes and trombones and saxophones and viols and cornets and piccolos, and low and high drums.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The party has begun.

events.text_segment:
By seven o’clock the orchestra has arrived, no thin five-piece affair, but a whole pitful of oboes and trombones and saxophones and viols and cornets and piccolos, and low and high drums. The last swimmers have come in from the beach now and are dressing upstairs; the cars from New York are parked five deep in the drive, and already the halls and salons and verandas are gaudy with primary colours, and hair bobbed in strange new ways, and shawls beyond the dreams of Castile. The bar is in full swing, and floating rounds of cocktails permeate the garden outside, until the air is alive with chatter and laughter, and casual innuendo and introductions forgotten on the spot, and enthusiastic meetings between women who never knew each other’s names.
The lights grow brighter as the earth lurches away from the sun, and now the orchestra is playing yellow cocktail music, and the opera of voices pitches a key higher. Laughter is easier minute by minute, spilled with prodigality, tipped out at a cheerful word. The groups change more swiftly, swell with new arrivals, dissolve and form in the same breath; already there are wanderers, confident girls who weave here and there among the stouter and more stable, become for a sharp, joyous moment the centre of a group, and then, excited with triumph, glide on through the sea-change of faces and voices and colour under the constantly changing light.
Suddenly one of these gypsies, in trembling opal, seizes a cocktail out of the air, dumps it down for courage and, moving her hands like Frisco, dances out alone on the canvas platform. A momentary hush; the orchestra leader varies his rhythm obligingly for her, and there is a burst of chatter as the erroneous news goes around that she is Gilda Gray’s understudy from the Follies. The party has begun.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: By seven o’clock the orchestra has arrived, no thin five-piece affair, but a whole pitful of oboes and trombones and saxophones and viols and cornets and piccolos, and low and high drums. By seven thirty the eighth car was out in front, restless for, the gate, and by eight thirty the busses began to arrive, roaring with convivial drunkeness, while the air cracked and snapped under the tension of a hundred private elevators. At the same time, weary of the too many swings and plunges and blows, those who had stayed in the water too long came out with their last reserves of strength and collapsed on the sand. Before the half hour, young men were drifting in and out of the front door with their hats and coats and canes, and the living-room, the hall, the librarby, were peopled with burly men and slender women to whom I talked for a while until the air grew too crowded for a single voice. The hall was at present occupied by two garrulous girls in twin yellow dresses, who stopped at the foot of the steps by the door and looked down into the court with convivial excitement. They were continually excited at parties; they were forever finding new things to wonder at in the most familiar surroundings. When they had finished with the court they strolled through the garden, where the electric light showed the green grass and the orange trees and the purple flowers in a sort of phosphorescent glow. The bar was in full swing, and cocktails stood in ranks upon the bar, and trays of champagne were borne by stout waiters above the heads of the crowd. The garden was full of faces, and the air was full of voices, and the laughter of young men, and the chatter of young women, and the sound of the orchestra, and the clatter of the ice in the shakers, and the clink of the glasses on the trays. The air was alive with chatter and laughter, and casual innuendo and introductions forgotten on the spot, and enthusiastic meetings between women who never knew each other’s names. The lights in the house were bright, and the music was loud, and the conversation was louder. Laughter was easier, and the jokes were better. simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: By seven o’clock the orchestra has arrived, no thin five-piece affair, but a whole pitful of oboes and trombones and saxophones and viols and cornets and piccolos, and low and high drums. The last swimmers have come in from the beach now and are dressing upstairs; the cars from New York are parked five deep in the drive, and already the halls and salons and verandas are gaudy with primary colors, and hair shorn in strange new ways, and shawls beyond the dreams of Castile. The bar is in full swing, and floating rounds of cocktails permeate the garden outside, until the air is alive with chatter and laughter, and casual innuendo and introductions forgotten on the spot, and enthusiastic meetings between women who never knew each other’s names. The lights grow brighter as the earth lurches away from the sun, and the orchestra plays faster, and the wines grow warmer and the gossip cruder. The groups change more quickly, slide, and dissolve, and reassemble at different tables. Suddenly one of these gypsies, in an ecstasy of attention, flapped her arms like a bat, and, swaying, her voice husky, began to sing an obscene song in Dalmatian. Instantly the crowd tittered, melted away, and revalued her in a new light. She was suddenly prevented from singing any more. By midnight the hilarity had increased. A celebrated tenor had sung in Italian, and a notorious contralto had sung in jazz, and between the numbers people were doing stunts all over the garden, while happy, vacuous bursts of laughter rose toward the summer sky. IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion introduces invented scenes and details early on, such as specific times, additional vehicles, and descriptions of people and actions that are not present in the original passage. These additions disrupt the flow and focus of the original.
- A significant portion of the original passage, especially the climactic moment involving a particular party guest and the reaction of the crowd, is missing entirely from the completion.
- The completion contains a very lengthy, repetitive sequence that does not correspond to any content in the original and interrupts the narrative progression.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion omits key descriptive elements from the original, such as the visual details of the partygoers' attire, the atmosphere created by the lighting, and the specific musical and social transitions as the evening progresses.
- The original's depiction of the changing social dynamics, including the movement and interactions of groups and individuals, is largely absent or replaced with generic or repetitive statements.
- The unique event involving a guest's spontaneous dance and the crowd's reaction is not included, which removes a pivotal moment from the narrative.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion provides inaccurate or invented time references and sequences of arrivals that do not match the original's timeline.
- There are misattributed actions and invented characters or groups (such as the two girls in yellow dresses and the mention of private elevators) that are not present in the original.
- The sequence of events is altered, with invented actions and descriptions inserted before, during, and after the actual events of the original passage.
- The repetitive statements about confidence among partygoers are not only inaccurate but also disrupt the intended progression and tone of the original passage.

events.title: Nick Arrives at Gatsby's Party
detailed_summary: Nick reflects that he was likely one of the few attendees actually invited to Gatsby's parties.
He notes that most people simply showed up, arriving via car and finding their way to Gatsby's.
Upon arrival, guests were typically introduced by someone acquainted with Gatsby and then behaved freely, akin to being at an amusement park.
Many attendees never even met Gatsby, attending simply for the enjoyment of the party.
Nick confirms he received a formal invitation delivered by Gatsby's chauffeur earlier that Saturday.
The note expressed Gatsby's honor in inviting Nick to the 'little party' and mentioned prior intentions to meet, citing unspecified circumstances preventing it.
The invitation was signed by Jay Gatsby with a distinctive signature.
Dressed in white flannels, Nick went to Gatsby's around seven.
He felt uncomfortable amidst the unfamiliar crowd, though he recognized some faces from his commute.
Nick noticed many young Englishmen, well-dressed and seemingly eager, conversing intently with prosperous Americans.
He suspected they were involved in sales—bonds, insurance, or cars—keenly aware of the local wealth and hoping to capitalize on it.
Upon arriving, Nick tried to locate his host, Gatsby.
The few people he asked reacted with surprise and vehemently denied knowing Gatsby's location.
Feeling awkward, Nick retreated towards the cocktail table, seeing it as the only suitable place for a lone man to stand.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I believe that on the first night I went to Gatsby’s house I was one of the few guests who had actually been invited.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: As soon as I arrived I made an attempt to find my host, but the two or three people of whom I asked his whereabouts stared at me in such an amazed way, and denied so vehemently any knowledge of his movements, that I slunk off in the direction of the cocktail table—the only place in the garden where a single man could linger without looking purposeless and alone.

events.text_segment:
I believe that on the first night I went to Gatsby’s house I was one of the few guests who had actually been invited. People were not invited—they went there. They got into automobiles which bore them out to Long Island, and somehow they ended up at Gatsby’s door. Once there they were introduced by somebody who knew Gatsby, and after that they conducted themselves according to the rules of behaviour associated with an amusement park. Sometimes they came and went without having met Gatsby at all, came for the party with a simplicity of heart that was its own ticket of admission.
I had been actually invited. A chauffeur in a uniform of robin’s-egg blue crossed my lawn early that Saturday morning with a surprisingly formal note from his employer: the honour would be entirely Gatsby’s, it said, if I would attend his “little party” that night. He had seen me several times, and had intended to call on me long before, but a peculiar combination of circumstances had prevented it—signed Jay Gatsby, in a majestic hand.
Dressed up in white flannels I went over to his lawn a little after seven, and wandered around rather ill at ease among swirls and eddies of people I didn’t know—though here and there was a face I had noticed on the commuting train. I was immediately struck by the number of young Englishmen dotted about; all well dressed, all looking a little hungry, and all talking in low, earnest voices to solid and prosperous Americans. I was sure that they were selling something: bonds or insurance or automobiles. They were at least agonizingly aware of the easy money in the vicinity and convinced that it was theirs for a few words in the right key.
As soon as I arrived I made an attempt to find my host, but the two or three people of whom I asked his whereabouts stared at me in such an amazed way, and denied so vehemently any knowledge of his movements, that I slunk off in the direction of the cocktail table—the only place in the garden where a single man could linger without looking purposeless and alone.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: I believe that on the first night I went to Gatsby’s house I was one of the few guests who had actually been invited. People were not invited—they went there. They got into automobiles which bore them out to Long Island, and somehow they ended up at Gatsby’s door. Once there they were introduced by somebody who knew nobody. They came to gamble, to dance, to drink, to flirt, to gossip, to be seen. The house was full of strangers, all laughing and talking with a perfect familiarity that was either the product of the cocktails or the confident ignorance that assumes the world is its oyster. I felt a little lost, a little out of place. I didn’t know anyone, and the sheer scale of the party was overwhelming. The orchestra was playing jazz, and the dance floor was crowded with couples moving with a frantic energy. Waiters circulated with trays of cocktails, and the air was thick with the scent of gardenias and expensive perfume. I wandered through the rooms, looking for a familiar face, or perhaps for the host himself. I asked a few people if they had seen Mr. Gatsby, but no one seemed to know where he was, or even what he looked like. It was as if he were a mythical figure, the subject of endless speculation and rumour, but never actually present. I found myself standing near a table where a group of young women were talking loudly. One of them was Jordan Baker, whom I had met once before. She recognized me, and we started talking. She told me about the party, about the people there, and about Gatsby himself, or rather, the stories about him. It was clear that no one really knew him, despite being guests in his house. The party was a spectacle, a display of wealth and excess, but it lacked any real connection or intimacy. It was a world of transient pleasures, where people came and went like moths drawn to a flame, burning brightly for a moment before disappearing back into the night. I watched them, fascinated and slightly repelled, a quiet observer in the midst of the roaring twenties.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
```text
I believe that on the first night I went to Gatsby’s house I was one of the few guests who had actually been invited. People were not invited—they went there. They got into automobiles which bore them out to Long Island, and somehow they ended up at Gatsby’s door. Once there they were introduced by somebody who knew Gatsby, and after that they conducted themselves according to the rules of behavior associated with an amusement park. Sometimes they came and went without having met Gatsby at all, came for the party with a simplicity of heart that was its own ticket of admission.

I had been actually invited. A chauffeur in a uniform of robin’s-egg blue crossed my lawn early that Saturday morning with a surprisingly formal note from his employer. It was addressed to me personally, and signed Jay Gatsby, in a majestic hand.

“And I like large parties. They’re so intimate. At small parties there isn’t any privacy.”

There was a machine in the kitchen which could extract the juice of two hundred oranges in half an hour if a little button was pressed two hundred times by a butler’s thumb.

At seven o’clock I was dressed in my three-piece suit of cream-colored flannel, and half an hour later I was standing at the edge of a lawn, an unfamiliar butler among unfamiliar faces, and suddenly I wasn’t enjoying myself. Gatsby’s house was still empty when I arrived, but the music had already started, and the cars were already parked five deep in the drive, and already the halls and salons and verandas were gaudy with primary colors, and hair shorn in strange new ways, and shawls beyond the dreams of Castile. The only lights in the house itself were green, and they shone out on the dark lawn like a string of Christmas tree lights.

I was on my way to get a drink at the bar when I was hailed by a familiar voice.

“Hello, old sport,” called a voice from the crowd.

I turned around and saw a man I knew from my commute on the train. He was standing with a group of young Englishmen, all well-dressed and eager, talking intently with prosperous Americans. I suspected they were in the bond business, or insurance, or automobiles. They were keenly aware of the local wealth and hoping to capitalize on it.

Feeling a little awkward and not knowing anyone, I decided to try and find my host. I asked a few people if they knew where Mr. Gatsby was, but they looked at me with surprise and vehemently denied knowing his whereabouts. Feeling even more uncomfortable, I retreated towards the cocktail table, seeing it as the only suitable place for a lone man to stand.
```

events.title: Nick Reunites with Jordan and Hears Gossip About Gatsby
detailed_summary: Feeling intensely embarrassed and contemplating getting drunk, Nick spots Jordan Baker emerging from the house.
Jordan stood at the top of the steps, observing the garden with detached curiosity.
Nick felt compelled to join someone to avoid awkwardness.
He greeted her loudly across the garden.
Jordan acknowledged him casually, mentioning she thought he might be present since he lived nearby.
She briefly held his hand while listening to two girls in identical yellow dresses who approached.
The girls greeted Jordan, offering commiserations for her recent loss in a golf tournament final.
One girl mentioned they had met Jordan at a previous party about a month ago.
Jordan observed that the girl had changed her hair color since then.
As the girls departed, Jordan linked her arm with Nick's, and they walked down into the garden.
They accepted cocktails from a passing tray and sat at a table with the two girls in yellow and three unnamed men.
Jordan asked one of the girls if she attended Gatsby's parties frequently.
The girl confirmed she attended the last one where they met.
Her companion, Lucille, added that she enjoyed the parties because she could act freely and always had fun.
Lucille recounted tearing her dress at a previous party and receiving a replacement gown from Gatsby worth $265 after he asked for her details.
Jordan inquired if Lucille kept the expensive gown, which Lucille confirmed, noting it needed alterations.
The other girl remarked on the peculiarity of Gatsby's generosity, suggesting he avoids confrontation.
When Nick asked who they were discussing, the name 'Gatsby' was mentioned.
The two girls and Jordan leaned in together conspiratorially.
One girl whispered a rumor that Gatsby had killed someone.
This rumor created a palpable thrill among the group, including the three men.
Lucille countered sceptically, suggesting it was more likely he was a German spy during the war.
One of the men claimed confirmation from someone who supposedly grew up with Gatsby in Germany.
The first girl dismissed the spy theory, pointing out Gatsby served in the American army.
She intensified the murder rumor, suggesting observing Gatsby when he thinks he's unnoticed reveals his guilt.
Both Lucille and the first girl shivered, and the group instinctively looked around for Gatsby.
Nick mused on the romantic speculation surrounding Gatsby, noting even those usually indiscreet whispered about him.

events.text_segment:
I was on my way to get roaring drunk from sheer embarrassment when Jordan Baker came out of the house and stood at the head of the marble steps, leaning a little backward and looking with contemptuous interest down into the garden.
Welcome or not, I found it necessary to attach myself to someone before I should begin to address cordial remarks to the passersby.
“Hello!” I roared, advancing toward her. My voice seemed unnaturally loud across the garden.
“I thought you might be here,” she responded absently as I came up. “I remembered you lived next door to—”
She held my hand impersonally, as a promise that she’d take care of me in a minute, and gave ear to two girls in twin yellow dresses, who stopped at the foot of the steps.
“Hello!” they cried together. “Sorry you didn’t win.”
That was for the golf tournament. She had lost in the finals the week before.
“You don’t know who we are,” said one of the girls in yellow, “but we met you here about a month ago.”
“You’ve dyed your hair since then,” remarked Jordan, and I started, but the girls had moved casually on and her remark was addressed to the premature moon, produced like the supper, no doubt, out of a caterer’s basket. With Jordan’s slender golden arm resting in mine, we descended the steps and sauntered about the garden. A tray of cocktails floated at us through the twilight, and we sat down at a table with the two girls in yellow and three men, each one introduced to us as Mr. Mumble.
“Do you come to these parties often?” inquired Jordan of the girl beside her.
“The last one was the one I met you at,” answered the girl, in an alert confident voice. She turned to her companion: “Wasn’t it for you, Lucille?”
It was for Lucille, too.
“I like to come,” Lucille said. “I never care what I do, so I always have a good time. When I was here last I tore my gown on a chair, and he asked me my name and address—inside of a week I got a package from Croirier’s with a new evening gown in it.”
“Did you keep it?” asked Jordan.
“Sure I did. I was going to wear it tonight, but it was too big in the bust and had to be altered. It was gas blue with lavender beads. Two hundred and sixty-five dollars.”
“There’s something funny about a fellow that’ll do a thing like that,” said the other girl eagerly. “He doesn’t want any trouble with anybody.”
“Who doesn’t?” I inquired.
“Gatsby. Somebody told me—”
The two girls and Jordan leaned together confidentially.
“Somebody told me they thought he killed a man once.”
A thrill passed over all of us. The three Mr. Mumbles bent forward and listened eagerly.
“I don’t think it’s so much that,” argued Lucille sceptically; “It’s more that he was a German spy during the war.”
One of the men nodded in confirmation.
“I heard that from a man who knew all about him, grew up with him in Germany,” he assured us positively.
“Oh, no,” said the first girl, “it couldn’t be that, because he was in the American army during the war.” As our credulity switched back to her she leaned forward with enthusiasm. “You look at him sometimes when he thinks nobody’s looking at him. I’ll bet he killed a man.”
She narrowed her eyes and shivered. Lucille shivered. We all turned and looked around for Gatsby. It was testimony to the romantic speculation he inspired that there were whispers about him from those who had found little that it was necessary to whisper about in this world.

events.title: Encounter with the Owl-Eyed Man in the Library
detailed_summary: As the first supper service began, Jordan invited Nick to join her group at another table.
This group consisted of three married couples and Jordan's persistent, suggestive undergraduate escort, representing East Egg's reserved nobility contrasting with West Egg's flamboyance.
After about thirty minutes, Jordan expressed boredom with the polite company and suggested they leave to find Gatsby, noting Nick's unease about not having met him.
They searched the crowded bar, the top of the steps, and the veranda without finding Gatsby.
They decided to try an imposing door and entered a grand, oak-panelled library, likely imported.
Inside, a stout, middle-aged man with large spectacles sat drunk on a table, staring intently at the bookshelves.
He turned excitedly upon their entrance and scrutinized Jordan.
He demanded their opinion about the books.
Waving towards the shelves, he declared he had already ascertained their authenticity – they were real books with pages.
He expressed surprise, having expected them to be convincing fakes, like cardboard props.
To prove his point, he fetched a volume of the 'Stoddard Lectures'.
He triumphantly presented it as genuine printed matter, comparing Gatsby to the theatrical producer Belasco for his thorough realism.
He noted the pages weren't cut, implying they hadn't been read, but still praised the effort.
He quickly returned the book, warning that removing one might cause the whole library facade to collapse.
He inquired if Nick and Jordan were brought by someone, stating most guests were, including himself.
He mentioned being brought by a Mrs. Claud Roosevelt whom he met the previous night.
He admitted he'd been drunk for a week and hoped sitting in the library would sober him up.
When asked if it worked, he was unsure, having only been there an hour, and started to talk about the real books again.
Nick and Jordan confirmed he'd already told them, shook his hand formally, and left the library.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The first supper—there would be another one after midnight—was now being served, and Jordan invited me to join her own party, who were spread around a table on the other side of the garden.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We shook hands with him gravely and went back outdoors.

events.text_segment:
The first supper—there would be another one after midnight—was now being served, and Jordan invited me to join her own party, who were spread around a table on the other side of the garden. There were three married couples and Jordan’s escort, a persistent undergraduate given to violent innuendo, and obviously under the impression that sooner or later Jordan was going to yield him up her person to a greater or lesser degree. Instead of rambling, this party had preserved a dignified homogeneity, and assumed to itself the function of representing the staid nobility of the countryside—East Egg condescending to West Egg and carefully on guard against its spectroscopic gaiety.
“Let’s get out,” whispered Jordan, after a somehow wasteful and inappropriate half-hour; “this is much too polite for me.”
We got up, and she explained that we were going to find the host: I had never met him, she said, and it was making me uneasy. The undergraduate nodded in a cynical, melancholy way.
The bar, where we glanced first, was crowded, but Gatsby was not there. She couldn’t find him from the top of the steps, and he wasn’t on the veranda. On a chance we tried an important-looking door, and walked into a high Gothic library, panelled with carved English oak, and probably transported complete from some ruin overseas.
A stout, middle-aged man, with enormous owl-eyed spectacles, was sitting somewhat drunk on the edge of a great table, staring with unsteady concentration at the shelves of books. As we entered he wheeled excitedly around and examined Jordan from head to foot.
“What do you think?” he demanded impetuously.
“About what?”
He waved his hand toward the bookshelves.
“About that. As a matter of fact you needn’t bother to ascertain. I ascertained. They’re real.”
“The books?”
He nodded.
“Absolutely real—have pages and everything. I thought they’d be a nice durable cardboard. Matter of fact, they’re absolutely real. Pages and—Here! Lemme show you.”
Taking our scepticism for granted, he rushed to the bookcases and returned with Volume One of the Stoddard Lectures.
“See!” he cried triumphantly. “It’s a bona-fide piece of printed matter. It fooled me. This fella’s a regular Belasco. It’s a triumph. What thoroughness! What realism! Knew when to stop, too—didn’t cut the pages. But what do you want? What do you expect?”
He snatched the book from me and replaced it hastily on its shelf, muttering that if one brick was removed the whole library was liable to collapse.
“Who brought you?” he demanded. “Or did you just come? I was brought. Most people were brought.”
Jordan looked at him alertly, cheerfully, without answering.
“I was brought by a woman named Roosevelt,” he continued. “Mrs. Claud Roosevelt. Do you know her? I met her somewhere last night. I’ve been drunk for about a week now, and I thought it might sober me up to sit in a library.”
“Has it?”
“A little bit, I think. I can’t tell yet. I’ve only been here an hour. Did I tell you about the books? They’re real. They’re—”
“You told us.”
We shook hands with him gravely and went back outdoors.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The first supper—there would be another one after midnight—was now being served, and Jordan invited me to join her own party, who were spread around a table on the other side of the garden. I followed her, and presently I found myself at a table with a half dozen strangers, most of them, I gathered, from New York. There was a stout, florid man named Mr. Palmetto in a white suit, who kept telling a story about a motor-boat that had gone down in a storm, and a pair of young Englishwomen, who were complaining bitterly about the lack of privacy in America. They were, I imagine, the kind of people who go to every party at Gatsby’s mansion, year after year, without ever knowing him. The conversation was loud and disjointed, punctuated by bursts of laughter that seemed to come from nowhere and everywhere at once. People drifted in and out of our group, introducing themselves with a casualness that bordered on indifference. I felt a little lost, a little out of place. I was one of the few guests, I suspected, who had actually been invited. The rest seemed to have simply materialized, drawn by the magnetic pull of Gatsby’s wealth and the promise of a good time. Jordan, cool and detached, sat beside me, occasionally offering a cynical comment on the proceedings. She seemed to know everyone, or at least to recognize them from other parties, other places. She had that air of sophisticated boredom that I was beginning to associate with the wealthy set. As the evening wore on, the rumors about Gatsby began to circulate more freely. He was a German spy during the war. He had killed a man. He was a bootlegger. He was the nephew of Kaiser Wilhelm. Each story was more fantastic than the last, and no one seemed to know the truth. It was as if Gatsby were a character in a play, and the guests were the audience, speculating wildly about his past. I kept looking around, trying to catch a glimpse of my host. I had expected him to be more visible, perhaps greeting guests, but he was nowhere to be seen. It added to the mystery, the aura of the man. Who was this Gatsby, who threw such lavish parties and yet remained so elusive? The music from the orchestra on the lawn grew louder, more insistent. Couples were dancing on the polished floor of the veranda, their movements fluid and graceful in the soft light. The garden was a kaleidoscope of color and sound, a vibrant, pulsating entity. Waiters circulated with trays of cocktails, their white jackets gleaming in the darkness. The air was thick with the scent of flowers and perfume and the faint, intoxicating aroma of alcohol. I tried to engage in conversation, but I found it difficult. The people at our table seemed more interested in talking about themselves or gossiping about others. There was a superficiality to their interactions, a lack of genuine connection. It was all about appearances, about being seen at the right place, with the right people. Jordan leaned closer to me. "Aren't you having fun, Nick?" she asked, her voice low. "I'm trying," I said, smiling. "It's quite a spectacle." "It is," she agreed. "Most of these people come here every weekend. They don't even know Gatsby. They just come for the party." "That's extraordinary," I said. "It is," she repeated, taking a sip of her drink. "He must be a very lonely man." The thought struck me. All this extravagance, all this effort, and for what? To entertain a crowd of strangers who didn't care about him, who were only interested in the free food and drink and the opportunity to mingle with others of their kind. It seemed a sad, empty existence. I looked out at the garden, at the swirling mass of people, the bright lights, the sound of the music. It was a scene of unparalleled excess, a testament to the roaring twenties and the boundless optimism, or perhaps recklessness, of the age. And at the center of it all was the invisible man, the mysterious Gatsby, the host who remained hidden in the shadows, watching, waiting. For what, I wondered? What was he hoping to find in this endless parade of faces? What was he searching for in the glittering chaos of his own creation? The questions hung in the air, unanswered, adding another layer to the enigma that was Jay Gatsby.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: The first supper—there would be another one after midnight—was now being served, and Jordan invited me to join her own party, who were spread around a table on the other side of the garden. There were three married couples and Jordan’s escort, a persistent undergraduate given to violent innuendo, and obviously under the impression that casual limousines were too odd a thing to take seriously. I was immediately struck by the familiar conviction that it was all a mistake and that I was not wanted. A celebrated tenor had sung in Italian, and a notorious contralto had sung in jazz, and between the numbers people were doing ‘stunts’ all over the garden, while happy, vacuous bursts of laughter rose toward the summer sky. A pair of stage twins, who turned out to be the girls in yellow, did a national dance, and four other girls made an incoherent shriek at the neighbouring tables. As soon as I arrived the undergraduate began in a loud voice to ask me if I hadn’t seen a girl around ‘in a white dress.’ She was ‘a little fat girl,’ he added parenthetically. ‘By the way, I’m Mr. McKee,’ he announced suddenly. ‘I’m from West Egg.’ ‘Same here. I live next door to Gatsby’s.’ ‘Know Gatsby?’ demanded the undergraduate suddenly. ‘I live at West Egg,’ I said automatically. ‘Well, I live at West Egg,’ he repeated, in a hurt tone; and she looked at him alertly, sharply, as if she were gathering some vital information from his character. His speaking voice, a gruff, husky tenor, added to the impression of fractiousness he conveyed. We were at a particularly exhilarated table. There was a sharp, unpleasant discordance in the air, as if the orchestra were tuning up for the ancient prelude to the opera *La Traviata*. I sat down at a table with the two girls in yellow and three men, each of whom seemed to have a suit of clothes waiting for him in a box somewhere inside. I was about to ask him if he had seen Mr. Gatsby when he said, suddenly, ‘I’m Gatsby.’ The two girls in yellow were laughing together, and I knew why. They were laughing because he was Gatsby. I had been talking to him for ten minutes without knowing it. ‘Your face is familiar,’ he said, politely. ‘Weren’t you in the Third Division during the war?’ ‘Why, yes. He’s a regular Belasco.’ He looked at me again. ‘Are you a friend of Gatsby’s?’ he asked. ‘I know him slightly,’ I said. ‘Well, I’m not a friend of his,’ he said. ‘I just met him. I was brought by a Mrs. Claud Roosevelt whom I met last night. I’ve been drunk for about a week now, and I thought it might sober me up to sit in a library.’ ‘Has it?’ ‘A little,’ he said. ‘I don’t know yet. I’ve been sitting here for about an hour, and I don’t think it’s done me any good.’ He looked at the shelves again. ‘These books are real,’ he remarked. ‘The whole library’s real. He’s a regular Belasco. It’s a triumph. What thoroughness! What realism! Knew when to stop, too—didn’t cut the pages. But what do you want? What do you expect?’ He waved his hand towards the shelves. ‘They’re real books,’ he repeated. ‘Look!’ I looked. The books were real. They were bound in leather and gold, and they had pages

events.title: Nick Unknowingly Meets Gatsby
detailed_summary: Back outside, dancing had commenced on the garden's canvas platform.
Various couples danced, some awkwardly, some fashionably, while single girls danced alone or briefly joined the orchestra.
By midnight, the party's energy escalated; performers sang, guests performed 'stunts,' and laughter filled the air.
The girls in yellow performed a costumed act, and champagne was served in large glasses.
The moon cast a silvery light on the Sound.
Nick, still with Jordan, sat at a table with a man his age and a boisterous young woman.
Nick began enjoying himself after drinking champagne, finding the scene transformed.
During a pause, the man at the table smiled at Nick.
The man commented on Nick's familiar face and asked if he served in the First Division during the war.
Nick confirmed his service in the Twenty-eighth Infantry.
The man shared his own service in the Sixteenth Infantry.
They briefly reminisced about villages in France.
The man mentioned living nearby, having just bought a hydroplane he planned to test.
He invited Nick to join him for a flight along the shore the next morning.
Nick agreed and asked for a time, receiving a flexible response.
Just as Nick was about to ask the man's name, Jordan interjected, asking if he was having a better time.
Nick confirmed he was enjoying himself more and turned back to the man.
He explained the party was unusual for him as he hadn't met the host, gesturing towards his own house nearby and mentioning Gatsby sent the invitation.
The man looked momentarily confused.
He then identified himself suddenly as Gatsby.
Nick expressed surprise and apologized.
Gatsby, calling Nick 'old sport,' apologized for being a poor host, assuming Nick already knew who he was.
Gatsby offered a remarkable, reassuring smile that seemed to embrace the world before focusing entirely on Nick with immense favor.
The smile conveyed deep understanding and belief, projecting the exact positive impression Nick hoped to make.
The smile vanished abruptly, revealing an elegant man around thirty, whose formal speech bordered on absurd, suggesting carefully chosen words.
Nick realized Gatsby had been selecting his words deliberately even before the introduction.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was dancing now on the canvas in the garden; old men pushing young girls backward in eternal graceless circles, superior couples holding each other tortuously, fashionably, and keeping in the corners—and a great number of single girls dancing individually or relieving the orchestra for a moment of the burden of the banjo or the traps.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Some time before he introduced himself I’d got a strong impression that he was picking his words with care.

events.text_segment:
There was dancing now on the canvas in the garden; old men pushing young girls backward in eternal graceless circles, superior couples holding each other tortuously, fashionably, and keeping in the corners—and a great number of single girls dancing individually or relieving the orchestra for a moment of the burden of the banjo or the traps. By midnight the hilarity had increased. A celebrated tenor had sung in Italian, and a notorious contralto had sung in jazz, and between the numbers people were doing “stunts” all over the garden, while happy, vacuous bursts of laughter rose toward the summer sky. A pair of stage twins, who turned out to be the girls in yellow, did a baby act in costume, and champagne was served in glasses bigger than finger-bowls. The moon had risen higher, and floating in the Sound was a triangle of silver scales, trembling a little to the stiff, tinny drip of the banjoes on the lawn.
I was still with Jordan Baker. We were sitting at a table with a man of about my age and a rowdy little girl, who gave way upon the slightest provocation to uncontrollable laughter. I was enjoying myself now. I had taken two finger-bowls of champagne, and the scene had changed before my eyes into something significant, elemental, and profound.
At a lull in the entertainment the man looked at me and smiled.
“Your face is familiar,” he said politely. “Weren’t you in the First Division during the war?”
“Why yes. I was in the Twenty-eighth Infantry.”
“I was in the Sixteenth until June nineteen-eighteen. I knew I’d seen you somewhere before.”
We talked for a moment about some wet, grey little villages in France. Evidently he lived in this vicinity, for he told me that he had just bought a hydroplane, and was going to try it out in the morning.
“Want to go with me, old sport? Just near the shore along the Sound.”
“What time?”
“Any time that suits you best.”
It was on the tip of my tongue to ask his name when Jordan looked around and smiled.
“Having a gay time now?” she inquired.
“Much better.” I turned again to my new acquaintance. “This is an unusual party for me. I haven’t even seen the host. I live over there—” I waved my hand at the invisible hedge in the distance, “and this man Gatsby sent over his chauffeur with an invitation.”
For a moment he looked at me as if he failed to understand.
“I’m Gatsby,” he said suddenly.
“What!” I exclaimed. “Oh, I beg your pardon.”
“I thought you knew, old sport. I’m afraid I’m not a very good host.”
He smiled understandingly—much more than understandingly. It was one of those rare smiles with a quality of eternal reassurance in it, that you may come across four or five times in life. It faced—or seemed to face—the whole eternal world for an instant, and then concentrated on you with an irresistible prejudice in your favour. It understood you just so far as you wanted to be understood, believed in you as you would like to believe in yourself, and assured you that it had precisely the impression of you that, at your best, you hoped to convey. Precisely at that point it vanished—and I was looking at an elegant young roughneck, a year or two over thirty, whose elaborate formality of speech just missed being absurd. Some time before he introduced himself I’d got a strong impression that he was picking his words with care.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: There was dancing now on the canvas in the garden; old men pushing young girls backward in eternal graceless circles, superior couples holding each other tortuously, fashionably, and keeping in the corners—and a great number of single girls dancing individually or relieving the orchestra for a moment of the burden of the banjo or the traps. The groups change swiftly, swell with new arrivals, dissolve and form in the same breath; already the lamps in the garden were glowing with a yellow cheerfulness, and by eight o'clock the orchestra had arrived—no thin five-piece affair, but a whole pitful of oboes and trombones and saxophones and viols and cornets and piccolos, and a whole drum, all playing the "Jazz History of the World" in four movements. The party had begun. I was still with Jordan Baker. We were sitting at a table with some people we knew, and some people we didn't know. The people we didn't know were introduced by the people we did know. They were all young, and they were all rich, and they were all trying very hard to be sophisticated. They talked about New York, about the theatre, about the latest scandals. Their laughter was loud and frequent, a brittle sound that seemed to shatter the air around them. Waiters circulated with trays of cocktails, and the air grew thick with the scent of gin and orange peel. As the evening advanced, the cocktails spread with a similar abandon, and the hilarity increased. Laughter was easier, or more piercing, depending on the amount of alcohol consumed. The groups around the tables became more fluid, people drifting from one conversation to another, their voices rising above the music. There was a constant buzz, a hum of human voices that was almost as loud as the orchestra. People were talking about everything and nothing, their words tumbling out in a rush, fueled by the alcohol and the excitement of the night. I noticed that no one seemed to know Gatsby, or at least, no one I spoke to did. They were all guests, invited or not, drawn by the magnetic pull of his wealth and the promise of a good time. They speculated about him, whispered rumors and theories. Some said he had killed a man, others that he was a German spy during the war. One woman insisted he was a relative of Kaiser Wilhelm. These stories, wild and improbable, added to the mystique surrounding the host, a man who remained largely invisible amidst the throng he had gathered. The garden was a riot of color and sound. Chinese lanterns hung from the trees, casting a soft, ethereal glow. The dance floor was packed, a swirling mass of bodies moving to the frantic rhythm of the jazz band. The music was loud, insistent, driving the dancers into a frenzy. People were dancing with a kind of desperate energy, as if trying to outrun something, or perhaps just trying to forget themselves for a few hours. The alcohol continued to flow, and the party became more raucous. Women were laughing hysterically, men were slapping each other on the back, their faces flushed and their ties askew. The veneer of sophistication was beginning to crack, revealing the underlying vulgarity and emptiness. People were behaving with a careless abandon, their inhibitions dissolving with each drink. There were arguments, loud and public, followed by equally loud and public reconciliations. There were couples who had clearly just met, locked in passionate embraces on the edges of the dance floor. It was a world of instant gratification, of fleeting connections and superficial pleasures. Everyone was there to be seen, to be entertained, to escape the mundane reality of their lives. They were like moths drawn to a flame, circling around the bright, dazzling light of Gatsby's wealth and extravagance. And in the center of it all, the mysterious host remained elusive, a figure of rumor and speculation, the orchestrator of this elaborate, glittering spectacle. The night wore on, the music played louder, the laughter grew wilder, and the party, like a runaway train, hurtled towards its inevitable, messy conclusion. The air was thick with the smell of perfume, alcohol, and the faint, underlying scent of desperation.

events.title: Gatsby's Enigma and Detachment
detailed_summary: Immediately after Gatsby identified himself, a butler arrived with news of a phone call from Chicago.
Gatsby excused himself courteously to the group, urging Nick to ask for anything he needed and promising to return later.
Once Gatsby left, Nick turned to Jordan, expressing his surprise, admitting he had pictured Gatsby as older and heavier.
Nick asked Jordan about Gatsby's identity and origins.
Jordan replied simply that he's 'just a man named Gatsby.'
When pressed about Gatsby's background and profession, Jordan mentioned Gatsby once claimed to be an Oxford graduate.
This briefly created a potential background for Gatsby, but Jordan immediately expressed her disbelief.
Her sceptical tone reminded Nick of the earlier rumor about Gatsby killing someone, fueling his curiosity.
Nick reflected that humble origins would be understandable, but a young man mysteriously appearing and buying a palace seemed implausible.
Jordan steered the conversation away from specifics, stating she likes Gatsby's large, intimate parties where privacy is possible.
The orchestra leader announced the next piece, requested by Gatsby: Vladimir Tostoff's 'Jazz History of the World,' described as a recent sensation.
As the music started, Nick observed Gatsby standing alone on the steps, watching the party with an approving gaze.
Nick noted Gatsby's healthy appearance and neat grooming, seeing nothing sinister.
He speculated Gatsby's sobriety might set him apart, as Gatsby seemed to grow more formal while the guests became more uninhibited.
After the music ended, guests engaged in playful, intimate behavior, but no one approached Gatsby in such a manner; he remained separate.

events.text_segment:
Almost at the moment when Mr. Gatsby identified himself a butler hurried toward him with the information that Chicago was calling him on the wire. He excused himself with a small bow that included each of us in turn.
“If you want anything just ask for it, old sport,” he urged me. “Excuse me. I will rejoin you later.”
When he was gone I turned immediately to Jordan—constrained to assure her of my surprise. I had expected that Mr. Gatsby would be a florid and corpulent person in his middle years.
“Who is he?” I demanded. “Do you know?”
“He’s just a man named Gatsby.”
“Where is he from, I mean? And what does he do?”
“Now you’re started on the subject,” she answered with a wan smile. “Well, he told me once he was an Oxford man.”
A dim background started to take shape behind him, but at her next remark it faded away.
“However, I don’t believe it.”
“Why not?”
“I don’t know,” she insisted, “I just don’t think he went there.”
Something in her tone reminded me of the other girl’s “I think he killed a man,” and had the effect of stimulating my curiosity. I would have accepted without question the information that Gatsby sprang from the swamps of Louisiana or from the lower East Side of New York. That was comprehensible. But young men didn’t—at least in my provincial inexperience I believed they didn’t—drift coolly out of nowhere and buy a palace on Long Island Sound.
“Anyhow, he gives large parties,” said Jordan, changing the subject with an urban distaste for the concrete. “And I like large parties. They’re so intimate. At small parties there isn’t any privacy.”
There was the boom of a bass drum, and the voice of the orchestra leader rang out suddenly above the echolalia of the garden.
“Ladies and gentlemen,” he cried. “At the request of Mr. Gatsby we are going to play for you Mr. Vladmir Tostoff’s latest work, which attracted so much attention at Carnegie Hall last May. If you read the papers you know there was a big sensation.” He smiled with jovial condescension, and added: “Some sensation!” Whereupon everybody laughed.
“The piece is known,” he concluded lustily, “as ‘Vladmir Tostoff’s Jazz History of the World!’ ”
The nature of Mr. Tostoff’s composition eluded me, because just as it began my eyes fell on Gatsby, standing alone on the marble steps and looking from one group to another with approving eyes. His tanned skin was drawn attractively tight on his face and his short hair looked as though it were trimmed every day. I could see nothing sinister about him. I wondered if the fact that he was not drinking helped to set him off from his guests, for it seemed to me that he grew more correct as the fraternal hilarity increased. When the “Jazz History of the World” was over, girls were putting their heads on men’s shoulders in a puppyish, convivial way, girls were swooning backward playfully into men’s arms, even into groups, knowing that someone would arrest their falls—but no one swooned backward on Gatsby, and no French bob touched Gatsby’s shoulder, and no singing quartets were formed with Gatsby’s head for one link.

He excused himself with a quick, apologetic smile, a smile of eternal reassurance, and disappeared into the house. His brief absence seemed to leave a momentary void in the vibrant chaos of the garden. Nick, left standing with Jordan Baker, watched him go, a fresh layer of mystery settling over the man he had just met. The phone call from Chicago added another piece to the enigmatic puzzle that was Jay Gatsby. It hinted at a world of business, perhaps illicit, far removed from West Egg's glittering facade. Jordan turned to Nick, her eyes cool and appraising. 'He's always taking calls,' she remarked, her voice a low, bored murmur. 'From all over. Philadelphia, Chicago, places like that.' 'Business?' Nick ventured. Jordan shrugged, a slight, elegant movement. 'Who knows? Something big, I suppose. He's a man of many secrets.' She paused, then added, 'Did you hear the rumors about him? That he killed a man? Or that he was a German spy during the war?' Nick shook his head, fascinated by the effortless way she relayed such sensational gossip. 'No, I hadn't heard those.' 'Oh, they're everywhere,' she said dismissively. 'Nobody knows the truth about him. Not really.' They drifted back into the throng, the music swelling around them. The party was in full swing, a dizzying spectacle of wealth and excess. People danced with a frantic energy, their laughter echoing across the lawn. Waiters circulated with trays of cocktails, their movements precise and tireless. The air was thick with the scent of flowers and perfume, mingled with the sharp tang of alcohol. Nick felt increasingly like a detached observer in this elaborate production. He watched the faces around him – some familiar,

simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: Almost at the moment when Mr. Gatsby identified himself a butler hurried toward him with the information that Chicago was calling him on the wire. He excused himself with a slight bow and hurried off into the house. He was gone, and I began to wonder if I hadn’t imagined him. The butler came back and stood by his chair throughout the ensuing half hour. “Did you know we had a bond man here?” inquired Jordan suddenly. “A bond man?” “Everybody thinks he went to Oxford.” “He went to Oxford?” “Yes, she said she knew the man who made the cap and gown for him. It’s one of the funniest things I ever heard.” We were silent for a moment. The orchestra leader waited for a moment and then raised his baton and the orchestra plunged into the first bars of a piece of music which was introduced as “Vladimir Tostoff’s Jazz History of the World.” The piece was a sensation, and the orchestra leader was a sensation, and the whole party was a sensation. events.title: Gatsby Summons Jordan; Party Degenerates
detailed_summary: Gatsby's butler approached Nick and Jordan.
He requested Miss Baker speak with Mr. Gatsby privately.
Jordan reacted with surprise but slowly rose and followed the butler towards the house.
Nick observed Jordan's athletic posture and movement, likening her walk to one developed on golf courses.
Alone again near two a.m., Nick heard intriguing, confused sounds from a room overlooking the terrace.
Avoiding Jordan's former escort (now occupied with chorus girls), Nick went inside the room.
The large room was crowded.
One of the girls in yellow played piano while a red-haired chorus singer performed.
The singer, heavily intoxicated with champagne, had become overwhelmed with sadness, weeping as she sang.
She filled pauses with sobs before continuing in a trembling voice, tears making black streaks through her makeup.
A guest humorously suggested she sing the tear tracks, causing her to collapse into a chair in a drunken sleep.
A nearby girl explained to Nick that the singer had argued with her supposed husband.
Nick looked around and noticed many women arguing with men presumed to be their husbands.
Even Jordan's sophisticated East Egg group had descended into discord; one man focused intently on an actress while his wife alternated between feigned indifference and angry, whispered accusations.
Resistance to leaving wasn't limited to men; two sober men were being urged to leave by their indignant wives.
The wives complained loudly to each other about their husbands wanting to leave whenever they were having fun, calling it selfish.
One husband pointed out sheepishly that they were nearly the last guests, as the orchestra had already left.
Despite the wives' agreement on the husbands' unbelievable behavior, the argument ended with the men physically carrying their protesting wives out.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I beg your pardon.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In spite of the wives’ agreement that such malevolence was beyond credibility, the dispute ended in a short struggle, and both wives were lifted, kicking, into the night.

events.text_segment:
“I beg your pardon.”
Gatsby’s butler was suddenly standing beside us.
“Miss Baker?” he inquired. “I beg your pardon, but Mr. Gatsby would like to speak to you alone.”
“With me?” she exclaimed in surprise.
“Yes, madame.”
She got up slowly, raising her eyebrows at me in astonishment, and followed the butler toward the house. I noticed that she wore her evening-dress, all her dresses, like sports clothes—there was a jauntiness about her movements as if she had first learned to walk upon golf courses on clean, crisp mornings.
I was alone and it was almost two. For some time confused and intriguing sounds had issued from a long, many-windowed room which overhung the terrace. Eluding Jordan’s undergraduate, who was now engaged in an obstetrical conversation with two chorus girls, and who implored me to join him, I went inside.
The large room was full of people. One of the girls in yellow was playing the piano, and beside her stood a tall, red-haired young lady from a famous chorus, engaged in song. She had drunk a quantity of champagne, and during the course of her song she had decided, ineptly, that everything was very, very sad—she was not only singing, she was weeping too. Whenever there was a pause in the song she filled it with gasping, broken sobs, and then took up the lyric again in a quavering soprano. The tears coursed down her cheeks—not freely, however, for when they came into contact with her heavily beaded eyelashes they assumed an inky colour, and pursued the rest of their way in slow black rivulets. A humorous suggestion was made that she sing the notes on her face, whereupon she threw up her hands, sank into a chair, and went off into a deep vinous sleep.
“She had a fight with a man who says he’s her husband,” explained a girl at my elbow.
I looked around. Most of the remaining women were now having fights with men said to be their husbands. Even Jordan’s party, the quartet from East Egg, were rent asunder by dissension. One of the men was talking with curious intensity to a young actress, and his wife, after attempting to laugh at the situation in a dignified and indifferent way, broke down entirely and resorted to flank attacks—at intervals she appeared suddenly at his side like an angry diamond, and hissed: “You promised!” into his ear.
The reluctance to go home was not confined to wayward men. The hall was at present occupied by two deplorably sober men and their highly indignant wives. The wives were sympathizing with each other in slightly raised voices.
“Whenever he sees I’m having a good time he wants to go home.”
“Never heard anything so selfish in my life.”
“We’re always the first ones to leave.”
“So are we.”
“Well, we’re almost the last tonight,” said one of the men sheepishly. “The orchestra left half an hour ago.”
In spite of the wives’ agreement that such malevolence was beyond credibility, the dispute ended in a short struggle, and both wives were lifted, kicking, into the night.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: I beg your pardon.” The voice was low, almost a murmur against the insistent jazz that spilled from the ballroom, but it cut through the din with surprising clarity. I turned, my glass of champagne momentarily forgotten in my hand. It was a young woman, her face a pale oval in the shifting lights, her eyes wide with a sort of startled innocence that seemed out of place in this riotous assembly. She wore a dress of shimmering gold, catching the light like a trapped sunbeam. “Did I… did I say something?” I asked, feeling a sudden, inexplicable flush rise to my cheeks. The alcohol, perhaps, or the sheer overwhelming strangeness of the evening. She shook her head slowly, a faint smile touching her lips. “No, not at all. It’s just… I thought I heard you mention… West Egg?” “Yes,” I confirmed, a little wary. “I live there. Just next door to… well, to this place.” I gestured vaguely towards the mansion, its colossal silhouette looming behind us, a beacon of ostentatious wealth against the summer night sky. “Oh,” she breathed, her smile widening slightly. “How extraordinary. I’m from the Midwest myself, you see. Just visiting. My cousin brought me.” She didn’t offer her name, and I didn’t press. Names seemed fluid here, less important than the fleeting connections forged in the heat of the moment. We stood in silence for a moment, the music washing over us, the laughter and chatter of hundreds of voices swirling around like leaves in a storm. I watched the dancers, a blur of color and movement, their faces flushed with excitement and something else – a desperate, almost frantic pursuit of pleasure. It struck me, not for the first time that night, how utterly alone I felt amidst this throng. Everyone seemed to know everyone, or at least pretended to, their conversations a tapestry of shared jokes and knowing glances. I, the observer, the quiet man from the West, felt like an anthropologist studying a peculiar, vibrant tribe. The young woman beside me sighed softly. “It’s quite something, isn’t it?” “It is,” I agreed. “Overwhelming.” “He must be a remarkable man,” she said, her gaze fixed on the mansion. “To throw parties like this. Every weekend, they say.” “Gatsby?” I supplied. She nodded. “Yes. Mr. Gatsby. I haven’t even seen him yet. Have you?” “Briefly,” I said. “Earlier this evening.” I didn’t elaborate. My brief encounter with the host had been as enigmatic as everything else about him. A smile that understood you, a carefully chosen word, and then he was gone, swallowed by the crowd. “What’s he like?” she asked, turning her wide eyes back to me. I hesitated. How to describe Gatsby? The rumors were legion – a German spy, an Oxford man, a murderer, a bootlegger. He was a figure of myth before he was a man. “He’s… reserved,” I settled on, which felt like a ridiculous understatement. “And very polite.” She seemed disappointed by my answer. “Oh. I expected… I don’t know. Something more.” “Perhaps he is,” I said. “I’ve only just met him myself.” A sudden burst of raucous laughter erupted nearby, drawing our attention. A group of young women, their dresses hiked up, were attempting a clumsy Charleston on the lawn, egged on by several equally inebriated young men. Their gaiety was loud, forced, a brittle shell over something less joyful. “It’s all so… temporary,” the young woman in gold said, her voice barely audible above the din. “Like spun sugar. Beautiful, but it melts away.” Her words struck a chord. That was it, wasn’t it? The ephemeral nature of it all. The wealth, the parties, the relationships forged and broken in the space of a single night. It was a world built on illusion, on the desperate hope that if you danced fast enough, drank enough, laughed loud enough, you could outrun the emptiness that lurked beneath the surface. I looked at her, really looked at her, and saw a flicker of the same disillusionment I felt. She wasn’t just a pretty face in a gold dress; she was another soul adrift in this glittering, chaotic sea. “Perhaps,” I said, choosing my words carefully, “some things are meant to melt away. Maybe that’s the point.” She didn’t reply, her gaze drifting back to the mansion, its lights blazing like a challenge to the darkness. The music swelled, a saxophone wailing a mournful, bluesy tune that seemed to capture the underlying sadness of the scene. I finished my champagne, the bubbles long gone, leaving only a flat, slightly bitter taste. The night was still young, but I already felt the weariness settling in, the quiet ache of being an outsider looking in on a world that was both dazzling and deeply flawed. I wondered what she was thinking, this girl from the Midwest, dropped into the heart of this roaring, reckless decade. Was she enchanted, or merely bewildered? Or perhaps, like me, she saw the cracks in the gilded facade. The air grew cooler as the night deepened, carrying the scent of cut grass and the distant, metallic tang of the Sound. The party raged on, a relentless, unstoppable force, pulling everyone into its orbit, promising everything and perhaps delivering nothing but a hangover and a vague sense of dissatisfaction in the morning light. I knew, with a certainty that chilled me, that this was just the beginning of my entanglement with this world, with Gatsby, and with the intoxicating, dangerous allure of the American Dream gone wild.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: I beg your pardon.” Gatsby’s butler was suddenly standing beside us. “Miss Baker?” he inquired. “I beg your pardon, but Mr. Gatsby would like to speak to you alone.” “With me?” she exclaimed, in a burst of surprise. “About what?” “He wouldn’t say, madam. Excuse me.” She looked at me several times, her brows bent in an anxious frown, but finally she got up and followed the butler to the house. I waited, and sure enough, in a few minutes she came out again, walking slowly, in her sweet, supple way, a balance it seemed she had developed by walking on tightropes all her life. Or, perhaps, that was only the effect of the dress. The white dress was ripped where she had torn a hole in it with a golf-club that afternoon. It was two o’clock. The orchestra had played the melancholy theme from Tchaikovsky, and the butler had waited for an hour, and then they had started storming the doors. “You see,” cried a lady, “they can’t get in!” “They can’t get in,” repeated a gentleman, “because the doors are locked.” “Oh, but they are not locked,” insisted the lady. She was right. The doors were not locked. And once inside, the large room was crowded. A girl in yellow played the piano, and a red-haired girl sang a song about the rain. She was heavily drunk with champagne, and she was weeping bitterly. She filled the pauses in the song with sobs, and then she went on in a trembling voice, tears making black streaks through the mascara all the way down her cheeks. A guest suggested that she sing us and weep no more, and she collapsed in a heap on a chair. “She argued with her husband,” explained a girl beside me. I looked around. Many women were arguing with men said to be their husbands. Even the sophisticated group from East Egg, which had been sitting together at the table, had disintegrated. One man was absorbed in deep conversation with the actress, and his wife alternated between an airy disdain and a fiercely possessive stare. Resistance to growing old and fat and fifty, which she found in the actress, had made her face hard and sharp and greedy. Two sober men were being urged from the house by their indignant wives. “Whenever I get to having a good time,” cried one of the wives, “some fool of a man always wants to go home with me.” “Selfish as hell,” muttered the other. “We’re almost the last house-party I’ve been to in five years,” said the husband, looking at his watch. “The orchestra left half an hour ago.” “Unbelievable behavior,” agreed the wives. They were not to be moved. The two men picked up their wives and started for the door. The wives were protesting violently, but there was nothing to be done. They were carried out, and the door closed behind them.

1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion introduces a lengthy, repetitive exchange about locked doors that is not present in the original passage. This invented dialogue dominates the latter part of the completion and distracts from the actual sequence of events.
- The completion omits several major scenes from the original, including the depiction of the party's atmosphere, the musical performance, the emotional breakdown of a guest, and the altercations between couples.
- There is an invented internal monologue and personal reflection from the narrator about feelings for Jordan and past relationships, which does not appear in the original at this point in the narrative.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion lacks the description of Jordan's demeanor and attire as she leaves with the butler, as well as the narrator's observations about her manner of movement.
- The transition to the narrator being alone and the time of night is not clearly established.
- The depiction of the party inside, including the music, the emotional state of the guests, and the specific actions of the woman in yellow, is missing.
- The sequence of quarrels among the guests, including the specific interactions between husbands and wives and the eventual resolution, is omitted.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion provides inaccurate or invented dialogue between the butler and Jordan, including questions and responses not found in the original.
- The timing and sequence of events are confused; the completion suggests Jordan returns quickly, which does not align with the original progression.
- The invented internal reflections and references to the narrator's feelings and past are misplaced and do not match the original content or tone at this point.
- The invented dialogue about locked doors is not only inaccurate but also disrupts the flow and structure of the original narrative.

events.title: Jordan Hints at Secrets; Nick Departs
detailed_summary: While Nick waited for his hat, Jordan and Gatsby emerged from the library.
Gatsby was speaking earnestly to Jordan but quickly became formal as other guests approached to leave.
Jordan's group called for her from the porch, but she paused to shake Nick's hand.
She whispered that she had just heard something astonishing, asking how long they were in the library (about an hour).
Jordan repeated it was 'simply amazing' but stated she was sworn to secrecy, playfully tantalizing Nick.
Yawning, she invited Nick to visit, providing her aunt's name (Mrs. Sigourney Howard) for the phone book.
She hurried away, waving goodbye as she joined her party.
Feeling slightly embarrassed for staying so late on his first visit, Nick joined the remaining guests around Gatsby.
He wanted to explain his earlier search for Gatsby and apologize for not recognizing him.
Gatsby dismissed it warmly, telling Nick not to worry.
He reminded Nick about their hydroplane plans for nine the next morning, his familiar phrase ('old sport') now feeling less personal.
The butler interrupted, informing Gatsby that Philadelphia was on the phone.
Gatsby instructed the butler to tell them he'd be there shortly and bid Nick good night.
As Nick left, Gatsby's smile made him feel a pleasant significance in being among the last guests.
Gatsby repeated 'Good night, old sport... Good night.'

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As I waited for my hat in the hall the door of the library opened and Jordan Baker and Gatsby came out together.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Good night, old sport… Good night.”

events.text_segment:
As I waited for my hat in the hall the door of the library opened and Jordan Baker and Gatsby came out together. He was saying some last word to her, but the eagerness in his manner tightened abruptly into formality as several people approached him to say goodbye.
Jordan’s party were calling impatiently to her from the porch, but she lingered for a moment to shake hands.
“I’ve just heard the most amazing thing,” she whispered. “How long were we in there?”
“Why, about an hour.”
“It was… simply amazing,” she repeated abstractedly. “But I swore I wouldn’t tell it and here I am tantalizing you.” She yawned gracefully in my face. “Please come and see me… Phone book… Under the name of Mrs. Sigourney Howard… My aunt…” She was hurrying off as she talked—her brown hand waved a jaunty salute as she melted into her party at the door.
Rather ashamed that on my first appearance I had stayed so late, I joined the last of Gatsby’s guests, who were clustered around him. I wanted to explain that I’d hunted for him early in the evening and to apologize for not having known him in the garden.
“Don’t mention it,” he enjoined me eagerly. “Don’t give it another thought, old sport.” The familiar expression held no more familiarity than the hand which reassuringly brushed my shoulder. “And don’t forget we’re going up in the hydroplane tomorrow morning, at nine o’clock.”
Then the butler, behind his shoulder:
“Philadelphia wants you on the phone, sir.”
“All right, in a minute. Tell them I’ll be right there… Good night.”
“Good night.”
“Good night.” He smiled—and suddenly there seemed to be a pleasant significance in having been among the last to go, as if he had desired it all the time. “Good night, old sport… Good night.”
