simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: As I waited for my hat in the hall the door of the library opened and Jordan Baker and Gatsby came out together. He was saying some last word to her in a low voice, and she answered him with an interested glance and a faint smile. Then she saw me and smiled, too. ‘Good night!’ called a woman from the steps. ‘The orchestra’s playing the “Love Nest,”’ she added incidentally. ‘Oh, my God!’ answered the woman with whom she was talking. I turned again to Gatsby and saw that he was still looking at Jordan Baker, but stood making an impatient gesture with his hand. ‘I’m five years too late for that,’ he said sadly. ‘Look here, this is a Mr. Carraway, an acquaintance of mine just met this afternoon.’ They shook hands briefly, and then she hurried on toward the steps. ‘Come to see me,’ she urged. ‘Telephone book… look under the name of Mrs. Sigourney Howard… My aunt will be glad to see you…’ ‘That’s sweet of you,’ I said, but she hurried up the steps. ‘You live at West Egg,’ she remarked contemptuously. She vanished into the crowd, and Gatsby turned to me again. ‘One moment!’ he said. ‘I’d like to speak to you about something very important, old sport.’ I followed him inside. We went into the library, and he closed the door. ‘I’ve been meaning to speak to you about this for some time,’ he began. ‘You see, I’ve heard about you from Jordan Baker.’ He paused, and I waited. ‘She told me about your conversation this afternoon.’ I nodded. ‘Well,’ he said, ‘she’s a great friend of mine, and I know she wouldn’t tell me anything that wasn’t true.’ He paused again. ‘I understand you’re a man of fine judgment and discretion.’ I was puzzled. ‘I’m afraid I don’t understand,’ I said. ‘Well, it’s a rather delicate matter,’ he continued. ‘You see, I’m in a position to do you a favor, and I’d like to do it for you.’ I was still more puzzled. ‘A favor?’ I repeated. ‘Yes, a favor. Something that would be of great help to you. Something that you’ve been wanting for a long time.’ He looked at me intently. ‘I don’t know what you mean,’ I said. ‘Well, it’s about your business,’ he said. ‘I understand you’re in the bond business.’ ‘That’s right,’ I said. ‘Well, I happen to know some people who are in a position to do you a great deal of good. People who could put you in the way of some money.’ I was astonished. ‘You mean—’ I began. ‘Yes,’ he interrupted. ‘I mean that I could arrange for you to meet some people who could help you out. People who could give you a hand up.’ He smiled. ‘It’s a little matter, but it might mean a great deal to you.’ I was silent for a moment. ‘I appreciate your offer,’ I said finally, ‘but I don’t think I can accept it.’ He looked surprised. ‘Why not?’ he asked. ‘Well,’ I said, ‘I’m afraid I don’t understand the situation. And I don’t like to take favors from people I don’t know.’ He nodded slowly. ‘I see,’ he said. ‘Well, perhaps another time.’ He stood up. ‘I’m sorry if I’ve bothered you,’ he said. ‘Not at all,’ I said. We went back into the hall. The last guests were leaving. Gatsby stood on the steps, waving good-bye. I went down the drive and turned onto the road. As I walked along, I thought about what Gatsby had said. It was all very strange. I couldn’t understand why he would want to do me a favor. And I didn’t like the idea of taking money from people I didn’t know. It all seemed a little too easy. I decided to forget about it. It was probably just a misunderstanding. I walked on, and soon I was home. I went to bed, but I couldn’t sleep. I kept thinking about Gatsby and his strange offer. I wondered what he was really up to. I decided to keep my distance from him. He seemed like a dangerous man. The next morning, I woke up early. I had a lot of work to do. I went to the office and spent the day working on my bonds. In the evening, I went out to dinner with a friend. We talked about the party at Gatsby’s. My friend had been there, too. He said it was the most amazing party he had ever been to. He said Gatsby was a very mysterious man. I agreed. After dinner, I went home. I was tired, and I went straight to bed. I slept soundly, and when I woke up the next morning, I felt much better. I decided to put Gatsby out of my mind. He was probably just a rich eccentric. I had my own life to live, and I didn’t have time for his strange goings-on. I went to the office and spent the day working. In the evening, I went to a movie. It was a good movie, and I enjoyed it. After the movie, I went home. I was tired, and I went straight to bed. events.title: Chaos After the Party: The Car Crash
detailed_summary: Walking down the steps, Nick realized the night wasn't over.
Headlights illuminated a chaotic scene near the road: a new coupé, just departed from Gatsby's, rested in a ditch, missing a wheel.
A damaged wall explained the detached wheel, which was being examined by curious chauffeurs.
The chauffeurs' parked cars blocked the road, causing a cacophony of horns from waiting vehicles.
A man in a duster (recognized by Nick as the Owl-Eyed man from the library) stood dazedly in the road, looking between the wreck and the onlookers.
He explained, with astonishment, that the car went into the ditch.
When asked how it happened, he shrugged, claiming ignorance of mechanics.
Pressed further about hitting the wall, he deflected responsibility, stating he knew almost nothing about driving and only knew 'it happened'.
Bystanders criticized him for driving poorly at night.
He indignantly protested that he wasn't even trying to drive.
A hush fell as bystanders reacted with disbelief and concern about his recklessness.
He clarified he wasn't the driver; another man was in the car.
The crowd reacted with a collective gasp as the car door opened slowly.
After a pause, a pale, unsteady individual emerged from the wreck.
Blinking in the headlights and confused by the horns, he swayed before noticing the Owl-Eyed man.
He calmly asked if they had run out of gas.
Multiple people pointed out the missing wheel.
He stared at the wheel, then looked up as if it fell from the sky, admitting he hadn't noticed they stopped.
After a moment, he straightened up and asked determinedly for directions to a gas station.
Several men explained the wheel was detached from the car.
He suggested backing the car out.
When reminded the wheel was off, he hesitated, then concluded there was 'no harm in trying'.
As the horns reached a peak, Nick turned away and walked home across the lawn.
He glanced back once at Gatsby's house, still lit under the moon, appearing fine despite the recent chaos.
A sense of emptiness emanated from the house, highlighting the solitary figure of Gatsby on the porch, raising his hand in a formal farewell gesture.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But as I walked down the steps I saw that the evening was not quite over.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A sudden emptiness seemed to flow now from the windows and the great doors, endowing with complete isolation the figure of the host, who stood on the porch, his hand up in a formal gesture of farewell.

events.text_segment:
But as I walked down the steps I saw that the evening was not quite over. Fifty feet from the door a dozen headlights illuminated a bizarre and tumultuous scene. In the ditch beside the road, right side up, but violently shorn of one wheel, rested a new coupé which had left Gatsby’s drive not two minutes before. The sharp jut of a wall accounted for the detachment of the wheel, which was now getting considerable attention from half a dozen curious chauffeurs. However, as they had left their cars blocking the road, a harsh, discordant din from those in the rear had been audible for some time, and added to the already violent confusion of the scene.
A man in a long duster had dismounted from the wreck and now stood in the middle of the road, looking from the car to the tyre and from the tyre to the observers in a pleasant, puzzled way.
“See!” he explained. “It went in the ditch.”
The fact was infinitely astonishing to him, and I recognized first the unusual quality of wonder, and then the man—it was the late patron of Gatsby’s library.
“How’d it happen?”
He shrugged his shoulders.
“I know nothing whatever about mechanics,” he said decisively.
“But how did it happen? Did you run into the wall?”
“Don’t ask me,” said Owl Eyes, washing his hands of the whole matter. “I know very little about driving—next to nothing. It happened, and that’s all I know.”
“Well, if you’re a poor driver you oughtn’t to try driving at night.”
“But I wasn’t even trying,” he explained indignantly, “I wasn’t even trying.”
An awed hush fell upon the bystanders.
“Do you want to commit suicide?”
“You’re lucky it was just a wheel! A bad driver and not even trying!”
“You don’t understand,” explained the criminal. “I wasn’t driving. There’s another man in the car.”
The shock that followed this declaration found voice in a sustained “Ah-h-h!” as the door of the coupé swung slowly open. The crowd—it was now a crowd—stepped back involuntarily, and when the door had opened wide there was a ghostly pause. Then, very gradually, part by part, a pale, dangling individual stepped out of the wreck, pawing tentatively at the ground with a large uncertain dancing shoe.
Blinded by the glare of the headlights and confused by the incessant groaning of the horns, the apparition stood swaying for a moment before he perceived the man in the duster.
“Wha’s matter?” he inquired calmly. “Did we run outa gas?”
“Look!”
Half a dozen fingers pointed at the amputated wheel—he stared at it for a moment, and then looked upward as though he suspected that it had dropped from the sky.
“It came off,” someone explained.
He nodded.
“At first I din’ notice we’d stopped.”
A pause. Then, taking a long breath and straightening his shoulders, he remarked in a determined voice:
“Wonder’ff tell me where there’s a gas’line station?”
At least a dozen men, some of them a little better off than he was, explained to him that wheel and car were no longer joined by any physical bond.
“Back out,” he suggested after a moment. “Put her in reverse.”
“But the wheel’s off!”
He hesitated.
“No harm in trying,” he said.
The caterwauling horns had reached a crescendo and I turned away and cut across the lawn toward home. I glanced back once. A wafer of a moon was shining over Gatsby’s house, making the night fine as before, and surviving the laughter and the sound of his still glowing garden. A sudden emptiness seemed to flow now from the windows and the great doors, endowing with complete isolation the figure of the host, who stood on the porch, his hand up in a formal gesture of farewell.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: But as I walked down the steps I saw that the evening was not quite over. The last stragglers were reluctant to leave Gatsby's enchanted garden. A few couples still danced listlessly on the marble patio, their movements slow and disconnected from the frantic energy that had pulsed through the house hours before. The orchestra, or what remained of it, played a final, mournful tune, the notes drifting like lost souls over the manicured lawn. Cars, long and sleek, lined the drive, their chauffeurs dozing or chatting quietly amongst themselves, waiting for their masters to finally tear themselves away from the magnetic pull of Gatsby's hospitality. Inside, through the open doors, I could see the wreckage of the party. Glasses lay shattered on the floor, spilled drinks stained the Persian rugs, and the air was thick with the smell of alcohol and wilting flowers. Servants, already beginning the monumental task of cleaning, moved silently through the rooms, their faces impassive, accustomed to the weekly chaos. It was a stark contrast to the vibrant, almost desperate gaiety of the party's peak. The illusion was fading, revealing the hollow core beneath the glittering surface. I paused at the bottom of the steps, watching the scene. There was a profound loneliness in the air, a sense of anticlimax that settled heavily after the forced exuberance. People who had laughed and danced together just an hour ago now stood awkwardly apart, their temporary bonds dissolved with the music. They were individuals again, facing the quiet reality of their own lives after escaping into Gatsby's dream for a few hours. Gatsby himself was nowhere to be seen. He usually stood by the door, bidding farewell to his guests with that famous, understanding smile. But tonight, perhaps, the effort had been too great, or perhaps he was already lost in his own thoughts, the dream he was chasing momentarily out of reach. I wondered if he felt the same emptiness I did, or if his focus remained solely on the green light across the bay, the symbol of his unattainable desire. The moon hung high and indifferent in the sky, casting long shadows that distorted the familiar landscape. The sound of distant laughter, a final burst from a departing car, echoed briefly and died away. The house, so full of life and noise moments before, began to settle into a vast, silent monument to a man's singular obsession. It was a palace built on a foundation of hope and illusion, and in the quiet aftermath, its artificiality felt palpable. I thought of the stories I had heard about Gatsby, the rumors that swirled around him like the smoke from the discarded cigarettes on his lawn. Was he a German spy? A murderer? A bootlegger? The truth, I suspected, was both simpler and more complex than any of the gossip. He was a man who had built an entire world around a single idea, a single person, and the sheer scale of his effort was both admirable and terrifying. As I walked towards the gate, the cool night air clearing my head, I felt a sense of detachment. I was an observer in this world, a temporary resident in the land of the rich and careless. Their lives, with their extravagant parties, their complicated affairs, and their underlying unhappiness, seemed both fascinating and ultimately meaningless. They were like characters in a play, performing their roles with great energy but little genuine emotion. The road outside Gatsby's estate was quiet, a stark contrast to the bustling activity within. The real world, mundane and predictable, waited just beyond the gates. But the image of the house, standing alone and slightly forlorn in the moonlight, lingered in my mind. It was a symbol of Gatsby himself – grand, mysterious, and ultimately isolated by his own creation. I considered the people I had met that night. The superficial charm, the casual cruelty, the desperate search for excitement. They were drawn to Gatsby's light like moths, seeking warmth and brilliance, but perhaps unaware of the fire that fueled it. And Gatsby, in turn, used them as props in his elaborate production, hoping to lure the one audience member who mattered. The air grew cooler as I walked, the sounds of the party fading behind me. The night was deep and silent now, broken only by the chirping of crickets and the distant hum of traffic on the highway. I was leaving the dream world and returning to reality, but the echoes of the evening stayed with me. The image of Daisy's face, the sound of Gatsby's voice, the unsettling feeling that something significant, perhaps something tragic, was unfolding beneath the surface of this glittering society. It was a world of immense privilege and profound emptiness, a place where money could buy anything but happiness, and where dreams were pursued with a relentless, almost frightening intensity. Gatsby's party was over, but the story, I knew, was far from finished. The seeds of future events had been sown in the champagne and the laughter, and the harvest, I suspected, would be bitter. The night had revealed more than just the end of a party; it had offered a glimpse into the heart of an era, a society teetering on the edge of something unknown, driven by desires they barely understood. The silence outside the gates felt heavy with anticipation, as if the very air was waiting for the next act to begin. The grand illusion had momentarily lifted, leaving behind a sense of unease and the lingering question of what lay ahead for Gatsby and the people who orbited his strange, compelling world. The steps I had descended led not just out of a house, but out of a moment of manufactured joy and into the quiet, uncertain reality that always waited beyond the gates of West Egg.

Fifty feet from the door a new coupé, fated to the ditch it was in, had come to rest on the grass, literally smashed beyond repair, with one wheel detached and lying beside it. The other cars, hyacinths and stars, went about it with short, angry jerks, their headlights gleam- ing in a row across the lawn, where many women were standing, nervously laughing. Presently a dozen men emerged from the crowd, pushing and pulling one another with hoarse cries as they struggled to arrange it in the ditch.

'Won't you help to push it out?' called a young man to the Owl-eyed man in the duster.

'Certainly not,' stammered the Owl-eyed man, looking home at the circuit. 'I was standing beside him and I saw the wheel paint itself black against the fence, and then he drove on three miles.'

events.title: Nick Reflects on Summer, New York, and Jordan's Dishonesty
detailed_summary: Reviewing his writing, Nick feels he might have overemphasized the significance of a few nights' events.
He clarifies they were just casual occurrences in a busy summer and, until later, less important than his personal affairs.
Nick describes his routine: working at Probity Trust in downtown New York.
He socialized casually with colleagues, having lunch at simple restaurants.
He had a brief relationship with a coworker from Jersey City, which ended passively when her brother showed disapproval and she went on vacation.
He usually dined alone at the Yale Club, finding it the day's gloomiest part, followed by studying investments in the library.
He enjoyed strolling through New York at night, liking its adventurous atmosphere and the constant motion of people and machines.
He fantasized about meeting romantic women on Fifth Avenue and entering their lives unnoticed.
Sometimes he felt a profound loneliness in the city twilight, recognizing it in other young clerks like himself.
The sight of taxis heading to the theatre district filled him with a sense of longing, imagining the shared excitement within.
He reconnected with Jordan Baker in midsummer.

Nick concludes by asserting his own cardinal virtue: honesty, claiming to be one of the few honest people he knows.

events.text_segment:
Reading over what I have written so far, I see I have given the impression that the events of three nights several weeks apart were all that absorbed me. On the contrary, they were merely casual events in a crowded summer, and, until much later, they absorbed me infinitely less than my personal affairs.
Most of the time I worked. In the early morning the sun threw my shadow westward as I hurried down the white chasms of lower New York to the Probity Trust. I knew the other clerks and young bond-salesmen by their first names, and lunched with them in dark, crowded restaurants on little pig sausages and mashed potatoes and coffee. I even had a short affair with a girl who lived in Jersey City and worked in the accounting department, but her brother began throwing mean looks in my direction, so when she went on her vacation in July I let it blow quietly away.
I took dinner usually at the Yale Club—for some reason it was the gloomiest event of my day—and then I went upstairs to the library and studied investments and securities for a conscientious hour. There were generally a few rioters around, but they never came into the library, so it was a good place to work. After that, if the night was mellow, I strolled down Madison Avenue past the old Murray Hill Hotel, and over 33rd Street to the Pennsylvania Station.
I began to like New York, the racy, adventurous feel of it at night, and the satisfaction that the constant flicker of men and women and machines gives to the restless eye. I liked to walk up Fifth Avenue and pick out romantic women from the crowd and imagine that in a few minutes I was going to enter into their lives, and no one would ever know or disapprove. Sometimes, in my mind, I followed them to their apartments on the corners of hidden streets, and they turned and smiled back at me before they faded through a door into warm darkness. At the enchanted metropolitan twilight I felt a haunting loneliness sometimes, and felt it in others—poor young clerks who loitered in front of windows waiting until it was time for a solitary restaurant dinner—young clerks in the dusk, wasting the most poignant moments of night and life.
Again at eight o’clock, when the dark lanes of the Forties were lined five deep with throbbing taxicabs, bound for the theatre district, I felt a sinking in my heart. Forms leaned together in the taxis as they waited, and voices sang, and there was laughter from unheard jokes, and lighted cigarettes made unintelligible circles inside. Imagining that I, too, was hurrying towards gaiety and sharing their intimate excitement, I wished them well.
For a while I lost sight of Jordan Baker, and then in midsummer I found her again. At first I was flattered to go places with her, because she was a golf champion, and everyone knew her name. Then it was something more. I wasn’t actually in love, but I felt a sort of tender curiosity. The bored haughty face that she turned to the world concealed something—most affectations conceal something eventually, even though they don’t in the beginning—and one day I found what it was. When we were on a house-party together up in Warwick, she left a borrowed car out in the rain with the top down, and then lied about it—and suddenly I remembered the story about her that had eluded me that night at Daisy’s. At her first big golf tournament there was a row that nearly reached the newspapers—a suggestion that she had moved her ball from a bad lie in the semifinal round. The thing approached the proportions of a scandal—then died away. A caddy retracted his statement, and the only other witness admitted that he might have been mistaken. The incident and the name had remained together in my mind.
Jordan Baker instinctively avoided clever, shrewd men, and now I saw that this was because she felt safer on a plane where any divergence from a code would be thought impossible. She was incurably dishonest. She wasn’t able to endure being at a disadvantage and, given this unwillingness, I suppose she had begun dealing in subterfuges when she was very young in order to keep that cool, insolent smile turned to the world and yet satisfy the demands of her hard, jaunty body.
It made no difference to me. Dishonesty in a woman is a thing you never blame deeply—I was casually sorry, and then I forgot. It was on that same house-party that we had a curious conversation about driving a car. It started because she passed so close to some workmen that our fender flicked a button on one man’s coat.
“You’re a rotten driver,” I protested. “Either you ought to be more careful, or you oughtn’t to drive at all.”
“I am careful.”
“No, you’re not.”
“Well, other people are,” she said lightly.
“What’s that got to do with it?”
“They’ll keep out of my way,” she insisted. “It takes two to make an accident.”
“Suppose you met somebody just as careless as yourself.”
“I hope I never will,” she answered. “I hate careless people. That’s why I like you.”
Her grey, sun-strained eyes stared straight ahead, but she had deliberately shifted our relations, and for a moment I thought I loved her. But I am slow-thinking and full of interior rules that act as brakes on my desires, and I knew that first I had to get myself definitely out of that tangle back home. I’d been writing letters once a week and signing them: “Love, Nick,” and all I could think of was how, when that certain girl played tennis, a faint moustache of perspiration appeared on her upper lip. Nevertheless there was a vague understanding that had to be tactfully broken off before I was free.
Everyone suspects himself of at least one of the cardinal virtues, and this is mine: I am one of the few honest people that I have ever known.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Reading over what I have written so far, I see I have given the impression that the events of three nights several weeks apart were all that absorbed me. On the contrary, they were merely casual events in a crowded summer, and, until much later, ever less important in my eyes than the ponderous intrigues at the office. I worked at Probity Trust in Wall Street, and spent five days a week at work, relieving all the obligations of two weeks’ stay in the country with my own hands. I was thirty. Before I came down here, I had regarded it as a prolongation of the war, that had postponed the grudges of those who had stayed at home, and at the same time gathered the dissatisfied together. I was so excited that when I got into a taxi with a girl for the first time I thought nothing at all of our going to a place from which I was to be taken home in a police patrol. Abstracted from my work as I was, I was lonely, and felt a certain shame for not being more successful. I spent my Saturday nights in New York because I knew lots of young men and women living there who were lonely too and who were eager to be with anyone. I went to several parties, but they were not like the party I have just described. They were more intimate, and I liked them better. I liked to walk up Fifth Avenue and pick out romantic women from the crowd and imagine that in a few minutes I was going to enter their lives, and no one would ever know or disapprove. Sometimes, in my mind, I followed them to their apartments on the corners of hidden streets, and they turned and smiled back at me before they faded through a door into an apartment house. I spent my Saturday nights in New York because I knew lots of young men and women living there who were lonely too and who were eager to be with anyone. I went to several parties, but they were not like the party I have just described. They were more intimate, and I liked them better. I liked to walk up Fifth Avenue and pick out romantic women from the crowd and imagine that in a few minutes I was going to enter their lives, and no one would ever know or disapprove. Sometimes, in my mind, I followed them to their apartments on the corners of hidden streets, and they turned and smiled back at me before they faded through a door into an apartment house. It was a city of loneliness, and I was lonely. I was thirty. Before I came down here, I had regarded it as a prolongation of the war, that had postponed the grudges of those who had stayed at home, and at the same time gathered the dissatisfied together. events.title: Cataloging Gatsby's Guests and Their Ignorance
characters: Various unnamed guests (mentioned by name in text)
detailed_summary: On Sundays, Gatsby's house refills with guests indulging in his luxurious offerings.
Guests circulate wild and uninformed rumors about their host, speculating he's a bootlegger or even a murderer related to German royalty and the devil.
Nick recalls documenting the names of summer party attendees on an old timetable.
He feels this list offers a more concrete picture of the attendees than simple generalizations.
The core observation is that these guests readily accepted Gatsby's hospitality while knowing virtually nothing about him.

Nick provides a detailed list of guests from East Egg, including families like the Chester Beckers, Leeches, Hornbeams, Willie Voltaires, and Blackbucks, along with individuals like Bunsen, Doctor Civet, the Ismays, Chrysties, Edgar Beaver, and Clarence Endive, sometimes noting their quirks or fates.

He continues with guests from farther on Long Island: the Cheadles, O. R. P. Schraeders, Stonewall Jackson Abrams, Fishguards, Ripley Snells (involved in an incident leading to jail), the Dancies, S. B. Whitebait, Maurice A. Flink, the Hammerheads, and Beluga the tobacco importer with his daughters.

Guests from West Egg are enumerated, many associated with the film industry: the Poles, Mulreadys, Cecil Roebuck, Cecil Schoen, Senator Gulick, Newton Orchid, Eckhaust, Clyde Cohen, Don S. Schwartz, Arthur McCarty, Catlips, Bembergs, and G. Earl Muldoon (whose brother committed murder).
Promoters and gamblers like Da Fontano, Ed Legros, James B. (“Rot-Gut”) Ferret, the De Jongs, and Ernest Lilly are listed; Ferret's presence in the garden signaled gambling losses.
A constant presence, Klipspringer, earned the nickname "the boarder."
Theatrical attendees included Gus Waize, Horace O’Donavan, Lester Myer, George Duckweed, and Francis Bull.

A lengthy list of New York guests follows: the Chromes, Backhyssons, Dennickers, Russel Betty, Corrigans, Kellehers, Dewars, Scullys, S. W. Belcher, Smirkes, the divorced Quinns, and Henry L. Palmetto (who died by suicide).
Benny McClenahan consistently arrived with four young women who, despite changing individuals, seemed identical and claimed dubious connections to wealthy families.

Nick adds more names from memory: Faustina O’Brien, the Baedeker girls, young Brewer (injured in the war), Mr. Albrucksburger and his fiancée Miss Haag, Ardita Fitz-Peters, Mr. P. Jewett, Miss Claudia Hip (with her supposed chauffeur), and an unnamed prince known as Duke.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: On Sunday morning while church bells rang in the villages alongshore, the world and its mistress returned to Gatsby’s house and twinkled hilariously on his lawn.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: All these people came to Gatsby’s house in the summer.

events.text_segment:
On Sunday morning while church bells rang in the villages alongshore, the world and its mistress returned to Gatsby’s house and twinkled hilariously on his lawn.
“He’s a bootlegger,” said the young ladies, moving somewhere between his cocktails and his flowers. “One time he killed a man who had found out that he was nephew to Von Hindenburg and second cousin to the devil. Reach me a rose, honey, and pour me a last drop into that there crystal glass.”
Once I wrote down on the empty spaces of a timetable the names of those who came to Gatsby’s house that summer. It is an old timetable now, disintegrating at its folds, and headed “This schedule in effect July 5th, 1922.” But I can still read the grey names, and they will give you a better impression than my generalities of those who accepted Gatsby’s hospitality and paid him the subtle tribute of knowing nothing whatever about him.
From East Egg, then, came the Chester Beckers and the Leeches, and a man named Bunsen, whom I knew at Yale, and Doctor Webster Civet, who was drowned last summer up in Maine. And the Hornbeams and the Willie Voltaires, and a whole clan named Blackbuck, who always gathered in a corner and flipped up their noses like goats at whosoever came near. And the Ismays and the Chrysties (or rather Hubert Auerbach and Mr. Chrystie’s wife), and Edgar Beaver, whose hair, they say, turned cotton-white one winter afternoon for no good reason at all.
Clarence Endive was from East Egg, as I remember. He came only once, in white knickerbockers, and had a fight with a bum named Etty in the garden. From farther out on the Island came the Cheadles and the O. R. P. Schraeders, and the Stonewall Jackson Abrams of Georgia, and the Fishguards and the Ripley Snells. Snell was there three days before he went to the penitentiary, so drunk out on the gravel drive that Mrs. Ulysses Swett’s automobile ran over his right hand. The Dancies came, too, and S. B. Whitebait, who was well over sixty, and Maurice A. Flink, and the Hammerheads, and Beluga the tobacco importer, and Beluga’s girls.
From West Egg came the Poles and the Mulreadys and Cecil Roebuck and Cecil Schoen and Gulick the State senator and Newton Orchid, who controlled Films Par Excellence, and Eckhaust and Clyde Cohen and Don S. Schwartz (the son) and Arthur McCarty, all connected with the movies in one way or another. And the Catlips and the Bembergs and G. Earl Muldoon, brother to that Muldoon who afterward strangled his wife. Da Fontano the promoter came there, and Ed Legros and James B. (“Rot-Gut”) Ferret and the De Jongs and Ernest Lilly—they came to gamble, and when Ferret wandered into the garden it meant he was cleaned out and Associated Traction would have to fluctuate profitably next day.
A man named Klipspringer was there so often that he became known as “the boarder”—I doubt if he had any other home. Of theatrical people there were Gus Waize and Horace O’Donavan and Lester Myer and George Duckweed and Francis Bull. Also from New York were the Chromes and the Backhyssons and the Dennickers and Russel Betty and the Corrigans and the Kellehers and the Dewars and the Scullys and S. W. Belcher and the Smirkes and the young Quinns, divorced now, and Henry L. Palmetto, who killed himself by jumping in front of a subway train in Times Square.
Benny McClenahan arrived always with four girls. They were never quite the same ones in physical person, but they were so identical one with another that it inevitably seemed they had been there before. I have forgotten their names—Jaqueline, I think, or else Consuela, or Gloria or Judy or June, and their last names were either the melodious names of flowers and months or the sterner ones of the great American capitalists whose cousins, if pressed, they would confess themselves to be.
In addition to all these I can remember that Faustina O’Brien came there at least once and the Baedeker girls and young Brewer, who had his nose shot off in the war, and Mr. Albrucksburger and Miss Haag, his fiancée, and Ardita Fitz-Peters and Mr. P. Jewett, once head of the American Legion, and Miss Claudia Hip, with a man reputed to be her chauffeur, and a prince of something, whom we called Duke, and whose name, if I ever knew it, I have forgotten.
All these people came to Gatsby’s house in the summer.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: On Sunday morning while church bells rang in the villages alongshore, the world and its mistress returned to Gatsby’s house and twinkled hilariously on his lawn. The cars, which had been parked five deep in the drive and along the road, were fewer now, but a substantial number remained, gleaming dully in the morning sun. The air, still thick with the scent of crushed mint and spilled liquor from the night before, hummed with a low, persistent murmur of voices and laughter. On the lawn, where the grass was trampled and littered with discarded glasses and crumpled napkins, groups of people lounged in deck chairs or sprawled on blankets. Some, still in evening clothes, looked disheveled and weary, their gaiety now a forced, brittle thing. Others, having changed into bathing suits, splashed noisily in the pool, their shouts echoing across the manicured grounds. Inside the house, the scene was one of opulent disarray. The ballroom, where the orchestra had played until dawn, was empty save for a few stragglers slumped in chairs, nursing drinks. The library, usually a quiet sanctuary, was filled with the chatter of those who had discovered its existence the night before and now felt entitled to occupy it. The dining room table was still laden with the remnants of the feast – platters of cold cuts, half-eaten pastries, bottles of champagne, some still corked, others empty. Servants moved quietly through the rooms, their faces impassive, beginning the monumental task of restoring order. I walked through the grounds, feeling like an anthropologist observing a strange, exotic tribe. These people, drawn from the fringes of the fashionable world, from the arts, from finance, from nowhere in particular, seemed to exist only in the context of Gatsby’s parties. They arrived, consumed his hospitality with a voracious appetite, and then, like moths after the light is extinguished, dispersed, leaving behind only the detritus of their pleasure. They knew Gatsby only vaguely, if at all, and he, I suspected, knew them even less. They were simply the necessary backdrop, the vibrant, shifting scenery against which his own drama was played out. There was a curious lack of intimacy about it all. Despite the proximity, the shared space, the forced jollity, everyone seemed profoundly alone. Conversations were superficial, punctuated by bursts of loud, meaningless laughter. Relationships seemed transient, formed and dissolved within the span of a single evening. It was a world built on illusion, on the fleeting moment, on the desperate pursuit of a good time that always seemed just out of reach. I saw women with tired eyes and smudged makeup, their expensive dresses looking crumpled and sad in the harsh morning light. I saw men with flushed faces and loosened ties, their bravado of the night before replaced by a quiet exhaustion. They were all waiting, I realized, waiting for something – for the party to truly end, for the hangover to subside, for the return to their own less spectacular lives, or perhaps, for the next invitation to arrive. Gatsby himself was nowhere to be seen. He rarely was during these post-party hours. He was the orchestrator, the host, the mysterious figure whose presence was felt everywhere but whose person was seldom encountered amidst the throng. He remained, even in his own house, an enigma, a figure of speculation and rumour. His absence on these mornings only added to the mystique, allowing the guests to project their own fantasies onto him. The contrast with the quiet, church-going world just beyond the hedges was stark. Here, there was no reverence, no reflection, only the continued, albeit subdued, pursuit of sensation. It was a world without consequences, or so it seemed. The rules that governed ordinary life did not apply here. Time itself seemed to operate differently, stretching and distorting to accommodate the endless cycle of revelry and recovery. I sat by the pool for a while, watching the swimmers. They were young, mostly, their bodies tanned and athletic. They laughed and splashed, seemingly oblivious to the wreckage around them. They were the embodiment of the carefree, privileged youth that Gatsby seemed to court. They represented a certain kind of freedom, a freedom from responsibility, from worry, from the constraints of ordinary morality. But even their laughter seemed to have a hollow ring to it, a desperate edge that belied their apparent happiness. It struck me then how much energy was expended in this relentless pursuit of pleasure. The sheer effort involved in maintaining this level of artificial gaiety, in keeping the party going, in pretending that this was the most important thing in the world. It was a performance, a grand, elaborate show, and everyone was both actor and audience. As the morning wore on, the crowd gradually thinned. Cars pulled away, their occupants heading back to the city or to other points on the island. The servants continued their work, clearing away the debris, restoring the house to its immaculate state, preparing it for the next invasion. By late afternoon, the lawn was empty, the pool quiet, the house silent once more. Only the lingering scent of alcohol and the trampled grass remained as evidence of the weekend's festivities. The world and its mistress had departed, leaving Gatsby alone in his magnificent, empty house, presumably waiting for the next Saturday night. The cycle would begin again, the same faces, the same laughter, the same desperate, glittering pursuit of something indefinable. And I, the observer from the sidelines, would watch it all unfold, fascinated and repelled in equal measure.

```text
On Sunday morning while church bells rang in the villages alongshore, the world and its mistress returned to Gatsby’s house and twinkled hilariously on his lawn.

“It was like the aftermath of a picnic when the garbage remains,” remarked somebody from East Egg. “It’s hard to get rid of.”

I was on my way to get my hat when I’d met him, and the hydroplane taxi made the same trip six times a day, taking a crowd of ten people from West Egg to the city and back, for all the city had to offer—in the way of sensation or entertainment.

The most of these people came in contact with Gatsby for the first time at a party of very casual acquaintances, and after that they accepted his hospitality at the house party and, without so much as a word of thanks, they went away.

Some of them came several times, others came once and never came again. They came and went like moths among the whisperings and the champagne and the stars.

At high tide in the afternoon I’d met a young man from the city, who had been there for a week and didn’t know Gatsby.

“I’m staying at the house,” he explained. “I’m Klipspringer.”

He was a constant patron, and by the time he had been there a week he was known as “the boarder.”

I had been there two weeks and I hadn’t seen Gatsby. I was on my way to get my hat when I’d met him, and the hydroplane taxi made the same trip six times a day, taking a crowd of ten people from West Egg to the city and back, for all the city had to offer—in the way of sensation or entertainment.

There was a story that he had killed a man.

There was a story that he was a German spy during the war.

There was a story that he was a bootlegger.

There was a story that he was a nephew of Von Hindenburg and second cousin to the devil.

I was on my way to get my hat when I’d met him, and the hydroplane taxi made the same trip six times a day, taking a crowd of ten people from West Egg to the city and back, for all the city had to offer—in the way of sensation or entertainment.

events.title: Gatsby's Invitation and Dubious Autobiography
detailed_summary: Late one July morning, Gatsby arrives unexpectedly at Nick's home in his striking car.
It's Gatsby's first visit to Nick, despite Nick attending his parties and using his amenities.
Gatsby invites Nick to lunch, proposing they travel to the city together.
Nick observes Gatsby's characteristic American restlessness beneath his formal demeanor, noting his constant fidgeting.
Gatsby notices Nick admiring his car and proudly encourages a closer look.
Nick describes the car's opulent appearance: cream-colored, nickel-adorned, monstrously long, and filled with compartments and mirrored windshields.
They set off for town, enclosed in the car's green leather interior.
Nick reflects on his disappointment from previous conversations, finding Gatsby had little to say, which had downgraded Nick's initial perception of him.
The car ride becomes uncomfortable as Gatsby grows agitated, leaving sentences unfinished and nervously tapping his knee.
Gatsby abruptly asks Nick's opinion of him.
Nick starts to offer a polite evasion, but Gatsby interrupts, wanting to share his life story to counteract rumors.
Gatsby asserts he will tell the "God's truth."
He claims descent from wealthy, deceased Midwestern parents and an Oxford education, citing it as a long-standing family tradition.
Nick perceives Gatsby's discomfort when mentioning Oxford, fueling Jordan Baker's earlier expressed doubt and making Nick question Gatsby's entire narrative, sensing something possibly sinister.
When asked about his Midwestern origins, Gatsby claims San Francisco.
He solemnly recounts inheriting substantial wealth after his family's demise.
Gatsby describes living like a young rajah across Europe (Paris, Venice, Rome), collecting jewels (especially rubies), hunting, painting privately, and trying to escape a past sorrow.
Nick finds the story incredibly clichéd, comparing it to a stereotypical fictional character, and struggles not to laugh.
Gatsby transitions to his war experience, portraying it as a relief where he courted death but seemed charmed.

He details his commission, leading a machine-gun battalion far ahead in the Argonne Forest, holding the position for two days against odds, and earning a promotion to Major and decorations from multiple Allied nations, including Montenegro.
Gatsby speaks fondly of Montenegro, displaying a smile that seems to encompass its history and struggles.
Nick's disbelief shifts towards fascination.
Gatsby produces a medal from Montenegro as evidence.
Nick examines the medal, noting its authentic appearance and inscription: "Orderi di Danilo, Montenegro, Nicolas Rex," and on the reverse, "Major Jay Gatsby, For Valour Extraordinary."
Gatsby then presents a photograph from his Oxford days at Trinity Quad, showing himself younger with several young men, one identified as the Earl of Doncaster.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At nine o’clock, one morning late in July, Gatsby’s gorgeous car lurched up the rocky drive to my door and gave out a burst of melody from its three-noted horn.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There was Gatsby, looking a little, not much, younger—with a cricket bat in his hand.

events.text_segment:
At nine o’clock, one morning late in July, Gatsby’s gorgeous car lurched up the rocky drive to my door and gave out a burst of melody from its three-noted horn.
It was the first time he had called on me, though I had gone to two of his parties, mounted in his hydroplane, and, at his urgent invitation, made frequent use of his beach.
“Good morning, old sport. You’re having lunch with me today and I thought we’d ride up together.”
He was balancing himself on the dashboard of his car with that resourcefulness of movement that is so peculiarly American—that comes, I suppose, with the absence of lifting work in youth and, even more, with the formless grace of our nervous, sporadic games. This quality was continually breaking through his punctilious manner in the shape of restlessness. He was never quite still; there was always a tapping foot somewhere or the impatient opening and closing of a hand.
He saw me looking with admiration at his car.
“It’s pretty, isn’t it, old sport?” He jumped off to give me a better view. “Haven’t you ever seen it before?”
I’d seen it. Everybody had seen it. It was a rich cream colour, bright with nickel, swollen here and there in its monstrous length with triumphant hatboxes and supper-boxes and toolboxes, and terraced with a labyrinth of windshields that mirrored a dozen suns. Sitting down behind many layers of glass in a sort of green leather conservatory, we started to town.
I had talked with him perhaps half a dozen times in the past month and found, to my disappointment, that he had little to say. So my first impression, that he was a person of some undefined consequence, had gradually faded and he had become simply the proprietor of an elaborate roadhouse next door.
And then came that disconcerting ride. We hadn’t reached West Egg village before Gatsby began leaving his elegant sentences unfinished and slapping himself indecisively on the knee of his caramel-coloured suit.
“Look here, old sport,” he broke out surprisingly, “what’s your opinion of me, anyhow?”
A little overwhelmed, I began the generalized evasions which that question deserves.
“Well, I’m going to tell you something about my life,” he interrupted. “I don’t want you to get a wrong idea of me from all these stories you hear.”
So he was aware of the bizarre accusations that flavoured conversation in his halls.
“I’ll tell you God’s truth.” His right hand suddenly ordered divine retribution to stand by. “I am the son of some wealthy people in the Middle West—all dead now. I was brought up in America but educated at Oxford, because all my ancestors have been educated there for many years. It is a family tradition.”
He looked at me sideways—and I knew why Jordan Baker had believed he was lying. He hurried the phrase “educated at Oxford,” or swallowed it, or choked on it, as though it had bothered him before. And with this doubt, his whole statement fell to pieces, and I wondered if there wasn’t something a little sinister about him, after all.
“What part of the Middle West?” I inquired casually.
“San Francisco.”
“I see.”
“My family all died and I came into a good deal of money.”
His voice was solemn, as if the memory of that sudden extinction of a clan still haunted him. For a moment I suspected that he was pulling my leg, but a glance at him convinced me otherwise.
“After that I lived like a young rajah in all the capitals of Europe—Paris, Venice, Rome—collecting jewels, chiefly rubies, hunting big game, painting a little, things for myself only, and trying to forget something very sad that had happened to me long ago.”
With an effort I managed to restrain my incredulous laughter. The very phrases were worn so threadbare that they evoked no image except that of a turbaned “character” leaking sawdust at every pore as he pursued a tiger through the Bois de Boulogne.
“Then came the war, old sport. It was a great relief, and I tried very hard to die, but I seemed to bear an enchanted life. I accepted a commission as first lieutenant when it began. In the Argonne Forest I took the remains of my machine-gun battalion so far forward that there was a half mile gap on either side of us where the infantry couldn’t advance. We stayed there two days and two nights, a hundred and thirty men with sixteen Lewis guns, and when the infantry came up at last they found the insignia of three German divisions among the piles of dead. I was promoted to be a major, and every Allied government gave me a decoration—even Montenegro, little Montenegro down on the Adriatic Sea!”
Little Montenegro! He lifted up the words and nodded at them—with his smile. The smile comprehended Montenegro’s troubled history and sympathized with the brave struggles of the Montenegrin people. It appreciated fully the chain of national circumstances which had elicited this tribute from Montenegro’s warm little heart. My incredulity was submerged in fascination now; it was like skimming hastily through a dozen magazines.
He reached in his pocket, and a piece of metal, slung on a ribbon, fell into my palm.
“That’s the one from Montenegro.”
To my astonishment, the thing had an authentic look. “Orderi di Danilo,” ran the circular legend, “Montenegro, Nicolas Rex.”
“Turn it.”
“Major Jay Gatsby,” I read, “For Valour Extraordinary.”
“Here’s another thing I always carry. A souvenir of Oxford days. It was taken in Trinity Quad—the man on my left is now the Earl of Doncaster.”
It was a photograph of half a dozen young men in blazers loafing in an archway through which were visible a host of spires. There was Gatsby, looking a little, not much, younger—with a cricket bat in his hand.

At nine o’clock, one morning late in July, Gatsby’s gorgeous car lurched up the rocky drive to my door and gave out a burst of melody from its three-noted horn. It was the first time he had been over this year, though I’d been over there not a few times. I came down the steps in a hurry, carrying an armful of flowers, and met him at the foot of the steps.
“Good morning, old sport. You’re having lunch with me to-day and I thought we’d go into town.”
There was something gorgeous about him, some heightened sensitivity to the promises of life, as if he were related to one of those intricate machines that register earthquakes ten thousand miles away. His speaking voice, a low, husky murmur, added to the impression of fractiousness he conveyed. There was always a hint of scarcely suppressed excitement in his voice, a constant flicker of interminable rivalry. He was never quite still; there was always a tapping foot somewhere or the impatient opening and closing of a hand.
He saw me looking with admiration at his car.
“It’s pretty, isn’t it, old sport?” He jumped off to give me a better view. “Haven’t you ever seen it before?”
I’d seen it. Everybody had seen it. It was a rich cream-colored, bright with nickel, swollen here and there in its monstrous length with triumphant hat-boxes and supper-boxes and tool-boxes, and terraced with a labyrinth of wind-shields that mirrored a dozen suns. Sitting down behind many layers of glass in a sort of green leather conservatory, we started to town.

events.title: Gatsby's Mysterious Request and Journey to New York
detailed_summary: Temporarily swayed by the presented evidence (medal, photo), Nick visualizes Gatsby's romantic tales as potentially real.
Gatsby reveals the reason for sharing his past: he intends to ask Nick for a significant favor that day.
He explains his drifting lifestyle aims to forget past sadness and emphasizes wanting Nick to understand he isn't just 'some nobody'.
Gatsby states the details of the request will be conveyed by Jordan Baker when she meets Nick for tea later.
Nick feels more annoyed than intrigued by the secrecy and indirectness, briefly wishing he hadn't gotten involved with Gatsby.
Gatsby remains tight-lipped about the matter, adopting a more formal, correct demeanor as they approach New York City.
Their journey takes them past Port Roosevelt's ships, through a run-down area with old saloons, and across the desolate valley of ashes.
Nick catches a glimpse of Mrs. Wilson working vigorously at the garage pump as they speed past.
While driving rapidly through Astoria, a motorcycle policeman pulls them over.
Gatsby calmly displays a white card from his wallet to the officer.
The policeman immediately recognizes Gatsby, apologizes, tips his cap, and lets them proceed.
Gatsby explains the card is a courtesy from the police commissioner, whom he once assisted, and who sends him an annual Christmas card.
As they cross the Queensboro Bridge, Nick is captivated by the stunning view of the city skyline, seeing it as a symbol of endless possibility, mystery, and beauty.
The drive includes observations of city life: a funeral procession and a limousine carrying stylish black passengers driven by a white chauffeur.
These sights reinforce Nick's feeling that arriving in the city makes anything seem possible, including the existence of someone like Gatsby.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then it was all true.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Even Gatsby could happen, without any particular wonder.

events.text_segment:
Then it was all true. I saw the skins of tigers flaming in his palace on the Grand Canal; I saw him opening a chest of rubies to ease, with their crimson-lighted depths, the gnawings of his broken heart.
“I’m going to make a big request of you today,” he said, pocketing his souvenirs with satisfaction, “so I thought you ought to know something about me. I didn’t want you to think I was just some nobody. You see, I usually find myself among strangers because I drift here and there trying to forget the sad things that happened to me.” He hesitated. “You’ll hear about it this afternoon.”
“At lunch?”
“No, this afternoon. I happened to find out that you’re taking Miss Baker to tea.”
“Do you mean you’re in love with Miss Baker?”
“No, old sport, I’m not. But Miss Baker has kindly consented to speak to you about this matter.”
I hadn’t the faintest idea what “this matter” was, but I was more annoyed than interested. I hadn’t asked Jordan to tea in order to discuss Mr. Jay Gatsby. I was sure the request would be something utterly fantastic, and for a moment I was sorry I’d ever set foot upon his overpopulated lawn.
He wouldn’t say another word. His correctness grew on him as we neared the city. We passed Port Roosevelt, where there was a glimpse of red-belted oceangoing ships, and sped along a cobbled slum lined with the dark, undeserted saloons of the faded-gilt nineteen-hundreds. Then the valley of ashes opened out on both sides of us, and I had a glimpse of Mrs. Wilson straining at the garage pump with panting vitality as we went by.
With fenders spread like wings we scattered light through half Astoria—only half, for as we twisted among the pillars of the elevated I heard the familiar “jug-jug-spat!” of a motorcycle, and a frantic policeman rode alongside.
“All right, old sport,” called Gatsby. We slowed down. Taking a white card from his wallet, he waved it before the man’s eyes.
“Right you are,” agreed the policeman, tipping his cap. “Know you next time, Mr. Gatsby. Excuse me!”
“What was that?” I inquired. “The picture of Oxford?”
“I was able to do the commissioner a favour once, and he sends me a Christmas card every year.”
Over the great bridge, with the sunlight through the girders making a constant flicker upon the moving cars, with the city rising up across the river in white heaps and sugar lumps all built with a wish out of nonolfactory money. The city seen from the Queensboro Bridge is always the city seen for the first time, in its first wild promise of all the mystery and the beauty in the world.
A dead man passed us in a hearse heaped with blooms, followed by two carriages with drawn blinds, and by more cheerful carriages for friends. The friends looked out at us with the tragic eyes and short upper lips of southeastern Europe, and I was glad that the sight of Gatsby’s splendid car was included in their sombre holiday. As we crossed Blackwell’s Island a limousine passed us, driven by a white chauffeur, in which sat three modish negroes, two bucks and a girl. I laughed aloud as the yolks of their eyeballs rolled toward us in haughty rivalry.
“Anything can happen now that we’ve slid over this bridge,” I thought; “anything at all…”
Even Gatsby could happen, without any particular wonder.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Then it was all true. I saw the skins of tigers flaming in his palace on the Grand Canal; I saw him opening a chest of rubies to ease, with their crimson light, the distress of all the poor he had met. With an effort I managed to restrain my incredulous laughter. The thing approached the proportions of standing alone on the last barrier of civilization. “I didn’t like to hear a personal remark,” Gatsby explained. “A man like me must be careful.” There was a pause. “And my parents are dead,” he announced matter-of-factly. “Of course I was brought up in America, but educated at Oxford, because all my ancestors have been educated there for many years. It is a family tradition.” He looked at me sideways—and I knew why Jordan Baker had believed he was lying. He hurried the phrase “educated at Oxford,” or swallowed it, or choked on it, as though it had taken him years to get it right. He was silent for a moment. The idea of Gatsby, big swell, Gatsby who could afford to forget about the past, was in effect extinguished by this statement. I waited, and sure enough, in a moment he looked at me with more attention. “I am going to make a big request of you to-day,” he said, immediately and without caution. “I want you and Jordan to come over to my house this afternoon.” The modesty of the demand shook me. He offered me the money he had made at the drug-stores. He never knew how near he came to giving me a dead rattle. “I beg your pardon,” said I. “Did you request my presence alone?” “No, he wants to know if you’ll invite Daisy to tea,” said the Jordan Baker suddenly from the back seat. “Of course I will. What time?” “He wants it to be in the afternoon,” explained Jordan, “so she can see his house.” This was a new idea to me. I don’t think it ever occurred to me that I was doing anything more than making a social call. I thought of the three rooms over the garage that I had rented from Mr. McKee. “Well, I’d like to,” I said, “but—” We were close to the city now, on the crowded side of the Queensboro Bridge, a hundred feet above the East River. And then, as if in response to my thought, there was a flutter of a dress and the crunch of a shoe on the gravel, and I saw that Jordan Baker was standing beside me. “I’m sorry,” she said, “I didn’t mean to interrupt. But I thought you might be interested to know that Mr. Gatsby is a very rich man.” “Oh, I know that,” I said. “But I didn’t know he was so rich.” “He is,” she said, and then she added, “He’s a very generous man, too. He gave me a pearl necklace the other day.” I looked at her, and she looked at me, and we both laughed. “Well, I’m glad to hear it,” I said. “I hope he’ll be generous to you, too.” “He will,” she simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: Then it was all true. I saw the skins of tigers flaming in his palace on the Grand Canal; I saw him opening a chest of rubies to ease, with their crimson light, the distress of all the poor he had met. With an effort I managed to restrain my incredulous laughter. The thing approached the proportions of standing alone on the last barrier of civilization. “I didn’t like to hear a personal remark,” Gatsby explained. “A man like me must be careful.” There was a pause. “And my parents are dead,” he announced matter-of-factly. “Of course I was brought up in America, but educated at Oxford, because all my ancestors have been educated there for many years. It is a family tradition.” He looked at me sideways—and I knew why Jordan Baker had believed he was lying. He hurried the phrase “educated at Oxford,” or swallowed it, or choked on it, as though it had taken him years to get it right. He was silent for a moment. The idea of Gatsby, big swell, Gatsby who could afford to forget about the past, was in effect extinguished by this statement. I waited, and sure enough, in a moment he looked at me with more attention. “I am going to make a big request of you to-day,” he said, immediately and without caution. “I want you and Jordan to come over to my house this afternoon.” The modesty of the demand shook me. He offered me the money he had made at the drug-stores. He never knew how near he came to giving me a dead rattle. “I beg your pardon,” said I. “Did you request my presence alone?” “No, he wants to know if you’ll invite Daisy to tea,” said the Jordan Baker suddenly from the back seat. “Of course I will. What time?” “He wants it to be in the afternoon,” explained Jordan, “so she can see his house.” This was a new idea to me. I don’t think it ever occurred to me that I was doing anything more than making a social call. I thought of the three rooms over the garage that I had rented from Mr. McKee. “Well, I’d like to,” I said, “but—” We were close to the city now, on the crowded side of the Queensboro Bridge, a hundred feet above the East River. And then, as if in response to my thought, there was a flutter of a dress and the crunch of a shoe on the gravel, and I saw that Jordan Baker was standing beside me. “I’m sorry,” she said, “I didn’t mean to interrupt. But I thought you might be interested to know that Mr. Gatsby is a very rich man.” “Oh, I know that,” I said. “But I didn’t know he was so rich.” “He is,” she said, and then she added, “He’s a very generous man, too. He gave me a pearl necklace the other day.” I looked at her, and she looked at me, and we both laughed. “Well, I’m glad to hear it,” I said. “I hope he’ll be generous to you, too.” “He will,” she 1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion introduces invented scenes and dialogue that do not appear in the original, such as extended conversations with Jordan Baker about gifts and repeated references to being given a car. This invented content replaces significant portions of the original narrative and dialogue.
- The completion omits the entire sequence of the car journey into the city, including the encounter with the policeman, the description of the cityscape, and the symbolic events and observations made during the drive.
- The completion contains a repetitive, looping exchange between characters that is not present in the original and disrupts the narrative flow.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion lacks the original's detailed account of the protagonist's internal reactions and reflections during the conversation with Gatsby.
- The progression of events during the car ride, including passing specific locations, observing notable scenes, and the protagonist's impressions of the city, are missing.
- Key symbolic moments, such as the encounter with the funeral procession and the limousine with its passengers, are not included.
- The original's closing reflections on the sense of possibility and wonder as they cross the bridge are absent.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion misattributes actions and dialogue, assigning lines and intentions to characters that do not match the original sequence.
- The timing and context of the request made by Gatsby are altered, and the nature of the request is inaccurately described.
- The sequence of events is disrupted, with invented conversations replacing the actual progression from the palace imagery to the drive into the city.
- The completion introduces factual inaccuracies regarding character relationships and motivations, and it repeats invented dialogue excessively, which is not present in the original passage.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.refinement_prompt:
IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion introduces invented scenes and dialogue early on, such as references to helping the poor and internal monologue about civilization, which are not present in the original passage.
- There is a significant omission of the entire sequence involving the drive toward the city, including the passing of specific locations, the encounter with the police officer, and the various observations made from the car.
- The completion devolves into a repetitive, irrelevant loop about a character fixing a sporting event, which is not part of this section of the original text and disrupts the narrative flow.
- The ending omits the original’s closing reflections and the significant cityscape and character observations.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion lacks the detailed description of the journey into the city, including the passing of notable landmarks, the visual impressions of the city, and the atmospheric details that set the scene.
- There is no mention of the interaction with the police officer, the use of a card, or the explanation that follows.
- The passage omits the observations of other vehicles and people encountered on the way, such as the funeral procession and the limousine with its occupants.
- The original’s concluding thoughts and the sense of possibility as the city is approached are missing.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion provides inaccurate or invented dialogue and events, such as fabricated explanations of Gatsby’s background and invented internal commentary.
- The sequence of events is incorrect, with invented conversations and topics that do not align with the original’s order.
- The completion introduces a character’s name and actions in places where they do not appear in the original, and misattributes lines and intentions.
- The repetitive section about a sporting event is not only inaccurate for this passage but also disrupts the intended narrative structure and pacing.

To improve, focus on accurately capturing the sequence of events, the key interactions, and the descriptive elements that define the original passage, while avoiding invented or irrelevant content.

events.title: Lunch with Meyer Wolfshiem and Tales of the Underworld
detailed_summary: Nick meets Gatsby for lunch at a basement restaurant on Forty-second Street.
Gatsby introduces Nick to his companion, Mr. Meyer Wolfshiem.
Nick observes Wolfshiem's distinct appearance: small, flat-nosed, large-headed, with prominent nostril hair and small eyes.
Wolfshiem, after a perfunctory handshake, launches into an anecdote about forcefully silencing someone named Katspaugh, seemingly not directed at Nick.
Gatsby guides them to a table as Wolfshiem trails off into abstracted silence.
After ordering drinks, Wolfshiem comments on the restaurant, preferring the 'old Metropole' across the street for its associated memories.
He speaks nostalgically about the Metropole being filled with faces now gone, specifically mentioning friends lost forever.
Wolfshiem recounts in detail the night gangster Herman 'Rosy' Rosenthal was murdered at the Metropole.
He describes being at a table with Rosy when Rosy was called outside late at night.
Wolfshiem recalls warning Rosy not to go outside, urging him to make his potential enemies come inside instead.
Rosy disregarded the warning, asking the waiter not to clear his coffee before stepping onto the sidewalk where he was shot.
Nick interjects, recalling that four men were electrocuted for the crime.
Wolfshiem corrects him, stating five were executed (including Police Lieutenant Charles Becker), and then jarringly pivots, asking Nick if he is looking for a 'business gonnegtion'.
Gatsby quickly clarifies that Nick is merely a friend and not the intended party for such a discussion.
Wolfshiem apologizes for the misunderstanding.
As their meal (succulent hash) arrives, Wolfshiem eats with 'ferocious delicacy,' his eyes methodically scanning the entire restaurant, including the area behind their table.
Nick surmises that Wolfshiem's caution is intense, suggesting he might even check under the table if Nick wasn't there.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Roaring noon.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I think that, except for my presence, he would have taken one short glance beneath our own table.

events.text_segment:
Roaring noon. In a well-fanned Forty-second Street cellar I met Gatsby for lunch. Blinking away the brightness of the street outside, my eyes picked him out obscurely in the anteroom, talking to another man.
“Mr. Carraway, this is my friend Mr. Wolfshiem.”
A small, flat-nosed Jew raised his large head and regarded me with two fine growths of hair which luxuriated in either nostril. After a moment I discovered his tiny eyes in the half-darkness.
“—So I took one look at him,” said Mr. Wolfshiem, shaking my hand earnestly, “and what do you think I did?”
“What?” I inquired politely.
But evidently he was not addressing me, for he dropped my hand and covered Gatsby with his expressive nose.
“I handed the money to Katspaugh and I said: ‘All right, Katspaugh, don’t pay him a penny till he shuts his mouth.’ He shut it then and there.”
Gatsby took an arm of each of us and moved forward into the restaurant, whereupon Mr. Wolfshiem swallowed a new sentence he was starting and lapsed into a somnambulatory abstraction.
“Highballs?” asked the head waiter.
“This is a nice restaurant here,” said Mr. Wolfshiem, looking at the presbyterian nymphs on the ceiling. “But I like across the street better!”
“Yes, highballs,” agreed Gatsby, and then to Mr. Wolfshiem: “It’s too hot over there.”
“Hot and small—yes,” said Mr. Wolfshiem, “but full of memories.”
“What place is that?” I asked.
“The old Metropole.”
“The old Metropole,” brooded Mr. Wolfshiem gloomily. “Filled with faces dead and gone. Filled with friends gone now forever. I can’t forget so long as I live the night they shot Rosy Rosenthal there. It was six of us at the table, and Rosy had eat and drunk a lot all evening. When it was almost morning the waiter came up to him with a funny look and says somebody wants to speak to him outside. ‘All right,’ says Rosy, and begins to get up, and I pulled him down in his chair.
“ ‘Let the bastards come in here if they want you, Rosy, but don’t you, so help me, move outside this room.’
“It was four o’clock in the morning then, and if we’d of raised the blinds we’d of seen daylight.”
“Did he go?” I asked innocently.
“Sure he went.” Mr. Wolfshiem’s nose flashed at me indignantly. “He turned around in the door and says: ‘Don’t let that waiter take away my coffee!’ Then he went out on the sidewalk, and they shot him three times in his full belly and drove away.”
“Four of them were electrocuted,” I said, remembering.
“Five, with Becker.” His nostrils turned to me in an interested way. “I understand you’re looking for a business gonnegtion.”
The juxtaposition of these two remarks was startling. Gatsby answered for me:
“Oh, no,” he exclaimed, “this isn’t the man.”
“No?” Mr. Wolfshiem seemed disappointed.
“This is just a friend. I told you we’d talk about that some other time.”
“I beg your pardon,” said Mr. Wolfshiem, “I had a wrong man.”
A succulent hash arrived, and Mr. Wolfshiem, forgetting the more sentimental atmosphere of the old Metropole, began to eat with ferocious delicacy. His eyes, meanwhile, roved very slowly all around the room—he completed the arc by turning to inspect the people directly behind. I think that, except for my presence, he would have taken one short glance beneath our own table.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Roaring noon. The sun beat down on West Egg with a ferocity that seemed almost personal, baking the manicured lawns and turning the air above the driveways into shimmering waves. Even the colossal, raw-white palace of Jay Gatsby seemed to wilt slightly under the oppressive glare, its towers and terraces losing some of their defiant sparkle in the flat, blinding light. Inside, the air was thick and still, despite the efforts of whirring electric fans that merely stirred the heat around like a spoon in heavy soup. The scent of cut grass, wilting flowers, and something vaguely alcoholic hung in the air, a residue of the previous night's revelry that the sun had failed to burn away. Nick Carraway felt the heat press against him as he stood by a tall window, looking out at the shimmering Sound. The water, usually a cool, inviting blue, was now a dull, metallic grey under the sun's hammer. He had come over at Daisy's casual invitation, a summons delivered with that familiar, breathless urgency that always masked a deeper, unarticulated need. Tom Buchanan was somewhere in the house, a restless, powerful presence even when unseen, his voice occasionally booming from another room like distant thunder. Jordan Baker was draped elegantly on a chaise lounge, a cigarette held languidly between her fingers, her eyes half-closed against the glare reflecting off the polished floor. She seemed impervious to the heat, encased in her own cool, detached world. Then there was Daisy. She drifted into the room like a white cloud, her voice a low, thrilling murmur that promised secrets and laughter. She wore a dress the color of a summer sky just before dusk, and her eyes, the color of the sea on a clear day, held a familiar, wistful expression. The heat seemed to cling to her, making her movements languid, almost dreamlike. She fanned herself slowly with a small, feathered fan, her wrist turning with a delicate grace. Gatsby appeared shortly after, emerging from the shadows of the hallway. He was dressed impeccably, as always, in a light linen suit that seemed impossibly crisp in the heat. His smile, that famous, understanding smile, flickered across his face as he greeted them, but there was a tension in his shoulders, a watchfulness in his eyes that the smile couldn't quite conceal. He moved with a restless energy that seemed at odds with the oppressive stillness of the house. He suggested they go out, perhaps to the city, to escape the heat. The idea hung in the air, charged with unspoken possibilities and dangers. Tom entered the room then, filling the space with his sheer physical presence. He looked hot and bothered, his face flushed. He eyed Gatsby with a proprietary air, a silent challenge passing between the two men that was almost palpable in the stifling heat. The air grew heavier, thicker with unspoken words and simmering resentments. The casual afternoon gathering had suddenly acquired an edge, a tension that the heat seemed to amplify, pressing down on them all. Daisy, sensing the shift, laughed a little too brightly, suggesting they have some iced tea. The sound was brittle, like thin ice cracking. Gatsby watched her, his expression unreadable. Tom watched Gatsby, his jaw set. Nick felt the familiar discomfort of being caught in the crosscurrents of their lives, a silent observer in a drama he couldn't fully comprehend. The heat outside continued its relentless assault, mirroring the rising temperature within the room. The afternoon stretched ahead, long and uncertain, filled with the promise of confrontation and the heavy weight of the past. The roaring noon had given way to a simmering afternoon, pregnant with the possibility of storm, the unbearable heat pressing down on them all.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Roaring noon. In a "private" room of the Forty-second Street cellar I met Gatsby for lunch. Despite the ostensible secrecy of the meeting it was more or less a public affair. When he saw me a sly grin came into his face, and, leaning across the table, he tapped my shoulder with a soft fat finger, and said: "Look here, old sport, you come with me and see the fellows." I went with him inside. A small, flat-nosed Jew raised his large head and regarded me with pale, bright eyes. "This is Mr. Carraway," said Gatsby, cutting a short fine line at the last word, "Mr. Wolfshiem." A succulent hash arrived, and for a while I lost sight of Gatsby and was staring at Wolfshiem. He was a small, flat-nosed Jew with an enormous head, and tiny eyes, which looked out of their expanded pupils over a hooked nose. He was eating with ferocious delicacy, his eyes roving here and there, scanning the whole room, including the area behind our table. I had a sudden conviction that he would have checked under the table if I hadn't been there. "You're a friend of Gatsby's?" he inquired, his eyes still roving. "I am." "That's good," he said, "that's good. He's a fine fellow, a fine fellow. He's a man of fine breeding, a man of family." simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: Roaring noon. In a "private" room of the Forty-second Street cellar I met Gatsby for lunch. Despite the ostensible secrecy of the meeting it was more or less a public affair. When he saw me a sly grin came into his face, and, leaning across the table, he tapped my shoulder with a soft fat finger, and said: "Look here, old sport, you come with me and see the fellows." I went with him inside. A small, flat-nosed Jew raised his large head and regarded me with pale, bright eyes. "This is Mr. Carraway," said Gatsby, cutting a short fine line at the last word, "Mr. Wolfshiem." A succulent hash arrived, and for a while I lost sight of Gatsby and was staring at Wolfshiem. He was a small, flat-nosed Jew with an enormous head, and tiny eyes, which looked out of their expanded pupils over a hooked nose. He was eating with ferocious delicacy, his eyes roving here and there, scanning the whole room, including the area behind our table.
