events.title: Gatsby's Mysteries, Wolfshiem's Identity, and an Awkward Encounter
detailed_summary: Gatsby leans towards Nick, expressing concern that he might have angered him during the earlier car ride.
Nick resists Gatsby's smile, stating his dislike for mysteries and questioning the need for Jordan Baker's involvement in Gatsby's request.
Gatsby assures him it's nothing 'underhand,' praising Jordan's character as a sportswoman.
Gatsby abruptly checks his watch, excuses himself to make a phone call, and leaves Nick alone with Wolfshiem.
Wolfshiem observes Gatsby's departure, praising him as a 'fine fellow,' handsome, a 'perfect gentleman,' and an 'Oggsford man'.
Wolfshiem confirms he attended 'Oggsford College,' calling it one of the world's most famous.
He tells Nick he has known Gatsby for several years, since just after the war, and quickly recognized his 'fine breeding,' deeming him respectable enough to introduce to his mother and sister.
Wolfshiem notices Nick (or pretends to notice) looking at his cufflinks.
He reveals the cufflinks are made from human molars.
Wolfshiem then comments on Gatsby's supposed propriety concerning women, asserting he would never disrespect a friend's marriage.
Gatsby returns to the table.
Wolfshiem finishes his coffee abruptly and stands to leave, announcing his departure as belonging to an 'older generation' and not wanting to impose.
Gatsby offers a lukewarm suggestion for him to stay, but Wolfshiem gives a hand gesture like a blessing and leaves, his 'tragic nose' trembling.
Gatsby explains Wolfshiem's occasional sentimentality, describing him as a 'character around New York—a denizen of Broadway'.
When Nick asks Wolfshiem's profession (actor? dentist?), Gatsby hesitates before coolly revealing Wolfshiem is a gambler.
Gatsby adds the stunning information that Wolfshiem 'fixed the World's Series back in 1919.'
Nick is staggered, having considered the event a historical occurrence rather than the deliberate act of one man manipulating national faith.
Gatsby explains Wolfshiem simply 'saw the opportunity' and is too 'smart' to be caught.
Nick insists on paying the bill.
As the waiter brings change, Nick spots Tom Buchanan across the room and asks Gatsby to come meet him.
Tom approaches Nick eagerly, asking where he's been and mentioning Daisy's annoyance.
Nick introduces Gatsby to Tom.
They shake hands briefly; an unusual look of strain and embarrassment appears on Gatsby's face.
While Tom continues questioning Nick about being so far uptown, Nick turns to include Gatsby in the conversation, only to find he has disappeared.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Look here, old sport,” said Gatsby, leaning toward me, “I’m afraid I made you a little angry this morning in the car.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I turned toward Mr. Gatsby, but he was no longer there.

events.text_segment:
“Look here, old sport,” said Gatsby, leaning toward me, “I’m afraid I made you a little angry this morning in the car.”
There was the smile again, but this time I held out against it.
“I don’t like mysteries,” I answered, “and I don’t understand why you won’t come out frankly and tell me what you want. Why has it all got to come through Miss Baker?”
“Oh, it’s nothing underhand,” he assured me. “Miss Baker’s a great sportswoman, you know, and she’d never do anything that wasn’t all right.”
Suddenly he looked at his watch, jumped up, and hurried from the room, leaving me with Mr. Wolfshiem at the table.
“He has to telephone,” said Mr. Wolfshiem, following him with his eyes. “Fine fellow, isn’t he? Handsome to look at and a perfect gentleman.”
“Yes.”
“He’s an Oggsford man.”
“Oh!”
“He went to Oggsford College in England. You know Oggsford College?”
“I’ve heard of it.”
“It’s one of the most famous colleges in the world.”
“Have you known Gatsby for a long time?” I inquired.
“Several years,” he answered in a gratified way. “I made the pleasure of his acquaintance just after the war. But I knew I had discovered a man of fine breeding after I talked with him an hour. I said to myself: ‘There’s the kind of man you’d like to take home and introduce to your mother and sister.’ ” He paused. “I see you’re looking at my cuff buttons.”
I hadn’t been looking at them, but I did now. They were composed of oddly familiar pieces of ivory.
“Finest specimens of human molars,” he informed me.
“Well!” I inspected them. “That’s a very interesting idea.”
“Yeah.” He flipped his sleeves up under his coat. “Yeah, Gatsby’s very careful about women. He would never so much as look at a friend’s wife.”
When the subject of this instinctive trust returned to the table and sat down Mr. Wolfshiem drank his coffee with a jerk and got to his feet.
“I have enjoyed my lunch,” he said, “and I’m going to run off from you two young men before I outstay my welcome.”
“Don’t hurry Meyer,” said Gatsby, without enthusiasm. Mr. Wolfshiem raised his hand in a sort of benediction.
“You’re very polite, but I belong to another generation,” he announced solemnly. “You sit here and discuss your sports and your young ladies and your—” He supplied an imaginary noun with another wave of his hand. “As for me, I am fifty years old, and I won’t impose myself on you any longer.”
As he shook hands and turned away his tragic nose was trembling. I wondered if I had said anything to offend him.
“He becomes very sentimental sometimes,” explained Gatsby. “This is one of his sentimental days. He’s quite a character around New York—a denizen of Broadway.”
“Who is he, anyhow, an actor?”
“No.”
“A dentist?”
“Meyer Wolfshiem? No, he’s a gambler.” Gatsby hesitated, then added, coolly: “He’s the man who fixed the World’s Series back in 1919.”
“Fixed the World’s Series?” I repeated.
The idea staggered me. I remembered, of course, that the World’s Series had been fixed in 1919, but if I had thought of it at all I would have thought of it as a thing that merely happened, the end of some inevitable chain. It never occurred to me that one man could start to play with the faith of fifty million people—with the single-mindedness of a burglar blowing a safe.
“How did he happen to do that?” I asked after a minute.
“He just saw the opportunity.”
“Why isn’t he in jail?”
“They can’t get him, old sport. He’s a smart man.”
I insisted on paying the check. As the waiter brought my change I caught sight of Tom Buchanan across the crowded room.
“Come along with me for a minute,” I said; “I’ve got to say hello to someone.”
When he saw us Tom jumped up and took half a dozen steps in our direction.
“Where’ve you been?” he demanded eagerly. “Daisy’s furious because you haven’t called up.”
“This is Mr. Gatsby, Mr. Buchanan.”
They shook hands briefly, and a strained, unfamiliar look of embarrassment came over Gatsby’s face.
“How’ve you been, anyhow?” demanded Tom of me. “How’d you happen to come up this far to eat?”
“I’ve been having lunch with Mr. Gatsby.”
I turned toward Mr. Gatsby, but he was no longer there.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: “Look here, old sport,” said Gatsby, leaning toward me, “I’m afraid I made you a little angry this morning in the car.” He hadn’t, but I knew what he meant. He was afraid that I thought him just another rich man, a bootlegger perhaps, and he wanted me to think well of him, to think that he was a man of fine breeding and education. He was, in fact, a little nervous, and he got the impression that I was skeptical of his sudden wealth and elaborate lifestyle. He cleared his throat and began, in a hurried, embarrassed way, to tell me the story of his life. It was a strange story, and as he told it, I felt a growing incredulity. He said he was the son of wealthy people in the Middle West—all dead now. He was brought up in America but educated at Oxford, because all his ancestors had been educated there for many years. This was the first point that made me stare. Oxford, New Mexico, perhaps, I thought, or something of that sort. He saw my doubt and hurried on. “It was an American tradition,” he explained. “The family always lived like Englishmen. Every one of them was educated at Oxford. It’s a family tradition.” He paused, and I waited, but he didn’t elaborate. He seemed to expect me to accept this extraordinary statement without question. He went on to say that after his parents died, he came into a good deal of money. He traveled all over Europe, collecting jewels, chiefly rubies, hunting big game, painting a little, things for myself only, and trying to forget something very sad that happened to him long ago. It was a romantic story, told with a strained, earnest sincerity that was more convincing than the details themselves. He spoke of capitals of Europe, of Monte Carlo, of the Bois de Boulogne, of the Riviera, of the great resorts where he had spent his youth. He had been everywhere, seen everything, done everything. He had even been in the war. “I was in the Argonne Forest,” he said, “I was promoted to be a major, and every Allied government gave me a decoration—even Montenegro, little Montenegro down on the Adriatic Sea!” He pulled a medal out of his pocket, a little, fat, gold medal, and I saw that it was inscribed “Major Jay Gatsby, For Valor Extraordinary.” On the reverse, it said “Montenegro, 1917.” I examined it skeptically. It looked real enough, but it was such an odd thing to carry around. He saw my expression and produced something else, a photograph. “Here’s another thing I keep about me,” he said. “An Oxford man. This was taken at Trinity College. The man on the left is a friend of mine from San Francisco—his name is Mr. Dan Cody. Does the name ring a bell?” I looked at the photograph. It showed about a dozen young men in blazers, sitting in a row. Gatsby was in the front row, looking very young and serious. The man next to him, presumably Dan Cody, was a large, imposing figure. The picture seemed genuine, but it didn’t prove he had been educated there. He could have just visited. I handed the things back to him, feeling more confused than ever. His story was so improbable, so filled with clichés from cheap novels, and yet, the medal and the photograph provided a strange, tangible support for it. He put them away and we drove on in silence for a moment. I was trying to reconcile the man I knew, the host of the lavish parties, the mysterious figure, with this romantic, slightly absurd character he was presenting. Just then, a policeman on a motorcycle pulled us over. My heart sank. This was it, I thought. The real reason for his wealth, the bootlegging, the illegal activities, were about to be exposed. But Gatsby, with a calm assurance that surprised me, simply reached into his wallet and produced a small white card. He handed it to the policeman. The officer took it, glanced at it, and his expression changed instantly. He saluted. “Right you are, Mr. Gatsby,” he said. “Proceed.” He waved us on, and we drove away, leaving the policeman standing by the road. Gatsby put the card back in his wallet. “I was able to do the commissioner a favor once,” he explained casually. “He sends me a Christmas card every year.” I stared at him, speechless. The incident with the policeman, the white card, it was like something out of a movie. It added another layer to the mystery of Jay Gatsby. It was clear that he had connections, powerful connections, that went beyond the world of West Egg and its nouveau riche. He had shown me the medal, the photograph, and now this. He was determined to convince me that he was not just some nobody who had stumbled into money, but a man with a history, a past, even if that past seemed to be a carefully constructed fiction. He wanted me to believe in him, to trust him, perhaps because he had a favor to ask, a favor that was important enough for him to reveal these carefully guarded pieces of his identity, or at least, the identity he wanted me to see. The car sped on towards the city, and I sat beside him, trying to make sense of the man who was Jay Gatsby, a man who seemed to be composed of equal parts ambition, mystery, and carefully curated lies.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Look here, old sport,” said Gatsby, leaning toward me, “I’m afraid I made you a little angry this morning in the car.”

There was the smile again, but this time I held my ground. “I don’t like mysteries,” I answered, “and I don’t understand why you won’t tell me what it is you want. Why in the devil’s name don’t you ask me yourself?”

“He was embarrassed, that’s all,” said Gatsby. “And he’s only a young man, after all.”

“This matter of Jordan Baker’s was that?”

“No, no, nothing to do with it at all. You see, I carry on a little business on the side, a sort of side line, you understand. And I thought that you might be able to use the connection.”

“With Jordan Baker?” I asked, politely confused.

“No, not with Jordan Baker. I thought you knew old sport. I’m afraid I’m not making myself clear. Jordan Baker’s a great sportswoman, you know, and she’d never do anything that wasn’t all right.”

The phrase “all right” in the mouth of Gatsby had an ominous ring, and I instantly jumped to the conclusion that he was offering me a cheap career as a salesman at several times my salary. I explained that I was much obliged, but I was engaged in another transaction that might take some time.

“Oh, it isn’t that,” he said. “I’m not just a nobody. I’ve been out of college only five years. I’ve been in the army and in France.” He looked at me with an anxious, puzzled effort, as if to find out what it was I was thinking. “Well,” he added, “I don’t want to keep you any longer, old sport.”

“I’m not in any hurry,” I said.

“I have to make a phone call, anyway.” He got up awkwardly, and I was about to rise when the front door opened and Wolfshiem came in, his tragic nose trembling in the candlelight. He looked at us all with a sort of melancholy satisfaction, and then, seeing Gatsby, his face broke into a radiant and benevolent smile.

“Ah, Gatsby, my dear fellow,” he cried, “how are you?”

“Fine, thank you, Mr. Wolfshiem,” answered Gatsby, as if surprised to see him. “I was just going to call you.”

“Well, I’m here, you see. I’m here. I can’t stay long. I’m just passing through. I have to go to Chicago.”

“Oh, I see. Well, I’ll be back in a minute.”

“Don’t hurry, my dear fellow. I’m just going to have a cup of coffee.” He sat down and looked at me with a sort of benign curiosity. “And this is the young man?” he inquired, with a slight bow.

“This is Mr. Carraway,” said Gatsby, politely.

“Ah, indeed. Mr. Carraway. I’ve heard about you.” He looked at me again with that same benign curiosity. “You’re a friend of Gatsby’s?”

“I am.”

“Ah, indeed. Well, I’m glad to know you, Mr. Carraway. I’ve known Gatsby for a long time. We were in the war together.”

“Oh, were you?”

“Yes, indeed. We were in the same division. We were in the same company. We were in the same platoon. We were in the same squad.” He paused and looked at me with a sort of proud satisfaction. “We were in the same tent.”

“Oh, I see.”

“Yes, indeed. We were in the same tent. And we were in the same bed.” He paused again and looked at me with a sort of triumphant satisfaction. “We were in the same sleeping bag.”

“Oh, I see.”

“Yes, indeed. We were in the same sleeping bag. And we were in the same dream.” He paused again and looked at me with a sort of mystical satisfaction. “We were in the same universe.”

“Oh, I see.”

“Yes, indeed. We were in the same universe. And we were in the same God.” He paused again and looked at me with a sort of divine satisfaction. “We were in the same nothing.”

“Oh, I see.”

“Yes, indeed. We were in the same nothing. And we were in the same everything.” He paused again and looked at me with a sort of cosmic satisfaction. “We were in the same all.”

“Oh, I see.”

“Yes, indeed. We were in the same all. And we were in the same one.” He paused again and looked at me with a sort of ultimate satisfaction. “We were in the same zero.”

events.title: Jordan Recounts Daisy and Gatsby's Early Romance and Her Pre-Wedding Crisis
detailed_summary: The narrative shifts to Jordan Baker telling Nick a story later that afternoon in the Plaza Hotel's tea-garden.
Jordan recalls walking in Louisville in October 1917, wearing distinctive English shoes.
She describes passing Daisy Fay's house; Daisy, then eighteen and Louisville's most popular girl, constantly received calls from officers stationed at Camp Taylor.
Jordan recounts seeing Daisy sitting in her white roadster beside the curb with a lieutenant Jordan hadn't seen before.
The couple was so intensely focused on each other they didn't notice Jordan until she was very close.
Daisy called Jordan over, flattering her by wanting to speak to her.
Daisy asked Jordan to relay a message that she couldn't make it to the Red Cross that day.
Jordan distinctly remembers the way the lieutenant looked at Daisy while she spoke – a look of adoration she found romantic and memorable.
Jordan reveals the lieutenant's name was Jay Gatsby, and she didn't recognize him again for over four years, not even initially after meeting him on Long Island.
Jordan explains that by the following year (1918), she was occupied with her own social life and golf tournaments and saw less of Daisy.
Rumors circulated about Daisy's mother finding her packing to go to New York to bid farewell to a soldier heading overseas; she was stopped and estranged from her family for weeks.
After that incident, Daisy stopped socializing with soldiers and only associated with local young men unfit for military service.
By the autumn of 1919, Daisy was cheerful again, had her debutante presentation after the armistice, and was reportedly engaged by February.
In June, she married Tom Buchanan of Chicago in an exceptionally grand wedding for Louisville.
Tom arrived with a large entourage, rented an entire hotel floor, and gave Daisy a pearl necklace valued at $350,000 the day before the ceremony.
Jordan, serving as a bridesmaid, entered Daisy's room thirty minutes before the bridal dinner.
She found Daisy lying on her bed, beautifully dressed but extremely drunk, holding a bottle of Sauterne and a letter.
Daisy, admitting she'd never drunk before, urged Jordan to congratulate her.
Scared, Jordan asked what was wrong.
Daisy retrieved the pearl necklace from a wastebasket, telling Jordan to return it to its owner and declare that 'Daisy's change' her mind.'
Daisy then broke down, crying hysterically.
Jordan fetched Daisy's mother's maid; they locked the door and forced Daisy into a cold bath.
Daisy clung to the letter, taking it into the tub until it dissolved into a wet pulp, finally allowing Jordan to place the remains in the soap dish.
Daisy spoke no further about the incident.
They revived her with smelling salts, applied ice, dressed her, and half an hour later, she emerged composed with the pearls around her neck.
The following day at 5 PM, she married Tom Buchanan calmly and left for a three-month honeymoon in the South Seas.

events.text_segment:
One October day in nineteen-seventeen—
(said Jordan Baker that afternoon, sitting up very straight on a straight chair in the tea-garden at the Plaza Hotel)
—I was walking along from one place to another, half on the sidewalks and half on the lawns. I was happier on the lawns because I had on shoes from England with rubber knobs on the soles that bit into the soft ground. I had on a new plaid skirt also that blew a little in the wind, and whenever this happened the red, white, and blue banners in front of all the houses stretched out stiff and said tut-tut-tut-tut, in a disapproving way.
The largest of the banners and the largest of the lawns belonged to Daisy Fay’s house. She was just eighteen, two years older than me, and by far the most popular of all the young girls in Louisville. She dressed in white, and had a little white roadster, and all day long the telephone rang in her house and excited young officers from Camp Taylor demanded the privilege of monopolizing her that night. “Anyways, for an hour!”
When I came opposite her house that morning her white roadster was beside the kerb, and she was sitting in it with a lieutenant I had never seen before. They were so engrossed in each other that she didn’t see me until I was five feet away.
“Hello, Jordan,” she called unexpectedly. “Please come here.”
I was flattered that she wanted to speak to me, because of all the older girls I admired her most. She asked me if I was going to the Red Cross to make bandages. I was. Well, then, would I tell them that she couldn’t come that day? The officer looked at Daisy while she was speaking, in a way that every young girl wants to be looked at sometime, and because it seemed romantic to me I have remembered the incident ever since. His name was Jay Gatsby, and I didn’t lay eyes on him again for over four years—even after I’d met him on Long Island I didn’t realize it was the same man.
That was nineteen-seventeen. By the next year I had a few beaux myself, and I began to play in tournaments, so I didn’t see Daisy very often. She went with a slightly older crowd—when she went with anyone at all. Wild rumours were circulating about her—how her mother had found her packing her bag one winter night to go to New York and say goodbye to a soldier who was going overseas. She was effectually prevented, but she wasn’t on speaking terms with her family for several weeks. After that she didn’t play around with the soldiers any more, but only with a few flat-footed, shortsighted young men in town, who couldn’t get into the army at all.
By the next autumn she was gay again, gay as ever. She had a début after the armistice, and in February she was presumably engaged to a man from New Orleans. In June she married Tom Buchanan of Chicago, with more pomp and circumstance than Louisville ever knew before. He came down with a hundred people in four private cars, and hired a whole floor of the Muhlbach Hotel, and the day before the wedding he gave her a string of pearls valued at three hundred and fifty thousand dollars.
I was a bridesmaid. I came into her room half an hour before the bridal dinner, and found her lying on her bed as lovely as the June night in her flowered dress—and as drunk as a monkey. She had a bottle of Sauterne in one hand and a letter in the other.
“ ’Gratulate me,” she muttered. “Never had a drink before, but oh how I do enjoy it.”
“What’s the matter, Daisy?”
I was scared, I can tell you; I’d never seen a girl like that before.
“Here, dearies.” She groped around in a wastebasket she had with her on the bed and pulled out the string of pearls. “Take ’em downstairs and give ’em back to whoever they belong to. Tell ’em all Daisy’s change’ her mine. Say: ‘Daisy’s change’ her mine!’ ”
She began to cry—she cried and cried. I rushed out and found her mother’s maid, and we locked the door and got her into a cold bath. She wouldn’t let go of the letter. She took it into the tub with her and squeezed it up in a wet ball, and only let me leave it in the soap-dish when she saw that it was coming to pieces like snow.
But she didn’t say another word. We gave her spirits of ammonia and put ice on her forehead and hooked her back into her dress, and half an hour later, when we walked out of the room, the pearls were around her neck and the incident was over. Next day at five o’clock she married Tom Buchanan without so much as a shiver, and started off on a three months’ trip to the South Seas.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
One October day in nineteen-seventeen—

(said Jordan Baker that afternoon, sitting with me on the piazza of the Plaza Hotel) I was walking along the street with a girl named Daisy. She was just eighteen, the most popular of all the young girls in Louisville, and by the next year she had grown into a slender, golden girl, twenty years old. She was dressed in white, and stood with the sun shining through her, a bright, passionate mouth, and the choicest of all young girls that America could offer. She was feeling the pressure of the world outside, and she wanted to see the most interesting, exciting people she could find. She wanted to live and be alive.

Well, this day in October, I was walking along the street with Daisy, and we came to a house where there was a great deal of gayety and excitement. There were officers from Camp Taylor, and they were all in love with Daisy. She was the most popular girl in Louisville, and she had a constant stream of officers calling on her. This day, we came to her house, and there was a car parked outside. It was a white roadster, and there was a young lieutenant sitting in it with Daisy. I had never seen him before. They were so engrossed in each other that they didn't see us until we were right beside them.

Daisy called out to me, 'Jordan! Won't you come over?'

I went over, and she said, 'I want you to tell them I couldn't come to the Red Cross today. I'm sorry, but I just couldn't.'

I looked at the lieutenant, and he was looking at Daisy in a way that I had never seen anyone look at anyone before. He was looking at her as if she were the most precious thing in the world. I remember that look, and I remember the way he said her name. It was Jay Gatsby. I didn't see him again for over four years. Not until I met him on Long Island.

Well, the next year, I was busy with my own life. I was playing golf, and I was going to parties. I didn't see as much of Daisy as I had before. But I heard things. I heard that her mother had found her packing to go to New York to say good-by to a soldier who was going overseas. Her mother had stopped her, and she had been estranged from her family for weeks. After that, she didn't go out with soldiers any more. She only went out with young men from Louisville who were not in the army.

By the autumn of nineteen-nineteen, she was her happy self again. She had her debut after the armistice, and in February she was engaged. In June, she married Tom Buchanan of Chicago. He came down with a crowd of people in four private cars, and they took a whole floor of the Seelbach Hotel, and the day before the wedding he gave her a string of pearls valued at three hundred and fifty thousand dollars.

I was a bridesmaid. I came into her room half an hour before the bridal dinner, and found her lying on her bed as lovely as the white girlhood of the world, and as drunk as a monkey. She had a bottle of Sauterne in one hand and a letter in the other.

'Here, dearie,' she said. 'Take 'em downstairs and give 'em back to whoever they belong to. Tell 'em all Daisy's change' her mind. Say "Daisy's change' her mind!"'

She began to cry—she cried and cried. I couldn't get a word out of her, so I went downstairs to get somebody. I got the maid, and we locked the door and got her into a cold bath. She wouldn't let go of the letter. She took it into the tub with her and squeezed it up into a wet ball, and only let me take it away from her when she saw that it was coming to pieces like snow. But she didn't say another word. We gave her spirits of ammonia and put ice on her forehead and hooked her into her dress, and half an hour later, when we walked out of the room, she was as cool as an autumn leaf with her pearls around her neck and the incident was over. And all the time she kept saying it was a mistake, and she was sorry, and she wouldn't do it again.

At five o'clock she married Tom Buchanan without so much as a shiver, and started off on a three months' trip to the South Seas.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: One October day in nineteen-seventeen—(told me by Jordan Baker, who had it from Gatsby, who had it from Daisy, I suppose)—the officer, young James Gatz, met Daisy Fay. It was in Louisville. The city was alive with young officers from Camp Taylor, their uniforms bright against the autumn leaves, their laughter echoing through the streets. Daisy, a girl of eighteen, was already a figure of legend in her own small world, a world of money, privilege, and effortless charm. She was beautiful, of course, with a voice that was like money, a voice that promised excitement and whispered of possibilities. She moved through her days surrounded by admirers, a golden girl in a golden house, seemingly untouched by the anxieties of the world at war. But beneath the surface of her bright, careless existence, there was a yearning, a desire for something more, something perhaps even dangerous. And then, James Gatz, or rather, Lieutenant Jay Gatsby as he had begun to call himself, appeared. He was penniless, a man with no past to speak of, only a future he was determined to invent. He had drifted into her orbit, drawn by the same magnetic pull that drew everyone to her, but with a difference. He saw not just the beautiful girl, but the symbol she represented, the life he craved, the world of wealth and security that had always been just beyond his reach. He was an officer, yes, but one who had come from nowhere, who had worked his way up from the bottom, carrying the weight of his humble origins like a secret burden. He knew instinctively that to win Daisy, he had to become someone else entirely. He had to become the man she expected, the man who belonged in her world. He lied about his background, about his family, about his money. He presented himself as a man of the same class, the same breeding, the same effortless ease. And Daisy, captivated by his uniform, his youth, his intensity, and perhaps most of all, by the sheer force of his presence, believed him. Their romance was swift and intense, a whirlwind of stolen moments and whispered promises. They drove through the autumn streets in her white car, the air crisp and cool, the world outside their bubble seeming to fade away. They spent hours together, talking, laughing, falling deeper and deeper in love. For Gatsby, Daisy was the embodiment of his dreams, the golden girl who held the key to the life he desperately wanted. For Daisy, Gatsby was an escape from the predictable path laid out before her, a taste of adventure and passion in a world that often felt stiflingly safe. He took her by storm, his passion overwhelming her carefully constructed defenses. He was the first man who had ever looked at her with such complete devotion, such absolute certainty. He made her feel special, unique, the center of his universe. And in return, she gave him her heart, or at least, the part of it that was capable of such a gift at that time in her life. He knew that he had no right to her, that his deception was a fragile foundation for their love. But he was desperate, consumed by his vision of the future, a future that had to include Daisy. He felt married to her, he told Jordan, that was the only way he could describe it. It was as if their brief time together had sealed their fate, bound them together in a way that transcended the conventional ties of marriage. He had taken her because he loved her, but also because he saw in her the promise of everything he wanted. He had committed himself to her, and in doing so, he had committed himself to a certain way of life, a certain kind of success. He knew that he had to succeed, that he had to become the man he pretended to be, not just for himself, but for her. Their time together was tragically short. The war intervened, as it did for so many young men and women of that generation. Gatsby was called away, sent overseas to fight. He left Daisy with promises of return, with letters filled with longing and devotion. And for a time, Daisy waited. She was young, beautiful, and surrounded by eligible men. The world moved on, and the intensity of their brief romance began to fade, like a photograph left too long in the sun. She received his letters, but they seemed to come from a different world, a world of trenches and danger that felt increasingly distant from her comfortable life in Louisville. She was lonely, and the pressure to marry, to settle down, became immense. There were other men, men who belonged to her world, men who offered security and stability. And then, Tom Buchanan arrived, a man of immense wealth and power, a man who offered her the kind of life she had always known, but on an even grander scale. He was everything Gatsby was not – established, secure, undeniably part of the world she inhabited. He swept her off her feet, his confidence and wealth a powerful antidote to her loneliness and uncertainty. She married him, not out of great love, perhaps, but out of a need for security, a desire to move on, and perhaps a flicker of resentment that Gatsby had not returned sooner, had not been able to offer her the same stability. And so, the golden girl married the brute, and Gatsby, fighting a war thousands of miles away, lost her. But he never forgot. The memory of Daisy, the dream of the life she represented, became the driving force of his existence. Everything he did, every risk he took, every dollar he earned, was aimed at one goal: to recreate that brief, perfect time in Louisville, to win back the girl who had embodied his impossible dream. He built his mansion across the bay from her house, a monument to his unwavering hope, a beacon meant to draw her back to him. He threw lavish parties, hoping she would wander in, drawn by the light and the music. He waited, patiently, obsessively, for the day when he could finally reclaim the past, when he could step back into that October day in nineteen-seventeen and make it last forever. That brief, intense romance in Louisville was the genesis of everything that followed, the seed from which the tragedy of Jay Gatsby's life would inevitably grow. It was the moment when the dream was born, a dream so powerful, so consuming, that it would ultimately destroy him.

events.title: Jordan Details Daisy's Marriage, Tom's Infidelity, and Gatsby's Reappearance
detailed_summary: Jordan continues her story, recalling seeing the Buchanans in Santa Barbara after their honeymoon.
She describes Daisy appearing utterly infatuated with Tom, becoming anxious if he briefly left the room and gazing at him with 'unfathomable delight'.
Jordan found their intense affection touching, though slightly amusing.
However, a week after Jordan's visit, Tom was involved in a car accident on the Ventura road.
The incident became public because his passenger, a chambermaid from the Santa Barbara Hotel, broke her arm, exposing Tom's early infidelity.
The following April, Daisy gave birth to their daughter.
The Buchanans subsequently spent a year traveling in France (Cannes, Deauville).
Jordan saw them during their time abroad.
They eventually returned to the US and settled in Chicago.
Daisy became a popular figure in Chicago's young, wealthy, and 'wild' social set.
Jordan emphasizes that Daisy maintained an 'absolutely perfect reputation'.
She attributes this partly to Daisy's abstinence from alcohol, which allowed her to maintain composure and discretion among hard-drinking peers.
Jordan muses on whether Daisy ever had affairs, alluding to an enigmatic quality in Daisy's voice.
Jordan brings the story closer to the present, explaining that about six weeks ago, Daisy heard Gatsby's name for the first time in years.
This occurred when Jordan asked Nick if he knew Gatsby (referencing their earlier conversation).
After Nick left that day, Daisy came to Jordan's room, woke her, and asked, 'What Gatsby?'.
When Jordan (half-asleep) described him, Daisy reacted strangely, saying it must be the man she used to know.

Jordan states that it was only at that moment that she finally connected the wealthy Jay Gatsby of West Egg with the young lieutenant Daisy had been with in the white roadster years earlier in Louisville.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I saw them in Santa Barbara when they came back, and I thought I’d never seen a girl so mad about her husband.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It wasn’t until then that I connected this Gatsby with the officer in her white car.

events.text_segment:
I saw them in Santa Barbara when they came back, and I thought I’d never seen a girl so mad about her husband. If he left the room for a minute she’d look around uneasily, and say: “Where’s Tom gone?” and wear the most abstracted expression until she saw him coming in the door. She used to sit on the sand with his head in her lap by the hour, rubbing her fingers over his eyes and looking at him with unfathomable delight. It was touching to see them together—it made you laugh in a hushed, fascinated way. That was in August. A week after I left Santa Barbara Tom ran into a wagon on the Ventura road one night, and ripped a front wheel off his car. The girl who was with him got into the papers, too, because her arm was broken—she was one of the chambermaids in the Santa Barbara Hotel.
The next April Daisy had her little girl, and they went to France for a year. I saw them one spring in Cannes, and later in Deauville, and then they came back to Chicago to settle down. Daisy was popular in Chicago, as you know. They moved with a fast crowd, all of them young and rich and wild, but she came out with an absolutely perfect reputation. Perhaps because she doesn’t drink. It’s a great advantage not to drink among hard-drinking people. You can hold your tongue and, moreover, you can time any little irregularity of your own so that everybody else is so blind that they don’t see or care. Perhaps Daisy never went in for amour at all—and yet there’s something in that voice of hers…
Well, about six weeks ago, she heard the name Gatsby for the first time in years. It was when I asked you—do you remember?—if you knew Gatsby in West Egg. After you had gone home she came into my room and woke me up, and said: “What Gatsby?” and when I described him—I was half asleep—she said in the strangest voice that it must be the man she used to know. It wasn’t until then that I connected this Gatsby with the officer in her white car.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: I saw them in Santa Barbara when they came back, and I thought I’d never seen a girl so mad about her husband. They were like figures out of a fairy tale, rich and beautiful, moving through sun-drenched landscapes with an air of effortless grace. Their house in Santa Barbara was sprawling and magnificent, filled with light and the scent of flowers, a place where time seemed to move at a more leisurely, luxurious pace. Daisy, with her low, thrilling voice that was full of money, seemed utterly captivated by Tom. She hung on his words, laughed at his jokes with a genuine, sparkling mirth, and followed him with her eyes across crowded rooms. He was a man of immense physical power and confidence, a former football hero who carried himself with an almost arrogant assurance, and she seemed to bask in his presence, drawing strength and identity from being his wife. They traveled constantly in those early years – Palm Beach, the Riviera, wherever the sun shone brightest and the wealthy gathered to play. Their life was a blur of exclusive parties, thrilling polo matches where Tom excelled, and leisurely afternoons spent yachting on azure waters. Daisy was always the center of attention, effortlessly charming everyone she met with her radiant smile and captivating personality, but her focus always seemed to return to Tom. It was a dazzling spectacle of wealth and young love, or what certainly appeared to be young love to an outsider like myself. I remember thinking how complete they seemed, how perfectly matched in their privilege and their shared, careless ease. They moved through the world with an air of invincibility, as if nothing could ever touch them, protected by their immense fortune and their social standing. Their happiness seemed as solid and enduring as their vast wealth. I saw them again later, of course, and the picture changed dramatically, revealing the cracks beneath the glittering surface, but that first impression of Daisy's absolute devotion to Tom, her radiant happiness in his company, remained vividly etched in my memory. It was a powerful image of a woman utterly consumed by love for her husband, a love that seemed to define her existence in those early, golden days of their marriage. They were the golden couple, living a golden life, and Daisy was the radiant sun around which Tom, the powerful, imposing planet, revolved. It was a world I could only observe from the periphery, a world of effortless grace and boundless possibility, embodied by Daisy's seemingly boundless affection for Tom. The sheer intensity of her gaze when she looked at him, the way her hand would instinctively reach for his arm or rest lightly on his shoulder, spoke volumes about her feelings. It wasn't just affection; it was adoration, a complete surrender to the idea of him as her protector and her world. This was before the restlessness set in, before the gilded cage began to feel like a prison, before the whispers started circulating about Tom's infidelities. In Santa Barbara, and in those subsequent early years, they were the epitome of marital bliss, a perfect, glittering unit, seemingly destined for a lifetime of shared happiness and privilege. It was a vision of life that seemed utterly unattainable to me, yet fascinating to witness.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: I saw them in Santa Barbara when they came back, and I thought I’d never seen a girl so mad about her husband. If he left the room for a minute she’d look around uneasily, and say: ‘Where’s Tom gone?’ and wear the most abstracted expression until she saw him again. She used to sit on the sand with his head in her lap, looking at him with unfathomable delight. It was touching to see them together—it made you laugh in a tender way. Then along about sixty-five they moved back to Chicago, and they were still there when Eisenhower came in, so they must have been married five years now. Everybody had seen them all over that winter. I think she went to California for a week at Easter, and fell in love with Tom when he stopped off there on his way to Chicago. He was dressed in his army uniform, and I remember thinking it was the first time I’d ever seen a man produce such an effect upon a girl. She used to sit on the sand with his head in her lap, looking at him with unfathomable delight. It was touching to see them together—it made you laugh in a tender way. Then along about sixty-five they moved back to Chicago, and they were still there when Eisenhower came in, so they must have been married five years now. Everybody had seen them all over that winter. I think she went to California for a week at Easter, and fell in love with Tom when he stopped off there on his way to Chicago. He was dressed in his army uniform, and I remember thinking it was the first time I’d ever seen a man produce such an effect upon a girl. She had a début after the armistice, and in February she was married to Tom Buchanan of Chicago. He came down with a hundred people in four private cars, and hired a whole floor of the Muhlbach Hotel, and the day before the wedding he gave her a string of pearls valued at three hundred and fifty thousand dollars. I was bridesmaid. I came into her room half an hour before the bridal dinner, and found her lying on her bed as lovely as the June night in her flowered dress—and as drunk as a monkey. She had a letter in her hand. ‘Here, read this,’ she muttered. ‘And tell me what to do. It’s from that man Gatsby.’ Something was said about the pearls. She stood up, threw the pearls down the steps and she didn’t even know she was doing it. ‘The three hundred and fifty thousand dollar necklace!’ She cried. ‘The three hundred and fifty thousand dollar necklace!’ Then she went into the bath-room and held the letter under a cold shower, and wouldn’t let me in. I waited outside the door. I heard a little splash on the floor, and the sound of a chauffeur going down the stairs. I know what begged her to wait, and she wouldn’t even listen to me. She wouldn’t look at anything. And then she went into the bath-room and held the letter under a cold shower, and wouldn’t let me in. I waited outside the door. events.title: Jordan Explains Gatsby's True Motive and His Request
detailed_summary: Jordan concludes her narrative as she and Nick ride through Central Park in a carriage at twilight.
Nick observes that the connection seems like a 'strange coincidence'.
Jordan refutes this, stating it was entirely intentional.
She reveals the crucial information: Gatsby purchased his West Egg mansion solely because it was situated directly across the bay from Daisy's home.
This revelation makes Nick understand Gatsby's earlier gesture towards the green light wasn't aimed at the stars but specifically at Daisy; Gatsby's 'purposeless splendour' now has a clear objective.
Jordan relays Gatsby's specific request to Nick: he wants Nick to invite Daisy to his house for tea on some afternoon, and then arrange for Gatsby himself to 'come over'.
Nick is taken aback by the modesty and indirectness of the request, considering Gatsby's five-year wait and extravagant lifestyle ostensibly built for this purpose.

Jordan attributes Gatsby's convoluted approach to fear and the prolonged anticipation, suggesting Gatsby worried Nick might be offended. She adds that beneath it all, Gatsby possesses a certain toughness.
Nick inquires why Gatsby didn't simply ask Jordan to arrange the meeting.
Jordan explains Gatsby specifically wants Daisy to see his impressive house, and Nick's adjacent cottage provides the perfect pretext.
Jordan shares that Gatsby had hoped Daisy might spontaneously wander into one of his parties, but she never did.
Consequently, Gatsby began subtly inquiring among his acquaintances if anyone knew Daisy, with Jordan being the first useful connection he found.
Jordan recounts how Gatsby elaborately worked up to asking for her help during one of his parties.
She notes that Gatsby vehemently rejected her initial suggestion of arranging a luncheon in New York, insisting the meeting must happen 'right next door' and appear casual, not 'out of the way'.

Jordan also mentions that Gatsby became hesitant upon learning Nick was friendly with Tom, nearly abandoning the plan, despite having limited knowledge of Tom himself, gleaned primarily from years of reading Chicago newspapers hoping to find Daisy's name.

events.text_segment:
When Jordan Baker had finished telling all this we had left the Plaza for half an hour and were driving in a victoria through Central Park. The sun had gone down behind the tall apartments of the movie stars in the West Fifties, and the clear voices of children, already gathered like crickets on the grass, rose through the hot twilight:
“I’m the Sheik of Araby.
Your love belongs to me.
At night when you’re asleep
Into your tent I’ll creep—”
“It was a strange coincidence,” I said.
“But it wasn’t a coincidence at all.”
“Why not?”
“Gatsby bought that house so that Daisy would be just across the bay.”
Then it had not been merely the stars to which he had aspired on that June night. He came alive to me, delivered suddenly from the womb of his purposeless splendour.
“He wants to know,” continued Jordan, “if you’ll invite Daisy to your house some afternoon and then let him come over.”
The modesty of the demand shook me. He had waited five years and bought a mansion where he dispensed starlight to casual moths—so that he could “come over” some afternoon to a stranger’s garden.
“Did I have to know all this before he could ask such a little thing?”
“He’s afraid, he’s waited so long. He thought you might be offended. You see, he’s regular tough underneath it all.”
Something worried me.
“Why didn’t he ask you to arrange a meeting?”
“He wants her to see his house,” she explained. “And your house is right next door.”
“Oh!”
“I think he half expected her to wander into one of his parties, some night,” went on Jordan, “but she never did. Then he began asking people casually if they knew her, and I was the first one he found. It was that night he sent for me at his dance, and you should have heard the elaborate way he worked up to it. Of course, I immediately suggested a luncheon in New York—and I thought he’d go mad:
“ ‘I don’t want to do anything out of the way!’ he kept saying. ‘I want to see her right next door.’
“When I said you were a particular friend of Tom’s, he started to abandon the whole idea. He doesn’t know very much about Tom, though he says he’s read a Chicago paper for years just on the chance of catching a glimpse of Daisy’s name.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
When Jordan Baker had finished telling all this we had left the Plaza for half an hour and were driving in a victoria through Central Park. The sun had gone down behind the tall apartments of the movie stars in the West Fifties, and the clear pale dawn of the season was upon us when we started for Long Island. There was a long, hot, dusty ride ahead, and the victoria seemed to crawl through the park's fading light. The air was thick with the smell of hot asphalt and wilting leaves. No one spoke. The afternoon's brutal honesty hung in the air like the heat itself, heavy and suffocating. Daisy sat beside Gatsby, her face pale and drawn, her eyes fixed straight ahead. Tom, across from them, stared out the window, his jaw set, a muscle twitching in his cheek. Jordan leaned back, her eyes closed, perhaps feigning sleep, perhaps genuinely exhausted by the emotional wreckage. I felt a profound weariness settle over me, a sense of the futility of it all. The grand gesture, the desperate attempt to recapture the past, had collapsed under the weight of reality and Tom's brutal pragmatism. Gatsby, who had seemed so invincible just hours before, now looked like a man who had lost everything. His dream, so tangible and close, had dissolved like mist in the harsh light of the Plaza suite.

The silence stretched, broken only by the clip-clop of the horse's hooves and the distant hum of city traffic. We emerged from the park and headed towards the Queensboro Bridge. The decision was made, unspoken but understood: the party was over. The illusion was shattered. We had to go home.

As we reached the bridge, Tom suddenly spoke, his voice rough. "We'd better stop for gas."
Gatsby nodded, his eyes still on Daisy.
"And we'll switch cars," Tom added, looking directly at Gatsby. "You take my coupe. Jordan and Nick and I will go in your yellow one."
A flicker of something – defiance? despair? – crossed Gatsby's face, but he agreed. It was a strategic move by Tom, forcing Gatsby into his car with Daisy, perhaps to prove his confidence, perhaps to set a trap. Or perhaps it was just the simplest arrangement for getting home.

We stopped at a garage on the edge of the city. The air was even hotter here, smelling of oil and gasoline. The attendant, a young Greek named Michaelis, filled the tanks. The exchange of cars felt significant, a physical manifestation of the shifting power dynamics. Gatsby and Daisy got into the blue coupe. Tom, Jordan, and I climbed into the opulent, ill-fated yellow car. As we pulled away, heading east towards the Eggs, I had a premonition of disaster, a sense that the day's events were not yet concluded, that the heat and the tension were building towards a terrible climax. The sun was now a fiery ball sinking below the horizon, casting long, distorted shadows ahead of us. The road stretched out, empty and waiting.

events.title: Nick and Jordan's Intimacy Grows in Central Park
detailed_summary: As night falls fully and their carriage travels under a bridge, Nick's focus shifts from Gatsby's elaborate plan concerning Daisy.
He acts on his attraction to Jordan, putting his arm around her and pulling her closer.
He invites her to dinner.
Nick reflects on his perception of Jordan as 'clean, hard, limited' and appreciates her 'universal scepticism'.
He finds himself drawn to her as she leans back within his embrace.
A thought about the categories of people crystallizes in his mind: 'There are only the pursued, the pursuing, the busy, and the tired.'
Jordan softly comments that Daisy 'ought to have something in her life,' hinting at dissatisfaction in Daisy's marriage.
Nick asks if Daisy is aware of the plan or wants to see Gatsby.
Jordan clarifies that Daisy must not know about the arrangement beforehand; Nick's invitation should appear as a simple, casual tea.
As their carriage passes the illuminated façade of Fifty-Ninth Street, Nick contrasts his own romantic situation with that of Gatsby and Tom.
Unlike them, he doesn't have an idealized, disembodied female face haunting his thoughts.
Motivated by this reflection and Jordan's faint, 'wan, scornful' smile, he tightens his embrace.
He draws her closer still, bringing his face near hers as the chapter ends on this intimate moment.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was dark now, and as we dipped under a little bridge I put my arm around Jordan’s golden shoulder and drew her toward me and asked her to dinner.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Her wan, scornful mouth smiled, and so I drew her up again closer, this time to my face.

events.text_segment:
It was dark now, and as we dipped under a little bridge I put my arm around Jordan’s golden shoulder and drew her toward me and asked her to dinner. Suddenly I wasn’t thinking of Daisy and Gatsby any more, but of this clean, hard, limited person, who dealt in universal scepticism, and who leaned back jauntily just within the circle of my arm. A phrase began to beat in my ears with a sort of heady excitement: “There are only the pursued, the pursuing, the busy, and the tired.”
“And Daisy ought to have something in her life,” murmured Jordan to me.
“Does she want to see Gatsby?”
“She’s not to know about it. Gatsby doesn’t want her to know. You’re just supposed to invite her to tea.”
We passed a barrier of dark trees, and then the façade of Fifty-Ninth Street, a block of delicate pale light, beamed down into the park. Unlike Gatsby and Tom Buchanan, I had no girl whose disembodied face floated along the dark cornices and blinding signs, and so I drew up the girl beside me, tightening my arms. Her wan, scornful mouth smiled, and so I drew her up again closer, this time to my face.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: It was dark now, and as we dipped under a little bridge I put my arm around Jordan’s golden shoulder and drew her toward me and asked her to dinner. I felt an endless number of small shops at which I might have engaged two tables, all buzzing with blondes and enthusiasm, but I hadn’t the faintest idea what Jordan and I were going to eat. I would have to ask her. Still—I was making a short list of those who invited themselves to Gatsby’s shindigs—who lived in both worlds, the demimonde and the squalid aristocracy. That was Jordan. There are only the pursued, the pursuing, the busy, and the tired. As Jordan and I walked out the door, she said, “Daisy ought to have something in her life.” “Does she want to see Gatsby?” “She wants to see him, but she doesn’t know it. She thinks I’m just here with you.” “So I’m to be the man who brought them together?” “No. You see, it’s a surprise. You’re to invite her to tea.” “To tea?” “Yes. Just tea. And don’t tell her about Gatsby. It’s a surprise.” “All right.” We were in a taxi now, and as we passed the illuminated façade of Fifty-Ninth Street, I thought of Gatsby and Tom. Unlike them, I had no idealized, disembodied female face haunting my thoughts. I was drawn to Jordan, to her clean, hard, limited face, to her universal scepticism, to the way she leaned back within my embrace. Her faint, wan, scornful smile, which I had noticed before, was there again. I tightened my arm. I drew her closer, and my face was near hers as the taxi sped on.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: It was dark now, and as we dipped under a little bridge I put my arm around Jordan’s golden shoulder and drew her toward me and asked her to dinner. A breeze blew through the open car, carrying the scent of honeysuckle and the distant murmur of the city. She leaned against me, her cheek cool against my jacket, and murmured, 'Anywhere.' The car sped on, the headlights cutting tunnels through the deepening twilight. We didn't talk much, the silence between us comfortable, charged with a quiet understanding that had grown between us over the summer. The world outside the car windows blurred into streaks of light and shadow – the dark shapes of trees, the occasional gleam of water, the scattered lights of houses. I felt a sense of peace, a temporary escape from the frantic energy and underlying tension that seemed to permeate everything else in my life, especially the tangled affairs of Gatsby and the Buchanans. Jordan's presence was calming, her cool detachment a contrast to the emotional turmoil I had witnessed and been drawn into. We drove towards the city, the promise of dinner and the evening stretching out before us, a simple, uncomplicated pleasure in a world that felt increasingly complex and uncertain. The air grew cooler as we approached the river, the city skyline beginning to rise like a jagged crown against the bruised purple sky. It felt good to be moving, to be leaving the oppressive atmosphere of West Egg behind, even just for a few hours. I tightened my arm around her, feeling the slight weight of her head on my shoulder, and for a moment, everything felt right.

events.title: Gatsby's Proposition and Tea Arrangement
detailed_summary: Nick arrives home late to find Gatsby's entire mansion inexplicably illuminated.
Initially thinking it's another party, Nick realizes the house is silent except for the wind.
Gatsby approaches Nick across the lawn.
Nick comments on the house looking like the World's Fair.
Gatsby deflects, suggesting trips to Coney Island or his pool, which Nick declines due to the late hour.
Gatsby waits with barely concealed anticipation.
Nick confirms he has spoken to Jordan Baker and will invite Daisy for tea.
Gatsby feigns nonchalance, insisting Nick shouldn't be troubled.
They awkwardly negotiate a suitable day, with Gatsby expressing concern about the state of Nick's lawn.
Gatsby hesitantly brings up another matter, ascertaining Nick's modest income.
He vaguely offers Nick a chance to make money through a confidential 'side line' business, implicitly connected to his association with Wolfshiem.
Nick firmly refuses the offer, stating he is too busy, understanding it's likely a thinly veiled payment for arranging the tea.
Gatsby seems disappointed but accepts the refusal and returns home.
Nick reflects on the evening and prepares for bed, unsure of Gatsby's subsequent actions.

events.text_segment:
When I came home to West Egg that night I was afraid for a moment that my house was on fire. Two o’clock and the whole corner of the peninsula was blazing with light, which fell unreal on the shrubbery and made thin elongating glints upon the roadside wires. Turning a corner, I saw that it was Gatsby’s house, lit from tower to cellar.
At first I thought it was another party, a wild rout that had resolved itself into “hide-and-go-seek” or “sardines-in-the-box” with all the house thrown open to the game. But there wasn’t a sound. Only wind in the trees, which blew the wires and made the lights go off and on again as if the house had winked into the darkness. As my taxi groaned away I saw Gatsby walking toward me across his lawn.
“Your place looks like the World’s Fair,” I said.
“Does it?” He turned his eyes toward it absently. “I have been glancing into some of the rooms. Let’s go to Coney Island, old sport. In my car.”
“It’s too late.”
“Well, suppose we take a plunge in the swimming pool? I haven’t made use of it all summer.”
“I’ve got to go to bed.”
“All right.”
He waited, looking at me with suppressed eagerness.
“I talked with Miss Baker,” I said after a moment. “I’m going to call up Daisy tomorrow and invite her over here to tea.”
“Oh, that’s all right,” he said carelessly. “I don’t want to put you to any trouble.”
“What day would suit you?”
“What day would suit you?” he corrected me quickly. “I don’t want to put you to any trouble, you see.”
“How about the day after tomorrow?”
He considered for a moment. Then, with reluctance: “I want to get the grass cut,” he said.
We both looked down at the grass—there was a sharp line where my ragged lawn ended and the darker, well-kept expanse of his began. I suspected that he meant my grass.
“There’s another little thing,” he said uncertainly, and hesitated.
“Would you rather put it off for a few days?” I asked.
“Oh, it isn’t about that. At least—” He fumbled with a series of beginnings. “Why, I thought—why, look here, old sport, you don’t make much money, do you?”
“Not very much.”
This seemed to reassure him and he continued more confidently.
“I thought you didn’t, if you’ll pardon my—you see, I carry on a little business on the side, a sort of side line, you understand. And I thought that if you don’t make very much—You’re selling bonds, aren’t you, old sport?”
“Trying to.”
“Well, this would interest you. It wouldn’t take up much of your time and you might pick up a nice bit of money. It happens to be a rather confidential sort of thing.”
I realize now that under different circumstances that conversation might have been one of the crises of my life. But, because the offer was obviously and tactlessly for a service to be rendered, I had no choice except to cut him off there.
“I’ve got my hands full,” I said. “I’m much obliged but I couldn’t take on any more work.”
“You wouldn’t have to do any business with Wolfshiem.” Evidently he thought that I was shying away from the “gonnegtion” mentioned at lunch, but I assured him he was wrong. He waited a moment longer, hoping I’d begin a conversation, but I was too absorbed to be responsive, so he went unwillingly home.
The evening had made me lightheaded and happy; I think I walked into a deep sleep as I entered my front door. So I don’t know whether or not Gatsby went to Coney Island, or for how many hours he “glanced into rooms” while his house blazed gaudily on.

events.title: Anxious Preparations and Waiting
detailed_summary: The next morning, Nick calls Daisy from his office and invites her to tea, specifically telling her not to bring Tom.
Daisy pretends not to know who Tom is.
The agreed-upon day arrives with heavy rain.
Gatsby sends a man to mow Nick's lawn despite the downpour.
Nick realizes he forgot to arrange for his maid and drives to the village to find her and buy supplies.
Gatsby sends an enormous quantity of flowers, filling Nick's house.
An hour before the appointed time, Gatsby arrives, dressed impeccably but looking pale and sleep-deprived.
He nervously asks if everything is satisfactory, initially seeming confused about Nick's comment regarding the lawn.
Gatsby vaguely comments on the weather forecast and inquires about the tea arrangements.
Nick shows him the pantry and the lemon cakes; Gatsby approves faintly.
As the rain lessens slightly, Gatsby waits, looking distractedly through a book, startled by noises, and frequently glancing out the window.
He becomes increasingly agitated, checking his watch and declaring that Daisy isn't coming because it's too late.
Nick reassures him it's only two minutes before the hour.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I called up Daisy from the office next morning, and invited her to come to tea.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Don’t be silly; it’s just two minutes to four.”

events.text_segment:
I called up Daisy from the office next morning, and invited her to come to tea.
“Don’t bring Tom,” I warned her.
“What?”
“Don’t bring Tom.”
“Who is ‘Tom’?” she asked innocently.
The day agreed upon was pouring rain. At eleven o’clock a man in a raincoat, dragging a lawn-mower, tapped at my front door and said that Mr. Gatsby had sent him over to cut my grass. This reminded me that I had forgotten to tell my Finn to come back, so I drove into West Egg Village to search for her among soggy whitewashed alleys and to buy some cups and lemons and flowers.
The flowers were unnecessary, for at two o’clock a greenhouse arrived from Gatsby’s, with innumerable receptacles to contain it. An hour later the front door opened nervously, and Gatsby in a white flannel suit, silver shirt, and gold-coloured tie, hurried in. He was pale, and there were dark signs of sleeplessness beneath his eyes.
“Is everything all right?” he asked immediately.
“The grass looks fine, if that’s what you mean.”
“What grass?” he inquired blankly. “Oh, the grass in the yard.” He looked out the window at it, but, judging from his expression, I don’t believe he saw a thing.
“Looks very good,” he remarked vaguely. “One of the papers said they thought the rain would stop about four. I think it was The Journal. Have you got everything you need in the shape of—of tea?”
I took him into the pantry, where he looked a little reproachfully at the Finn. Together we scrutinized the twelve lemon cakes from the delicatessen shop.
“Will they do?” I asked.
“Of course, of course! They’re fine!” and he added hollowly, “… old sport.”
The rain cooled about half-past three to a damp mist, through which occasional thin drops swam like dew. Gatsby looked with vacant eyes through a copy of Clay’s Economics, starting at the Finnish tread that shook the kitchen floor, and peering towards the bleared windows from time to time as if a series of invisible but alarming happenings were taking place outside. Finally he got up and informed me, in an uncertain voice, that he was going home.
“Why’s that?”
“Nobody’s coming to tea. It’s too late!” He looked at his watch as if there was some pressing demand on his time elsewhere. “I can’t wait all day.”
“Don’t be silly; it’s just two minutes to four.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I called up Daisy from the office next morning, and invited her to come to tea. "Don't bring Tom," I warned her. "What in the name of Heaven is the matter?" she asked blankly. "Do you mean to say you're in love with me," and she laughed. I told her how I had heard about a man who lived in a house with a tower, which from the road looked like a Church, and she said, "That's Gatsby's house." So I explained that I'd heard she was coming to a tea at my house. "Of course I'm coming," she said. "But I can't wait all day." The day agreed upon was pouring rain. At eleven o'clock a man in a raincoat, dragging a lawn-mower, came plodding up the drive. He turned out to be Gatsby's gardener, come to cut my grass. "I'm afraid the rain's going to spoil it for you," I said. "Oh, it don't matter," he said. "I've got a machine that does the work of about a dozen men." As he went off, muttering to himself, I realized that I had forgotten to arrange for my Finn. 2. MISSING ELEMENTS:

- The final exchange about Gatsby wanting to leave and the reassurance about the time is not present.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:

events.title: Daisy's Arrival and Excruciating Reunion
detailed_summary: Gatsby sits down miserably just as a car is heard arriving.
Both Nick and Gatsby jump up nervously; Nick goes outside to greet the visitor.
Daisy arrives in a large open car, her face bright and smiling beneath a lavender hat.
Her voice captivates Nick as she confirms the location.
Nick helps her from the car; she playfully asks if Nick is in love with her or why she had to come alone.
Nick instructs her chauffeur, Ferdie, to return in an hour.
They enter the house, and Nick is shocked to find the living room empty.
As Daisy questions the emptiness, there is a knock at the front door.
Nick opens it to find Gatsby, deathly pale and standing in a puddle, staring intensely.
Gatsby walks stiffly past Nick into the hall and disappears into the living room without a word.
Nick closes the door against the rain, aware of his own racing heart.
After a moment of silence, Nick hears muffled sounds and Daisy's artificially bright voice greeting Gatsby.
An awkward pause follows; Nick enters the living room.
Gatsby is leaning against the mantelpiece, attempting to appear casual but clearly strained, staring at Daisy.
Daisy sits nervously on the edge of a chair.
Gatsby mutters that they have met before.
He almost knocks over the mantelpiece clock, catching it with trembling hands.
He sits down rigidly, apologizing for the clock.
Nick feels intensely awkward and comments inanely about the clock's age.
Daisy states matter-of-factly that they haven't met in years; Gatsby automatically corrects her: 'Five years next November'.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The automatic quality of Gatsby’s answer set us all back at least another minute.

events.text_segment:
He sat down miserably, as if I had pushed him, and simultaneously there was the sound of a motor turning into my lane. We both jumped up, and, a little harrowed myself, I went out into the yard.
Under the dripping bare lilac-trees a large open car was coming up the drive. It stopped. Daisy’s face, tipped sideways beneath a three-cornered lavender hat, looked out at me with a bright ecstatic smile.
“Is this absolutely where you live, my dearest one?”
The exhilarating ripple of her voice was a wild tonic in the rain. I had to follow the sound of it for a moment, up and down, with my ear alone, before any words came through. A damp streak of hair lay like a dash of blue paint across her cheek, and her hand was wet with glistening drops as I took it to help her from the car.
“Are you in love with me,” she said low in my ear, “or why did I have to come alone?”
“That’s the secret of Castle Rackrent. Tell your chauffeur to go far away and spend an hour.”
“Come back in an hour, Ferdie.” Then in a grave murmur: “His name is Ferdie.”
“Does the gasoline affect his nose?”
“I don’t think so,” she said innocently. “Why?”
We went in. To my overwhelming surprise the living-room was deserted.
“Well, that’s funny,” I exclaimed.
“What’s funny?”
She turned her head as there was a light dignified knocking at the front door. I went out and opened it. Gatsby, pale as death, with his hands plunged like weights in his coat pockets, was standing in a puddle of water glaring tragically into my eyes.
With his hands still in his coat pockets he stalked by me into the hall, turned sharply as if he were on a wire, and disappeared into the living-room. It wasn’t a bit funny. Aware of the loud beating of my own heart I pulled the door to against the increasing rain.
For half a minute there wasn’t a sound. Then from the living-room I heard a sort of choking murmur and part of a laugh, followed by Daisy’s voice on a clear artificial note:
“I certainly am awfully glad to see you again.”
A pause; it endured horribly. I had nothing to do in the hall, so I went into the room.
Gatsby, his hands still in his pockets, was reclining against the mantelpiece in a strained counterfeit of perfect ease, even of boredom. His head leaned back so far that it rested against the face of a defunct mantelpiece clock, and from this position his distraught eyes stared down at Daisy, who was sitting, frightened but graceful, on the edge of a stiff chair.
“We’ve met before,” muttered Gatsby. His eyes glanced momentarily at me, and his lips parted with an abortive attempt at a laugh. Luckily the clock took this moment to tilt dangerously at the pressure of his head, whereupon he turned and caught it with trembling fingers, and set it back in place. Then he sat down, rigidly, his elbow on the arm of the sofa and his chin in his hand.
“I’m sorry about the clock,” he said.
My own face had now assumed a deep tropical burn. I couldn’t muster up a single commonplace out of the thousand in my head.
“It’s an old clock,” I told them idiotically.
I think we all believed for a moment that it had smashed in pieces on the floor.
“We haven’t met for many years,” said Daisy, her voice as matter-of-fact as it could ever be.
“Five years next November.”
The automatic quality of Gatsby’s answer set us all back at least another minute.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: He sat down miserably, as if I had pushed him, and simultaneously there was the sound of a motor turning into my lane. We both jumped up and started for the front door, but I got there first and he waited in the living-room—disappearing, I was surprised to see, by the kitchen route. I went out to the open car. Daisy sat in it, glowing and fresh, her face a bright ecstatic smile, her voice the smile of an angel that floated over the most first-aid of all the poor ghosts in the world. 'Well, she inquired in a bright, thrilling voice, 'is that Nick?' I laughed. 'I can't believe it,' she whispered. 'I don't believe it's that man.' I helped her from the car. 'You dream, you,' she said, shaking her head. 'You absolute little dream.' When she got to the steps she stopped and looked around. 'Where's Gatsby?' she said suddenly. 'I thought he'd be here.' 'He is,' I said, as she went inside. 'Just a minute.' I followed her at once. I told her chauffeur to go away and he drove off. And then I went back inside. I was surprised to see that the living-room was empty. 'Well, this is a surprise,' she said. 'Where's Gatsby?' 'He's here,' I said. 'He's just—' The front door opened and Gatsby came in. He was deathly pale, and there were dark signs of sleeplessness beneath his eyes. 'Is this the man?' she asked. 'It is,' I said. 'He's just—' Gatsby walked stiffly past me into the hall and disappeared into the living-room without a word. I closed the door against the rain and stood there for a moment, my heart pounding. After a moment of silence, I heard a muffled sound, and then Daisy's voice, artificially bright, 'Well, I'm glad to see you, Mr. Gatsby.' An awkward pause followed. I went into the living-room. Gatsby was leaning against the mantelpiece in a strained, unnatural way, as if he were trying to appear casual. He was staring at Daisy, who was sitting on the edge of a chair, her hands clasped in her lap. 'We've met before,' he muttered. He almost knocked over the mantelpiece clock, but caught it with trembling hands. 'I'm sorry,' he said. 'I'm afraid I've been a little—' He sat down rigidly. 'I'm sorry about the clock,' he said. 'It's an old clock,' I said. 'It's been there for years.' 'We haven't met for years,' she said matter-of-factly. 'Five years next November,' Gatsby corrected her automatically.
