events.title: Luncheon Tension Culminates in a Trip to Town
detailed_summary: Gatsby nervously sips his drink.
Tom makes small talk about the weather and shows Gatsby the estate.
Gatsby points out his own house across the bay.
They have lunch in a darkened dining room, the mood strained despite attempts at gaiety.
Daisy despairs about the heat and the future, impulsively suggesting they all go to town.
While Tom talks to Gatsby about converting a garage, Daisy pointedly tells Gatsby he looks cool.
Daisy and Gatsby share an intense, exclusive gaze, which Tom observes.
Tom, visibly shocked and angered by the intimacy he witnessed, abruptly agrees to go to town.
Tom's agitation grows as he tries to hurry everyone along.
Daisy resists being rushed, asking for time for a cigarette, but Tom insists.
Daisy and Jordan go upstairs to prepare, leaving the men awkwardly waiting outside.
Gatsby attempts small talk with Tom about the stables.
Tom vents frustration about women's 'notions'.
Daisy calls down about drinks, and Tom goes inside to get whiskey.
Gatsby confides in Nick that he feels constrained in Tom's house.
Nick remarks on Daisy's indiscreet voice.
Gatsby suddenly declares her voice is 'full of money,' an insight Nick finds illuminating.
Tom returns with whiskey, followed by Daisy and Jordan dressed for the city.
Gatsby suggests taking his car, but Tom insists they swap cars, proposing he drive Gatsby's yellow car and Gatsby drive his coupé.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Gatsby took up his drink.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Well, you take my coupé and let me drive your car to town.”

events.text_segment:
Gatsby took up his drink.
“They certainly look cool,” he said, with visible tension.
We drank in long, greedy swallows.
“I read somewhere that the sun’s getting hotter every year,” said Tom genially. “It seems that pretty soon the earth’s going to fall into the sun—or wait a minute—it’s just the opposite—the sun’s getting colder every year.
“Come outside,” he suggested to Gatsby, “I’d like you to have a look at the place.”
I went with them out to the veranda. On the green Sound, stagnant in the heat, one small sail crawled slowly toward the fresher sea. Gatsby’s eyes followed it momentarily; he raised his hand and pointed across the bay.
“I’m right across from you.”
“So you are.”
Our eyes lifted over the rose-beds and the hot lawn and the weedy refuse of the dog-days alongshore. Slowly the white wings of the boat moved against the blue cool limit of the sky. Ahead lay the scalloped ocean and the abounding blessed isles.
“There’s sport for you,” said Tom, nodding. “I’d like to be out there with him for about an hour.”
We had luncheon in the dining-room, darkened too against the heat, and drank down nervous gaiety with the cold ale.
“What’ll we do with ourselves this afternoon?” cried Daisy, “and the day after that, and the next thirty years?”
“Don’t be morbid,” Jordan said. “Life starts all over again when it gets crisp in the fall.”
“But it’s so hot,” insisted Daisy, on the verge of tears, “and everything’s so confused. Let’s all go to town!”
Her voice struggled on through the heat, beating against it, moulding its senselessness into forms.
“I’ve heard of making a garage out of a stable,” Tom was saying to Gatsby, “but I’m the first man who ever made a stable out of a garage.”
“Who wants to go to town?” demanded Daisy insistently. Gatsby’s eyes floated toward her. “Ah,” she cried, “you look so cool.”
Their eyes met, and they stared together at each other, alone in space. With an effort she glanced down at the table.
“You always look so cool,” she repeated.
She had told him that she loved him, and Tom Buchanan saw. He was astounded. His mouth opened a little, and he looked at Gatsby, and then back at Daisy as if he had just recognized her as someone he knew a long time ago.
“You resemble the advertisement of the man,” she went on innocently. “You know the advertisement of the man—”
“All right,” broke in Tom quickly, “I’m perfectly willing to go to town. Come on—we’re all going to town.”
He got up, his eyes still flashing between Gatsby and his wife. No one moved.
“Come on!” His temper cracked a little. “What’s the matter, anyhow? If we’re going to town, let’s start.”
His hand, trembling with his effort at self-control, bore to his lips the last of his glass of ale. Daisy’s voice got us to our feet and out on to the blazing gravel drive.
“Are we just going to go?” she objected. “Like this? Aren’t we going to let anyone smoke a cigarette first?”
“Everybody smoked all through lunch.”
“Oh, let’s have fun,” she begged him. “It’s too hot to fuss.”
He didn’t answer.
“Have it your own way,” she said. “Come on, Jordan.”
They went upstairs to get ready while we three men stood there shuffling the hot pebbles with our feet. A silver curve of the moon hovered already in the western sky. Gatsby started to speak, changed his mind, but not before Tom wheeled and faced him expectantly.
“Have you got your stables here?” asked Gatsby with an effort.
“About a quarter of a mile down the road.”
“Oh.”
A pause.
“I don’t see the idea of going to town,” broke out Tom savagely. “Women get these notions in their heads—”
“Shall we take anything to drink?” called Daisy from an upper window.
“I’ll get some whisky,” answered Tom. He went inside.
Gatsby turned to me rigidly:
“I can’t say anything in his house, old sport.”
“She’s got an indiscreet voice,” I remarked. “It’s full of—” I hesitated.
“Her voice is full of money,” he said suddenly.
That was it. I’d never understood before. It was full of money—that was the inexhaustible charm that rose and fell in it, the jingle of it, the cymbals’ song of it… High in a white palace the king’s daughter, the golden girl…
Tom came out of the house wrapping a quart bottle in a towel, followed by Daisy and Jordan wearing small tight hats of metallic cloth and carrying light capes over their arms.
“Shall we all go in my car?” suggested Gatsby. He felt the hot, green leather of the seat. “I ought to have left it in the shade.”
“Is it standard shift?” demanded Tom.
“Yes.”
“Well, you take my coupé and let me drive your car to town.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Gatsby took up his drink. He held it loosely, a pale gold liquid in a fragile glass, and his eyes, which had been fixed on the distant, shimmering lights across the bay, returned slowly to the swirling chaos of his own lawn. The music, a frantic jazz, pulsed through the humid night air, mingling with the high, excited laughter of hundreds of people he barely knew. They were everywhere – spilling out of the house onto the terraces, clustered around the buffet tables laden with glistening hams and salads, dancing with a wild, careless abandon on the polished floor of the ballroom.He watched them, a solitary figure on the edge of the revelry, a host who seemed more like a spectator. There was a profound loneliness in his posture, a stillness that set him apart from the frenetic energy surrounding him. He smiled, that famous, understanding smile, at a passing group, but it didn't quite reach his eyes. They remained watchful, searching, as if looking for something – or someone – who wasn't there, or perhaps who was there but remained just out of reach.The rumors about him circulated like wildfire through the crowd. He was a German spy. He had killed a man. He was a bootlegger, a nephew of Kaiser Wilhelm, a man who had sprung from nowhere with ill-gotten gains. Each story added another layer to the enigma, another piece to the puzzle that no one could quite solve. And Gatsby, standing there with his drink, seemed to absorb it all, letting the myths build around him, perhaps even encouraging them in some silent, inscrutable way.He took a small sip of his drink, the ice clinking softly against the glass. The taste seemed distant, unimportant. His mind was elsewhere, perhaps five years in the past, perhaps just across the water. The present moment, this extravagant display of wealth and gaiety, felt like a carefully constructed stage set, beautiful and elaborate, but ultimately hollow without the presence that gave it meaning.He saw Nick Carraway making his way through the crowd, a look of bewildered fascination on his face. Nick was one of the few people here who seemed genuinely curious, genuinely trying to understand. Most others were simply there to consume, to bask in the reflected glow of Gatsby's wealth, to enjoy the free food and liquor and the intoxicating atmosphere of possibility. They were moths drawn to a flame, oblivious to the fire's true nature or the man who tended it.Gatsby nodded slightly to Nick, a silent acknowledgment across the throng. He appreciated Nick's quiet presence, his lack of judgment, his willingness to listen. Nick was a link, a bridge to a world Gatsby desperately wanted to reclaim.He turned his gaze back towards the bay, towards the faint green light that pulsed at the end of Daisy's dock. It was a tiny point of light in the vast darkness, but to Gatsby, it was everything. It was the symbol of his dream, the culmination of years of striving, of building, of waiting. Every party, every lavish expenditure, every risk he had taken – it all led back to that light, to the hope of recapturing a moment in time, of erasing the past five years and starting over.The music swelled, a saxophone wailing a mournful, bluesy tune beneath the frantic rhythm. Couples spun past, their faces flushed with alcohol and excitement. A woman shrieked with laughter as she stumbled, caught by her partner. The air was thick with the scent of perfume, alcohol, and the damp earth of the garden.Gatsby finished his drink and set the glass down on a nearby table. He felt a familiar ache in his chest, a longing so profound it was almost physical. He had built this empire, this monument to his love, and yet, the object of his devotion remained elusive, separated by a gulf of time and circumstance.He straightened his tie, a gesture of quiet determination. He would not give up. He could not give up. The dream was too real, too vivid in his mind. He had come too far to fail now. He had transformed himself, shedding his past like an old skin, reinventing himself as Jay Gatsby, the man who could achieve anything. And achieving his dream meant winning back Daisy.He began to move through the crowd, a polite smile fixed on his face, exchanging brief pleasantries, nodding to acquaintances. He moved with a certain grace, a quiet confidence that belied the turmoil within him. He was the perfect host, attentive and charming, making sure everyone was enjoying themselves, even as his own thoughts were miles away, across the water, in a house with a green light.He saw Daisy and Tom Buchanan arrive, their presence creating a subtle ripple through the crowd. Daisy, radiant and fragile, clinging to Tom's arm. Tom, solid and imposing, his eyes scanning the room with a proprietary air. Gatsby's heart gave a lurch. This was it. The moment he had been waiting for, preparing for, for so long.He watched them for a moment, a complex mixture of emotions playing across his face – hope, anxiety, a fierce protectiveness. He had to be careful. He had to play this right. Everything depended on it.He took a deep breath and began to walk towards them, a smile that was both genuine and carefully constructed on his lips. The music seemed to fade into the background, the noise of the party receding. All that mattered was Daisy. All that mattered was the dream.He reached them, his hand extended, his voice calm and steady. "Hello, Daisy."Her eyes widened slightly, a flicker of surprise, then recognition. Tom's expression remained unreadable, a watchful intensity in his gaze.The conversation that followed was stilted, awkward, charged with unspoken history and tension. Gatsby tried to maintain his composure, to project an air of effortless charm, but he could feel the tremor in his hands, the pounding of his heart. This was not how he had imagined it. The reality was messier, more complicated than the perfect scenarios he had played out in his mind.He offered them drinks, introduced them to a few people, tried to draw Daisy into conversation. But she seemed hesitant, nervous, caught between the past and the present, between Gatsby and Tom. Tom, meanwhile, watched Gatsby with a thinly veiled suspicion, his questions pointed, his demeanor challenging.Gatsby felt the carefully constructed facade begin to crack. The dream, so vivid and tangible just moments before, seemed to recede, becoming once again a distant, unattainable light. He had built this entire world for her, and yet, here she was, standing beside the man who represented everything he despised, everything he was trying to escape.He excused himself briefly, needing a moment to compose himself. He walked away from the crowd, towards the quieter part of the garden, the cool night air a welcome relief against his flushed face. He looked back at the house, at the dazzling lights and the swirling figures within. It all felt like a mirage, beautiful but insubstantial.He had believed so implicitly in the power of his dream, in the idea that he could simply recreate the past through sheer force of will and wealth. But standing there, alone in the garden, he felt the weight of reality pressing down on him. The past was not something you could simply step back into. It was gone, irrevocably altered by time and experience.He heard footsteps behind him and turned to see Nick approaching. Nick's presence was a comfort, a reminder of the outside world, the world beyond the gilded cage of Gatsby's mansion. "Everything alright, Gatsby?" Nick asked, his voice quiet.Gatsby forced a smile. "Yes, old sport. Just... taking a moment."He looked back at the house, at the distant figure of Daisy, still standing with Tom. The green light across the bay seemed dimmer now, less significant. The dream felt fragile, threatened by the harsh light of day, or rather, the harsh reality of the night.He knew, with a sudden, chilling certainty, that this was not going to be easy. The path to his dream was not a straight line, but a tangled, treacherous maze. And he was not sure he had the strength to navigate it. But he had to try. He had to keep fighting. For Daisy. For the dream. For everything he had built.He turned back to Nick, his smile fading, replaced by a look of quiet desperation. "It's... it's going to be alright," he said, but his voice lacked conviction. He picked up his drink again, the ice long melted, the liquid warm and flat. He raised it slightly, not in a toast, but in a gesture of weary resignation. The party raged on around him, oblivious to the quiet battle being fought within the heart of its host. The night was still young, but the weight of years felt heavy on Gatsby's shoulders. The dream was still alive, but its light seemed to flicker, threatened by the encroaching darkness of reality. He took a sip, the taste bitter on his tongue. The long vigil had begun.

Gatsby took up his drink. “They certainly look cool,” he remarked, as soon as the question of the weather was disposed of. “Unlike a lot of these newly rich people you see to-day. I know your family.”
“I don’t think I ever met your father.”
“No.” He hesitated. “My father’s dead.” After a pause he added, “My whole family’s dead.”
“I see.”
The butler brought back a little plate of cold fried chicken and four bottles of ale. “Daisy’s home,” commented Tom. “She’s been having a swell time, wherever she’s been. I can tell when Daisy’s blue by the way she moves around. Look at the candles!”
Cold fat candles stood in hot golden candlesticks, holding up bouquets of melting flowers. “I can’t stand this heat,” cried Daisy. “Everybody we know feels the same way. Mr. Gatsby, would you like a little cold drink?”
“Thank you.”
“We can’t move,” said Daisy with a helpless little laugh. “Not always.”
Again a sort of apology arose to my lips. Almost any exhibition of complete self-sufficiency draws a stunned tribute from me.
That was the inexhaustible charm that rose and fell in it, the jingle of it, the cymbals’ song of it. . . . High in a white palace the king’s daughter, the golden girl. . . .
Tom was talking intently across the table at Gatsby, his nostrils quivering. I felt the hot, sticky night close in on them, and my own instinct was to shrink away. I waited, and sure enough, in a moment she looked at him with an absolute, unqualified devotion. Her expression was curiously familiar—it was the kind of look that passes between husband and wife, after years of marriage—and for a moment I lost sight of Jordan and Daisy and the others. But with every word she was drawing further and further into herself, so he gave that up, and only the dead dream fought on as the afternoon slipped away, trying to touch what was no longer tangible, struggling unhappily, undespairingly, toward that lost voice across the room.
The afternoon had made them tranquil for a while, as if to give them a deep breath before starting again. But now they were all restless again, and Daisy was getting ready to leave. “Are you sure you won’t come in, Tom?” she asked, as we stood on the porch. “I’m sure I won’t,” he answered shortly. “You two run along. We’ll follow in the coupé.”
She looked at him, and then at Gatsby, and then back at him, as if she had forgotten something. “Oh, all right,” she said. “Come on, Jordan.”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text:
Gatsby took up his drink. “They certainly look cool,” he remarked, as soon as the question of the weather was disposed of. “Unlike a lot of these newly rich people you see to-day. I know your family.”
“I don’t think I ever met your father.”
“No.” He hesitated. “My father’s dead.” After a pause he added, “My whole family’s dead.”
“I see.”
The butler brought back a little plate of cold fried chicken and four bottles of ale. “Daisy’s home,” commented Tom. “She’s been having a swell time, wherever she’s been. I can tell when Daisy’s blue by the way she moves around. Look at the candles!”
Cold fat candles stood in hot golden candlesticks, holding up bouquets of melting flowers. “I can’t stand this heat,” cried Daisy. “Everybody we know feels the same way. Mr. Gatsby, would you like a little cold drink?”
“Thank you.”
“We can’t move,” said Daisy with a helpless little laugh. “Not always.”
Again a sort of apology arose to my lips. Almost any exhibition of complete self-sufficiency draws a stunned tribute from me.
That was the inexhaustible charm that rose and fell in it, the jingle of it, the cymbals’ song of it. . . . High in a white palace the king’s daughter, the golden girl. . . .
Tom was talking intently across the table at Gatsby, his nostrils quivering. I felt the hot, sticky night close in on them, and my own instinct was to shrink away. I waited, and sure enough, in a moment she looked at him with an absolute, unqualified devotion. Her expression was curiously familiar—it was the kind of look that passes between husband and wife, after years of marriage—and for a moment I lost sight of Jordan and Daisy and the others. But with every word she was drawing further and further into herself, so he gave that up, and only the dead dream fought on as the afternoon slipped away, trying to touch what was no longer tangible, struggling unhappily, undespairingly, toward that lost voice across the room.
The afternoon had made them tranquil for a while, as if to give them a deep breath before starting again. But now they were all restless again, and Daisy was getting ready to leave. “Are you sure you won’t come in, Tom?” she asked, as we stood on the porch. “I’m sure I won’t,” he answered shortly. “You two run along. We’ll follow in the coupé.”
She looked at him, and then at Gatsby, and then back at him, as if she had forgotten something. “Oh, all right,” she said. “Come on, Jordan.”
They went inside. Tom and Gatsby stood side by side on the porch, looking out at the hot, damp night. “I suppose you’ve got to make your house into a garage, after all,” said Tom. “Or else tear it down.”
“I’ve got it all planned,” answered Gatsby. “I’m going to have a garage, and a stable, and a swimming-pool, and a private beach.”
“That’s a lot of stuff,” said Tom. “I don’t see how you’re going to get it all in.”
“I’ve got it all planned,” repeated Gatsby. “I’m going to have a garage, and a stable, and a swimming-pool, and a private beach.”
“That’s a lot of stuff,” said Tom. “I don’t see how you’re going to get it all in.”

events.title: Tom Reveals Suspicions Driving Gatsby's Car
detailed_summary: Gatsby reluctantly agrees to Tom's car swap proposal after a weak objection about gas.
Tom makes a pointed remark about being able to buy anything at drugstores nowadays, which causes Gatsby visible unease.
Tom directs Daisy towards Gatsby's car, calling it a 'circus wagon'.
Daisy refuses, deciding to ride with Gatsby in Tom's coupé.
Tom, Jordan, and Nick get into Gatsby's yellow car, and Tom drives off quickly.
Tom immediately confronts Nick and Jordan, realizing they knew about Daisy and Gatsby.
Tom defensively claims to have 'second sight' and reveals he has been investigating Gatsby's past.
Jordan mocks Tom's claim of investigation.
Tom scoffs at the idea of Gatsby being an 'Oxford man,' pointing to his pink suit as evidence against it.
Jordan insists Gatsby did attend Oxford.
Tom dismisses it as perhaps a different Oxford.
Jordan questions Tom's snobbery, asking why he invited Gatsby if he disapproves.
Tom reveals Daisy invited Gatsby, mentioning she knew him before their marriage.
The group grows irritable and rides in silence.

events.text_segment:
The suggestion was distasteful to Gatsby.
“I don’t think there’s much gas,” he objected.
“Plenty of gas,” said Tom boisterously. He looked at the gauge. “And if it runs out I can stop at a drugstore. You can buy anything at a drugstore nowadays.”
A pause followed this apparently pointless remark. Daisy looked at Tom frowning, and an indefinable expression, at once definitely unfamiliar and vaguely recognizable, as if I had only heard it described in words, passed over Gatsby’s face.
“Come on, Daisy,” said Tom, pressing her with his hand toward Gatsby’s car. “I’ll take you in this circus wagon.”
He opened the door, but she moved out from the circle of his arm.
“You take Nick and Jordan. We’ll follow you in the coupé.”
She walked close to Gatsby, touching his coat with her hand. Jordan and Tom and I got into the front seat of Gatsby’s car, Tom pushed the unfamiliar gears tentatively, and we shot off into the oppressive heat, leaving them out of sight behind.
“Did you see that?” demanded Tom.
“See what?”
He looked at me keenly, realizing that Jordan and I must have known all along.
“You think I’m pretty dumb, don’t you?” he suggested. “Perhaps I am, but I have a—almost a second sight, sometimes, that tells me what to do. Maybe you don’t believe that, but science—”
He paused. The immediate contingency overtook him, pulled him back from the edge of theoretical abyss.
“I’ve made a small investigation of this fellow,” he continued. “I could have gone deeper if I’d known—”
“Do you mean you’ve been to a medium?” inquired Jordan humorously.
“What?” Confused, he stared at us as we laughed. “A medium?”
“About Gatsby.”
“About Gatsby! No, I haven’t. I said I’d been making a small investigation of his past.”
“And you found he was an Oxford man,” said Jordan helpfully.
“An Oxford man!” He was incredulous. “Like hell he is! He wears a pink suit.”
“Nevertheless he’s an Oxford man.”
“Oxford, New Mexico,” snorted Tom contemptuously, “or something like that.”
“Listen, Tom. If you’re such a snob, why did you invite him to lunch?” demanded Jordan crossly.
“Daisy invited him; she knew him before we were married—God knows where!”
We were all irritable now with the fading ale, and aware of it we drove for a while in silence.

events.title: Confrontation and Revelation at Wilson's Garage
detailed_summary: Approaching the valley of ashes, Nick remembers Gatsby's comment about gas.
Tom dismisses concerns about fuel but Jordan insists they stop at Wilson's garage due to the heat.
Tom brakes abruptly at the garage.
Wilson emerges looking ill and weak.
Tom impatiently demands gas.
Wilson explains he's been sick all day and needs money badly, inquiring about buying Tom's old car.
Wilson mentions his plan to take his wife and move West.
Tom is startled to hear Myrtle wants to go West.
Wilson reveals he is forcing Myrtle to leave, having 'wised up to something funny' recently, implying knowledge of her affair.
As Gatsby's coupé (carrying Gatsby and Daisy) drives past, Myrtle looks down from an upper window.
Nick observes Myrtle's face contort with jealous rage, realizing she assumes Jordan, riding with Tom, is Daisy.
Nick reflects on the parallel discoveries of infidelity made by Tom and Wilson, noting the profound difference sickness makes.
Tom promises to send his old car over to Wilson the next day.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then as Doctor T. J. Eckleburg’s faded eyes came into sight down the road, I remembered Gatsby’s caution about gasoline.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I’ll let you have that car,” said Tom.

events.text_segment:
Then as Doctor T. J. Eckleburg’s faded eyes came into sight down the road, I remembered Gatsby’s caution about gasoline.
“We’ve got enough to get us to town,” said Tom.
“But there’s a garage right here,” objected Jordan. “I don’t want to get stalled in this baking heat.”
Tom threw on both brakes impatiently, and we slid to an abrupt dusty stop under Wilson’s sign. After a moment the proprietor emerged from the interior of his establishment and gazed hollow-eyed at the car.
“Let’s have some gas!” cried Tom roughly. “What do you think we stopped for—to admire the view?”
“I’m sick,” said Wilson without moving. “Been sick all day.”
“What’s the matter?”
“I’m all run down.”
“Well, shall I help myself?” Tom demanded. “You sounded well enough on the phone.”
With an effort Wilson left the shade and support of the doorway and, breathing hard, unscrewed the cap of the tank. In the sunlight his face was green.
“I didn’t mean to interrupt your lunch,” he said. “But I need money pretty bad, and I was wondering what you were going to do with your old car.”
“How do you like this one?” inquired Tom. “I bought it last week.”
“It’s a nice yellow one,” said Wilson, as he strained at the handle.
“Like to buy it?”
“Big chance,” Wilson smiled faintly. “No, but I could make some money on the other.”
“What do you want money for, all of a sudden?”
“I’ve been here too long. I want to get away. My wife and I want to go West.”
“Your wife does,” exclaimed Tom, startled.
“She’s been talking about it for ten years.” He rested for a moment against the pump, shading his eyes. “And now she’s going whether she wants to or not. I’m going to get her away.”
The coupé flashed by us with a flurry of dust and the flash of a waving hand.
“What do I owe you?” demanded Tom harshly.
“I just got wised up to something funny the last two days,” remarked Wilson. “That’s why I want to get away. That’s why I been bothering you about the car.”
“What do I owe you?”
“Dollar twenty.”
The relentless beating heat was beginning to confuse me and I had a bad moment there before I realized that so far his suspicions hadn’t alighted on Tom. He had discovered that Myrtle had some sort of life apart from him in another world, and the shock had made him physically sick. I stared at him and then at Tom, who had made a parallel discovery less than an hour before—and it occurred to me that there was no difference between men, in intelligence or race, so profound as the difference between the sick and the well. Wilson was so sick that he looked guilty, unforgivably guilty—as if he had just got some poor girl with child.
“I’ll let you have that car,” said Tom.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Then as Doctor T. J. Eckleburg’s faded eyes came into sight down the road, I remembered Gatsby’s caution about gasoline. There was a long, hard day ahead and if we were to make it to the city and back, we’d need a full tank. The valley of ashes is bounded on one side by a small foul river, and when the drawbridge is up to let barges through, the traffic jams are insufferable. This was a place where ashes took the forms of houses and chimneys and rising smoke and finally, with a transcendent effort, of men who moved dimly and already crumbling through the powdery air. Occasionally a line of gray cars crawls along an invisible track, gives out a ghastly creak and comes to rest, and immediately the ash-gray men swarm up with leaden spades and stir up an impenetrable cloud, which screens their obscure operations from your sight. But above the gray land and the spasms of bleak dust which drift endlessly over it, you perceive, after a moment, the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg. The eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg are blue and gigantic—their retinas are one yard high. They look out of no face, but, instead, from a pair of enormous yellow spectacles which pass over a nonexistent nose. Evidently some wild wag of an advertising man had painted them there years ago, and then promptly sank down himself into eternal blindness, or forgot them and moved away. But his eyes, dimmed a little by many paintless days, under sun and rain, brood on over the solemn dumping ground. The only building in sight was a small block of yellow brick sitting on the edge of the waste land, with a sort of compact Main Street ministering to it, and contiguous to absolutely nothing. One of the three shops it contained was a garage—repairs. The owner was a blond, spiritless man, anaemic, and faintly handsome. When he saw us a damp gleam of hope sprang into his light blue eyes. A white ashen dust veiled his dark suit and his pale hair as it veiled everything in the vicinity—except his wife, who moved about the garage with a soft, languid (and, I thought, a perceptible) vitality. They were both in the middle thirties. George B. Wilson was his name, and he was one of the few men who had a garage on the motor-road—the only building in sight, with one exception, so long as the motor-road stretched in a thin gray line, bounded on one side by the railroad and on the other by a long stretch of dismal swamps. It was a hot day, and the air was thick with the smell of dust and gasoline. Wilson came forward, wiping his hands on a piece of cotton waste. “Hello, Wilson,” said Tom, his hand on my shoulder. “How’s business?” “I can’t complain,” answered Wilson unconvincingly. “When are you going to sell me that car?” asked Tom. “Next week; I’ve got my man working on it now,” said Wilson. “Works pretty slow, don’t he?” inquired Tom good-humoredly. “No, he doesn’t,” said Wilson quickly. “He’s an honest, hard-working man. I don’t understand why it isn’t done.” “Well, he’d better get a move on,” muttered Tom, with a glance at the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg, which had just emerged, pale and enormous, from the dissolving trees. “Come on, we’ll stop somewhere else. I’ve got to get some gas.” “I’m almost out myself,” said Wilson. “I’ve got to go to town to-morrow and get some more.” “Well, you’d better get a move on,” repeated Tom. “I’ll stop in on my way back and see how you’re getting on.” He turned to me. “Come on, Nick,” he said. “We’ll go to town.” I hesitated. “I’ve got nothing to do,” I said, “but I’d like to get some lunch.” “All right,” he said. “We’ll get some lunch in town.” He turned to Wilson. “I’ll be back,” he said. “Don’t worry about the car.” He got into the car and started the engine. Wilson stood there, looking after us, a forlorn figure in the dust. As we drove away, I saw Myrtle Wilson standing in the doorway of the garage, watching us. She had changed her dress to a dark blue crêpe-de-chine, which stretched tight over her rather wide hips as Tom helped her into the car. She had a fierce vitality that made her glow. Her face was smeared with grease and she was trying to wipe it off with a piece of cotton waste. “Hello, Myrtle,” said Tom. “How are you?” “I’m all right,” she said, her voice husky. “I’m going to town,” she added, looking at me. “I’ve got to get some things.” “All right,” said Tom. “We’ll go to town.” He started the car and we drove away, leaving Wilson standing in the dust. As we sped toward the city, the valley of ashes receded behind us, and the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg faded into the distance, still brooding over the desolate landscape.

events.title: Arrival at the Plaza and Rising Hostility
detailed_summary: Nick feels uneasy leaving the garage area, noticing the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg and recalling Myrtle watching them intensely.
Tom drives frantically towards the city, feeling his control over both Daisy and Myrtle slipping.
They catch up to Gatsby and Daisy.
Jordan suggests seeing a movie in the cool theater.
Daisy complains about the heat and suggests they separate.
Tom insists they stay together and meet at the Plaza Hotel.
Tom anxiously keeps Gatsby's car in sight, fearing they might disappear.
The group impulsively rents a stifling hotel suite at the Plaza.
Nick recalls the chaotic argument leading to this decision.
Inside the hot suite, Daisy tries to fix her hair.
Tom urges everyone to stop complaining about the heat and prepares the whiskey.
Gatsby tells Tom to leave Daisy alone, reminding him that coming to town was Tom's idea.
A tense silence follows.
Tom aggressively questions Gatsby about his catchphrase 'old sport'.
Daisy intervenes, telling Tom to stop making personal remarks and order ice.
As Tom phones for ice, Mendelssohn's Wedding March drifts up from a wedding reception downstairs.
The group reminisces about Daisy and Tom's wedding day and a guest named Biloxi.

events.text_segment:
That locality was always vaguely disquieting, even in the broad glare of afternoon, and now I turned my head as though I had been warned of something behind. Over the ash-heaps the giant eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg kept their vigil, but I perceived, after a moment, that other eyes were regarding us with peculiar intensity from less than twenty feet away.
In one of the windows over the garage the curtains had been moved aside a little, and Myrtle Wilson was peering down at the car. So engrossed was she that she had no consciousness of being observed, and one emotion after another crept into her face like objects into a slowly developing picture. Her expression was curiously familiar—it was an expression I had often seen on women’s faces, but on Myrtle Wilson’s face it seemed purposeless and inexplicable until I realized that her eyes, wide with jealous terror, were fixed not on Tom, but on Jordan Baker, whom she took to be his wife.
There is no confusion like the confusion of a simple mind, and as we drove away Tom was feeling the hot whips of panic. His wife and his mistress, until an hour ago secure and inviolate, were slipping precipitately from his control. Instinct made him step on the accelerator with the double purpose of overtaking Daisy and leaving Wilson behind, and we sped along toward Astoria at fifty miles an hour, until, among the spidery girders of the elevated, we came in sight of the easygoing blue coupé.
“Those big movies around Fiftieth Street are cool,” suggested Jordan. “I love New York on summer afternoons when everyone’s away. There’s something very sensuous about it—overripe, as if all sorts of funny fruits were going to fall into your hands.”
The word “sensuous” had the effect of further disquieting Tom, but before he could invent a protest the coupé came to a stop, and Daisy signalled us to draw up alongside.
“Where are we going?” she cried.
“How about the movies?”
“It’s so hot,” she complained. “You go. We’ll ride around and meet you after.” With an effort her wit rose faintly. “We’ll meet you on some corner. I’ll be the man smoking two cigarettes.”
“We can’t argue about it here,” Tom said impatiently, as a truck gave out a cursing whistle behind us. “You follow me to the south side of Central Park, in front of the Plaza.”
Several times he turned his head and looked back for their car, and if the traffic delayed them he slowed up until they came into sight. I think he was afraid they would dart down a side-street and out of his life forever.
But they didn’t. And we all took the less explicable step of engaging the parlour of a suite in the Plaza Hotel.
The prolonged and tumultuous argument that ended by herding us into that room eludes me, though I have a sharp physical memory that, in the course of it, my underwear kept climbing like a damp snake around my legs and intermittent beads of sweat raced cool across my back. The notion originated with Daisy’s suggestion that we hire five bathrooms and take cold baths, and then assumed more tangible form as “a place to have a mint julep.” Each of us said over and over that it was a “crazy idea”—we all talked at once to a baffled clerk and thought, or pretended to think, that we were being very funny…
The room was large and stifling, and, though it was already four o’clock, opening the windows admitted only a gust of hot shrubbery from the Park. Daisy went to the mirror and stood with her back to us, fixing her hair.
“It’s a swell suite,” whispered Jordan respectfully, and everyone laughed.
“Open another window,” commanded Daisy, without turning around.
“There aren’t any more.”
“Well, we’d better telephone for an axe—”
“The thing to do is to forget about the heat,” said Tom impatiently. “You make it ten times worse by crabbing about it.”
He unrolled the bottle of whisky from the towel and put it on the table.
“Why not let her alone, old sport?” remarked Gatsby. “You’re the one that wanted to come to town.”
There was a moment of silence. The telephone book slipped from its nail and splashed to the floor, whereupon Jordan whispered, “Excuse me”—but this time no one laughed.
“I’ll pick it up,” I offered.
“I’ve got it.” Gatsby examined the parted string, muttered “Hum!” in an interested way, and tossed the book on a chair.
“That’s a great expression of yours, isn’t it?” said Tom sharply.
“What is?”
“All this ‘old sport’ business. Where’d you pick that up?”
“Now see here, Tom,” said Daisy, turning around from the mirror, “if you’re going to make personal remarks I won’t stay here a minute. Call up and order some ice for the mint julep.”
As Tom took up the receiver the compressed heat exploded into sound and we were listening to the portentous chords of Mendelssohn’s Wedding March from the ballroom below.
“Imagine marrying anybody in this heat!” cried Jordan dismally.
“Still—I was married in the middle of June,” Daisy remembered. “Louisville in June! Somebody fainted. Who was it fainted, Tom?”
“Biloxi,” he answered shortly.
“A man named Biloxi. ‘Blocks’ Biloxi, and he made boxes—that’s a fact—and he was from Biloxi, Tennessee.”
“They carried him into my house,” appended Jordan, “because we lived just two doors from the church. And he stayed three weeks, until Daddy told him he had to get out. The day after he left Daddy died.” After a moment she added as if she might have sounded irreverent, “There wasn’t any connection.”
“I used to know a Bill Biloxi from Memphis,” I remarked.
“That was his cousin. I knew his whole family history before he left. He gave me an aluminium putter that I use today.”

'You look so cool,' she repeated. 'Tell me about the navy. We went to France, to that'—she hesitated—'that awful show at Château Thierry.' 'We saw you at the movies.' 'He looked at her now, a little preoccupied, as if he were a photographer arranging the light. The thing approached the proportions of a love affair. simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: That locality was always vaguely disquieting, even in the broad glare of afternoon, and now I turned my head as though I had been warned of something behind. About half way between West Egg and New York the motor road hastily joins the railroad and runs beside it for a quarter of a mile, so as to shrink away from a certain desolate area of land. This is a valley of ashes—a fantastic farm where ashes grow like wheat into ridges and hills and grotesque gardens; where ashes take the forms of houses and chimneys and rising smoke and finally, with a transcendent effort, of men who move dimly and already crumbling through the powdery air. Occasionally a line of gray cars crawls along an invisible track, gives out a ghastly creak and comes to rest, and immediately the ash-gray men swarm up with leaden spades and stir up an impenetrable cloud which screens their obscure operations from your sight. But above the gray land and the spasms of bleak dust which drift endlessly over it, you perceive, after a moment, the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg. The eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg are blue and gigantic—their retinas are one yard high. They look out of no face, but, instead, from a pair of enormous yellow spectacles which pass over a non-existent nose. Evidently some wild wag of an oculist set them there to fatten his practice in the borough of Queens, and then sank down himself into eternal blindness or forgot them and moved away. But his eyes, dimmed a little by many paintless days under sun and rain, brood on over the solemn dumping ground. The valley of ashes is bounded on one side by a small foul river, and, when the drawbridge is up to let a tug go through, the whole caravansary must wait for the black river to flow into the sea. This is what the valley of ashes was—a line of gray cars crawls along an invisible track, gives out a ghastly creak and comes to rest, and immediately the ash-gray men swarm up with leaden spades and stir up an impenetrable cloud which screens their obscure operations from your sight. Eckleburg are blue and gigantic—their retinas are one yard high. They look out of no face, but, instead, from a pair of enormous yellow spectacles which pass over a non-existent nose. Evidently some wild wag of an oculist set them there to fatten his practice in the borough of Queens, and then sank down himself into eternal blindness or forgot them and moved away. But his eyes, dimmed a little by many paintless days under sun and rain, brood on over the solemn dumping ground. simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.refinement_prompt:
IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion introduces a lengthy and detailed description of a location that is not present in the original passage, including invented scenes and background about the area and its features. This section is out of place and does not match the events or focus of the original excerpt.
- The completion omits the entire sequence involving the observation of Myrtle Wilson, her emotional reaction, and the mistaken identity, which is a key part of the original.
- The completion fails to include the transition from the drive to the hotel, the decision-making process about where to go, and the subsequent arrival at the hotel suite, all of which are central to the original passage.
- The completion does not include the group’s interactions in the hotel suite, the discussion about the heat, the mention of the mint julep, or the recollections about Biloxi, which are significant narrative elements in the original.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion lacks the depiction of the characters’ emotional states and interpersonal tensions, especially Tom’s panic and the shifting dynamics between the characters as they travel.
- There is no mention of the specific actions and dialogue that occur during the car journey, such as the pursuit of Daisy’s car, the traffic interactions, and Tom’s attempts to maintain control.
- The completion omits the group’s arrival at the hotel, their conversation with the clerk, and the physical discomforts experienced by the narrator.
- The completion does not include the detailed dialogue and character interactions in the hotel suite, including the discussion about the heat, the mint julep, and the humorous and tense exchanges among the group.
- The recollection about Biloxi and the related family anecdotes are entirely missing.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion presents an inaccurate sequence of events, focusing on a description of the setting rather than the character-driven narrative of the original.
- There are invented actions and dialogue, such as Daisy and Tom repeatedly debating about what to do, which do not occur in the original passage.
- The completion misattributes actions and dialogue, assigning lines and behaviors to characters that are not present in the original excerpt.
- The completion fails to accurately represent the timing and progression of events, such as the transition from the car journey to the hotel suite and the specific time of day mentioned in the original.
- The completion introduces repetitive and irrelevant dialogue that does not reflect the actual interactions or tone of the original passage.

events.title: Gatsby's Confession and Daisy's Emotional Collapse
detailed_summary: Jazz music starts playing downstairs.
Daisy laments growing old.
Tom, prompted by Jordan's mention of Biloxi, questions Gatsby about attending Oxford.
Gatsby confirms he went to Oxford briefly in 1919 as part of a post-armistice opportunity for officers.
Nick feels a renewed sense of faith in Gatsby's story.
Daisy defends Gatsby, telling Tom to make drinks and stop being 'stupid'.
Tom insists on asking Gatsby one more question, directly confronting him about causing trouble in his house.
Gatsby states his intention plainly: Daisy never loved Tom and has always loved him.
Tom dismisses Gatsby as crazy.
Gatsby passionately elaborates, claiming Daisy married Tom only for his money while waiting for Gatsby.
Tom demands to know the extent of their affair, disbelieving Gatsby's claim of a five-year love.
Tom asserts Daisy loved him when they married and loves him now, admitting his own occasional infidelities but claiming constant underlying love.
Daisy calls Tom revolting and alludes to his past 'sprees'.
Gatsby urges Daisy to tell Tom the 'truth' that she never loved him.
Reluctantly, Daisy states she never loved Tom.
Tom challenges her with specific memories of their past intimacy.
Daisy falters, her voice losing conviction.
Overwhelmed, Daisy cries out that Gatsby wants too much, admitting she loved Tom once but loves Gatsby now.
Gatsby is stunned by her admission of having loved Tom.
Tom seizes on this, claiming Daisy didn't even know Gatsby was alive and citing their shared history.
Gatsby demands to speak to Daisy alone, but she admits, pitifully, that she cannot truthfully say she never loved Tom.
Tom asserts his intention to take better care of Daisy.
Gatsby panics, stating Daisy is leaving Tom.
Tom laughs, disbelieving, until Daisy confirms it with effort.
Tom furiously attacks Gatsby, calling him a bootlegger and referencing his association with Wolfshiem and shady drugstore deals.
Gatsby attempts to defend himself but appears shaken, looking as if he had 'killed a man'.
Daisy grows increasingly withdrawn and terrified as Gatsby denies Tom's accusations.
Gatsby's dream seems to die as Daisy loses her resolve.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The music had died down as the ceremony began and now a long cheer floated in at the window, followed by intermittent cries of “Yea—ea—ea!” and finally by a burst of jazz as the dancing began.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The voice begged again to go.

events.text_segment:
The music had died down as the ceremony began and now a long cheer floated in at the window, followed by intermittent cries of “Yea—ea—ea!” and finally by a burst of jazz as the dancing began.
“We’re getting old,” said Daisy. “If we were young we’d rise and dance.”
“Remember Biloxi,” Jordan warned her. “Where’d you know him, Tom?”
“Biloxi?” He concentrated with an effort. “I didn’t know him. He was a friend of Daisy’s.”
“He was not,” she denied. “I’d never seen him before. He came down in the private car.”
“Well, he said he knew you. He said he was raised in Louisville. Asa Bird brought him around at the last minute and asked if we had room for him.”
Jordan smiled.
“He was probably bumming his way home. He told me he was president of your class at Yale.”
Tom and I looked at each other blankly.
“Biloxi?”
“First place, we didn’t have any president—”
Gatsby’s foot beat a short, restless tattoo and Tom eyed him suddenly.
“By the way, Mr. Gatsby, I understand you’re an Oxford man.”
“Not exactly.”
“Oh, yes, I understand you went to Oxford.”
“Yes—I went there.”
A pause. Then Tom’s voice, incredulous and insulting:
“You must have gone there about the time Biloxi went to New Haven.”
Another pause. A waiter knocked and came in with crushed mint and ice but the silence was unbroken by his “thank you” and the soft closing of the door. This tremendous detail was to be cleared up at last.
“I told you I went there,” said Gatsby.
“I heard you, but I’d like to know when.”
“It was in nineteen-nineteen, I only stayed five months. That’s why I can’t really call myself an Oxford man.”
Tom glanced around to see if we mirrored his unbelief. But we were all looking at Gatsby.
“It was an opportunity they gave to some of the officers after the armistice,” he continued. “We could go to any of the universities in England or France.”
I wanted to get up and slap him on the back. I had one of those renewals of complete faith in him that I’d experienced before.
Daisy rose, smiling faintly, and went to the table.
“Open the whisky, Tom,” she ordered, “and I’ll make you a mint julep. Then you won’t seem so stupid to yourself… Look at the mint!”
“Wait a minute,” snapped Tom, “I want to ask Mr. Gatsby one more question.”
“Go on,” Gatsby said politely.
“What kind of a row are you trying to cause in my house anyhow?”
They were out in the open at last and Gatsby was content.
“He isn’t causing a row,” Daisy looked desperately from one to the other. “You’re causing a row. Please have a little self-control.”
“Self-control!” repeated Tom incredulously. “I suppose the latest thing is to sit back and let Mr. Nobody from Nowhere make love to your wife. Well, if that’s the idea you can count me out… Nowadays people begin by sneering at family life and family institutions, and next they’ll throw everything overboard and have intermarriage between black and white.”
Flushed with his impassioned gibberish, he saw himself standing alone on the last barrier of civilization.
“We’re all white here,” murmured Jordan.
“I know I’m not very popular. I don’t give big parties. I suppose you’ve got to make your house into a pigsty in order to have any friends—in the modern world.”
Angry as I was, as we all were, I was tempted to laugh whenever he opened his mouth. The transition from libertine to prig was so complete.
“I’ve got something to tell you, old sport—” began Gatsby. But Daisy guessed at his intention.
“Please don’t!” she interrupted helplessly. “Please let’s all go home. Why don’t we all go home?”
“That’s a good idea,” I got up. “Come on, Tom. Nobody wants a drink.”
“I want to know what Mr. Gatsby has to tell me.”
“Your wife doesn’t love you,” said Gatsby. “She’s never loved you. She loves me.”
“You must be crazy!” exclaimed Tom automatically.
Gatsby sprang to his feet, vivid with excitement.
“She never loved you, do you hear?” he cried. “She only married you because I was poor and she was tired of waiting for me. It was a terrible mistake, but in her heart she never loved anyone except me!”
At this point Jordan and I tried to go, but Tom and Gatsby insisted with competitive firmness that we remain—as though neither of them had anything to conceal and it would be a privilege to partake vicariously of their emotions.
“Sit down, Daisy,” Tom’s voice groped unsuccessfully for the paternal note. “What’s been going on? I want to hear all about it.”
“I told you what’s been going on,” said Gatsby. “Going on for five years—and you didn’t know.”
Tom turned to Daisy sharply.
“You’ve been seeing this fellow for five years?”
“Not seeing,” said Gatsby. “No, we couldn’t meet. But both of us loved each other all that time, old sport, and you didn’t know. I used to laugh sometimes”—but there was no laughter in his eyes—“to think that you didn’t know.”
“Oh—that’s all.” Tom tapped his thick fingers together like a clergyman and leaned back in his chair.
“You’re crazy!” he exploded. “I can’t speak about what happened five years ago, because I didn’t know Daisy then—and I’ll be damned if I see how you got within a mile of her unless you brought the groceries to the back door. But all the rest of that’s a God damned lie. Daisy loved me when she married me and she loves me now.”
“No,” said Gatsby, shaking his head.
“She does, though. The trouble is that sometimes she gets foolish ideas in her head and doesn’t know what she’s doing.” He nodded sagely. “And what’s more, I love Daisy too. Once in a while I go off on a spree and make a fool of myself, but I always come back, and in my heart I love her all the time.”
“You’re revolting,” said Daisy. She turned to me, and her voice, dropping an octave lower, filled the room with thrilling scorn: “Do you know why we left Chicago? I’m surprised that they didn’t treat you to the story of that little spree.”
Gatsby walked over and stood beside her.
“Daisy, that’s all over now,” he said earnestly. “It doesn’t matter any more. Just tell him the truth—that you never loved him—and it’s all wiped out forever.”
She looked at him blindly. “Why—how could I love him—possibly?”
“You never loved him.”
She hesitated. Her eyes fell on Jordan and me with a sort of appeal, as though she realized at last what she was doing—and as though she had never, all along, intended doing anything at all. But it was done now. It was too late.
“I never loved him,” she said, with perceptible reluctance.
“Not at Kapiolani?” demanded Tom suddenly.
“No.”
From the ballroom beneath, muffled and suffocating chords were drifting up on hot waves of air.
“Not that day I carried you down from the Punch Bowl to keep your shoes dry?” There was a husky tenderness in his tone… “Daisy?”
“Please don’t.” Her voice was cold, but the rancour was gone from it. She looked at Gatsby. “There, Jay,” she said—but her hand as she tried to light a cigarette was trembling. Suddenly she threw the cigarette and the burning match on the carpet.
“Oh, you want too much!” she cried to Gatsby. “I love you now—isn’t that enough? I can’t help what’s past.” She began to sob helplessly. “I did love him once—but I loved you too.”
Gatsby’s eyes opened and closed.
“You loved me too?” he repeated.
“Even that’s a lie,” said Tom savagely. “She didn’t know you were alive. Why—there’s things between Daisy and me that you’ll never know, things that neither of us can ever forget.”
The words seemed to bite physically into Gatsby.
“I want to speak to Daisy alone,” he insisted. “She’s all excited now—”
“Even alone I can’t say I never loved Tom,” she admitted in a pitiful voice. “It wouldn’t be true.”
“Of course it wouldn’t,” agreed Tom.
She turned to her husband.
“As if it mattered to you,” she said.
“Of course it matters. I’m going to take better care of you from now on.”
“You don’t understand,” said Gatsby, with a touch of panic. “You’re not going to take care of her any more.”
“I’m not?” Tom opened his eyes wide and laughed. He could afford to control himself now. “Why’s that?”
“Daisy’s leaving you.”
“Nonsense.”
“I am, though,” she said with a visible effort.
“She’s not leaving me!” Tom’s words suddenly leaned down over Gatsby. “Certainly not for a common swindler who’d have to steal the ring he put on her finger.”
“I won’t stand this!” cried Daisy. “Oh, please let’s get out.”
“Who are you, anyhow?” broke out Tom. “You’re one of that bunch that hangs around with Meyer Wolfshiem—that much I happen to know. I’ve made a little investigation into your affairs—and I’ll carry it further tomorrow.”
“You can suit yourself about that, old sport,” said Gatsby steadily.
“I found out what your ‘drugstores’ were.” He turned to us and spoke rapidly. “He and this Wolfshiem bought up a lot of side-street drugstores here and in Chicago and sold grain alcohol over the counter. That’s one of his little stunts. I picked him for a bootlegger the first time I saw him, and I wasn’t far wrong.”
“What about it?” said Gatsby politely. “I guess your friend Walter Chase wasn’t too proud to come in on it.”
“And you left him in the lurch, didn’t you? You let him go to jail for a month over in New Jersey. God! You ought to hear Walter on the subject of you.”
“He came to us dead broke. He was very glad to pick up some money, old sport.”
“Don’t you call me ‘old sport’!” cried Tom. Gatsby said nothing. “Walter could have you up on the betting laws too, but Wolfshiem scared him into shutting his mouth.”
That unfamiliar yet recognizable look was back again in Gatsby’s face.
“That drugstore business was just small change,” continued Tom slowly, “but you’ve got something on now that Walter’s afraid to tell me about.”
I glanced at Daisy, who was staring terrified between Gatsby and her husband, and at Jordan, who had begun to balance an invisible but absorbing object on the tip of her chin. Then I turned back to Gatsby—and was startled at his expression. He looked—and this is said in all contempt for the babbled slander of his garden—as if he had “killed a man.” For a moment the set of his face could be described in just that fantastic way.
It passed, and he began to talk excitedly to Daisy, denying everything, defending his name against accusations that had not been made. But with every word she was drawing further and further into herself, so he gave that up, and only the dead dream fought on as the afternoon slipped away, trying to touch what was no longer tangible, struggling unhappily, undespairingly, toward that lost voice across the room.
The voice begged again to go.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The music had died down as the ceremony began and now a long cheer floated in at the window, followed by intermittent cries of “Yea—ea—ea!” and finally by a burst of jazz as the dancing began. The air, thick with the scent of gardenias and expensive perfume, seemed to vibrate with a sudden, unleashed energy. It was a sound that promised release, a temporary suspension of the rigid formalities that had governed the preceding hour. Couples, flushed and eager, spilled onto the polished floor, their movements initially tentative, then bolder as the rhythm took hold. The band, a brassy, exuberant ensemble, launched into a Charleston, its syncopated beat infectious, pulling even the most reserved guests into its orbit. Laughter, sharp and bright, mingled with the music, creating a joyous, almost frantic, symphony of celebration. Waiters, balancing trays laden with champagne flutes and glittering cocktails, weaved through the throng, their faces impassive amidst the revelry. The room, draped in silks and adorned with cascades of flowers, felt like a stage set for a grand, slightly unreal, performance. Chandeliers blazed overhead, casting a warm, golden light that softened the edges of the scene, making everyone look a little younger, a little more beautiful, a little less burdened by the weight of their own histories. It was a world built on illusion, on the careful cultivation of appearances, and tonight, the illusion was perfect. The bride, radiant in white lace, was swept onto the floor by her new husband, a figure of imposing physicality and casual confidence. They moved together with an easy grace that spoke of shared privilege, of a life lived without want or worry. Around them, the party swirled, a kaleidoscope of color and movement. Women in shimmering gowns, their jewels catching the light, laughed with men in crisp tuxedos, their conversations a low murmur beneath the music. It was a gathering of the privileged, the wealthy, the people who inhabited a world where money smoothed over every rough edge, where discomfort was a foreign concept. I watched from the periphery, a silent observer in this glittering tableau. There was a certain fascination in it, a hypnotic quality to the sheer scale of the opulence, the effortless extravagance. But there was also a sense of detachment, a feeling that I was looking through a pane of glass at a world I could observe but never truly inhabit. The gaiety felt forced, the laughter a little too loud, the smiles a little too fixed. It was as if everyone was playing a part, performing the role of the happy, carefree socialite. And perhaps they were. Perhaps the performance was the reality, the only reality that mattered in this rarefied atmosphere. The jazz band shifted tempo, moving into a slower, more languid tune. Couples drew closer, their movements becoming more intimate, more suggestive. The air grew warmer, heavier, charged with a subtle current of desire and unspoken longing. I saw faces flushed with alcohol and emotion, eyes meeting across the crowded floor, brief, intense connections forming and dissolving in the swirling mass of bodies. It was a world of fleeting pleasures, of transient affections, where relationships seemed as fluid and changeable as the music itself. I thought of the stories I had heard, the whispers and rumors that circulated through this society like a contagious disease. Stories of affairs, of betrayals, of broken promises. They were the undercurrent beneath the polished surface, the hidden cracks in the gilded facade. And watching these people dance, laugh, and flirt, it was easy to see how those stories came to be. There was a restlessness about them, a perpetual search for something more, something new, something that might fill the emptiness that seemed to lie beneath the surface of their lives. They had everything, and yet they seemed constantly unsatisfied, constantly seeking the next thrill, the next distraction. It was a peculiar paradox, one that I found both intriguing and disturbing. The night wore on, the music growing louder, the dancing more frenzied. The initial elegance of the scene began to fray at the edges. Ties were loosened, hair became disheveled, laughter grew coarser. The veneer of sophistication began to crack, revealing something wilder, more primal, beneath. It was the release of pent-up energy, the shedding of inhibitions that had been carefully maintained throughout the day. The party was reaching its peak, a crescendo of noise and movement and intoxication. I saw people stumble, their balance lost to the combined effects of alcohol and exhaustion. Arguments flared up and died down just as quickly, forgotten in the general chaos. It was a scene of controlled abandon, a carefully orchestrated descent into revelry. But even in the midst of the chaos, there was a sense of order, a sense that this was how things were meant to be. This was the ritual of their lives, the cycle of formality and release, of constraint and excess. It was a pattern that repeated itself endlessly, a dance that never truly ended. I found myself drawn into conversations, pulled into the eddying currents of the party. People spoke of trivial things, of summer plans, of mutual acquaintances, of the latest scandals. Their words were light and airy, devoid of any real substance. It was a language of surfaces, a way of communicating without revealing anything of importance. I felt a strange sense of isolation even as I was surrounded by people. Their world was not my world, their concerns were not my concerns. I was an outsider looking in, a spectator at a play in which I had no part. And yet, there was a part of me that was drawn to it, to the glamour, the excitement, the sheer vitality of it all. It was a world that promised something, something elusive and undefined, but something that felt important. It was the promise of belonging, perhaps, or the promise of understanding, of finally grasping the secret of their effortless existence. But the more I observed, the less I understood. Their lives seemed to be built on contradictions, on a foundation of wealth and privilege that somehow failed to bring them happiness. They were like beautiful, fragile objects, polished and perfect on the outside, but hollow within. The music changed again, a slow, mournful saxophone solo drifting through the air. It was a sound that seemed to speak of longing, of regret, of the things that were lost or never found. It was a counterpoint to the earlier exuberance, a reminder that even in the midst of celebration, there was a deeper current of sadness running beneath the surface. I saw a woman weeping quietly in a corner, her face hidden in her hands. No one seemed to notice, or perhaps they chose not to. Her sorrow was a private matter, an unwelcome intrusion into the public display of happiness. It was a stark reminder that even in this world of privilege, there was pain, there was suffering. It was not a shield against the realities of life, merely a different way of experiencing them. The party continued its relentless pace, oblivious to the quiet moments of despair that flickered at its edges. The dancing grew wilder, the music louder, the laughter more unrestrained. It was a desperate attempt to outrun the darkness, to drown out the whispers of doubt and dissatisfaction. And for a time, it seemed to work. The sheer force of the revelry was overwhelming, sweeping everyone along in its wake. It was a collective act of denial, a refusal to acknowledge the emptiness that lay beneath the surface. I felt a growing weariness settle over me. The energy of the party was draining, its relentless gaiety exhausting. I longed for quiet, for solitude, for a moment to collect my thoughts and make sense of what I was witnessing. But there was no escape. The party was a vortex, pulling everyone deeper into its swirling depths. It was a world without pause, without reflection, a world of constant motion and fleeting sensation. And I was caught in its grip, an unwilling participant in a dance that felt both exhilarating and terrifying. The night air, cool and damp, offered a brief respite as I stepped onto a balcony overlooking the gardens. The sounds of the party were muffled here, a distant roar that seemed to belong to another world. Below, the gardens were bathed in moonlight, the flowers ghostly white against the dark green of the foliage. It was a scene of quiet beauty, a stark contrast to the frenetic energy of the ballroom. I took a deep breath, filling my lungs with the clean, cool air. It felt like a cleansing, a washing away of the artificiality and excess that had surrounded me. I looked up at the stars, their cold, distant light a reminder of the vastness of the universe, of the insignificance of the human drama unfolding below. And for a moment, the party, the wealth, the glittering facade, all seemed to shrink in importance. They were just fleeting moments in the grand sweep of time, brief flashes of light against an eternal darkness. But then the music swelled again, louder this time, pulling me back into the present. The party was still raging, its energy undiminished. And I knew that I could not escape it, not yet. I was bound to this world, to these people, by a strange mixture of fascination and repulsion. I wanted to understand them, to understand what drove them, what they were searching for. And so, I turned back towards the light, towards the noise, towards the dance. The air inside was thick and hot, the scent of perfume and alcohol even stronger than before. The faces of the dancers were flushed and sweaty, their eyes bright with a feverish intensity. It was a scene of raw, unbridled energy, a release of all the pent-up emotions and desires that lay beneath the polished surface of their lives. I saw a woman throw her head back and laugh, a wild, abandoned sound that cut through the music. I saw a man pull his partner close, their bodies pressed together in a desperate embrace. It was a dance of longing, of searching, of a desperate attempt to connect in a world that felt increasingly disconnected. And I was a part of it now, swept up in the current, moving with the rhythm of the music. I was no longer an observer, but a participant, caught in the intoxicating swirl of the party. The night was a blur of faces, of voices, of fleeting moments of connection and disconnection. It was a world of contradictions, of beauty and decay, of hope and despair. And as the night wore on, the lines between them began to blur, the distinctions becoming less clear. The party was a microcosm of their lives, a reflection of the world they inhabited. It was a world of endless possibility, but also a world of profound emptiness. And as the first hints of dawn began to appear in the sky, casting a pale light through the windows, the party began to wind down. The music grew softer, the dancing slower, the laughter more subdued. The energy that had fueled the night began to dissipate, leaving behind a sense of exhaustion and anticlimax. People began to drift away, their faces tired and drawn. The magic of the night was fading, replaced by the harsh reality of the morning. And as I stood there, watching the last of the guests depart, I felt a profound sense of sadness. It was the sadness of an ending, the sadness of a dream that had come to an end. But it was also the sadness of a world that seemed to be constantly searching for something it could never find. It was a world of beautiful illusions, but a world that ultimately failed to satisfy. And as the sun rose higher in the sky, casting its harsh light on the remnants of the party, I knew that I would never forget what I had seen. It was a glimpse into a world that was both fascinating and terrifying, a world that was built on wealth and privilege, but a world that was ultimately empty at its core. And as I walked away, leaving the silence and the stillness behind, I carried with me the memory of the music, the laughter, and the desperate, unending dance.

events.title: Tom Reasserts Control and Nick Reflects on Turning Thirty
detailed_summary: Daisy pleads to leave, her courage gone.
Tom, sensing victory, magnanimously tells Daisy to drive home with Gatsby in Gatsby's car.
He dismisses Gatsby's 'presumptuous little flirtation' as over.
Daisy and Gatsby leave wordlessly.
Tom prepares to leave, offering Nick and Jordan the unopened whiskey.
Nick declines, suddenly remembering it is his thirtieth birthday.
Nick reflects on entering a new decade, anticipating loneliness and diminished prospects.
Driving back to Long Island with Tom and Jordan, Nick feels detached from Tom's exultant talk.
He finds some comfort in Jordan's presence beside him as they cross the bridge, momentarily forgetting the weight of turning thirty.
Nick frames their journey back as driving 'toward death through the cooling twilight'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Please, Tom! I can’t stand this any more.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So we drove on toward death through the cooling twilight.

events.text_segment:
“Please, Tom! I can’t stand this any more.”
Her frightened eyes told that whatever intentions, whatever courage she had had, were definitely gone.
“You two start on home, Daisy,” said Tom. “In Mr. Gatsby’s car.”
She looked at Tom, alarmed now, but he insisted with magnanimous scorn.
“Go on. He won’t annoy you. I think he realizes that his presumptuous little flirtation is over.”
They were gone, without a word, snapped out, made accidental, isolated, like ghosts, even from our pity.
After a moment Tom got up and began wrapping the unopened bottle of whisky in the towel.
“Want any of this stuff? Jordan?… Nick?”
I didn’t answer.
“Nick?” He asked again.
“What?”
“Want any?”
“No… I just remembered that today’s my birthday.”
I was thirty. Before me stretched the portentous, menacing road of a new decade.
It was seven o’clock when we got into the coupé with him and started for Long Island. Tom talked incessantly, exulting and laughing, but his voice was as remote from Jordan and me as the foreign clamour on the sidewalk or the tumult of the elevated overhead. Human sympathy has its limits, and we were content to let all their tragic arguments fade with the city lights behind. Thirty—the promise of a decade of loneliness, a thinning list of single men to know, a thinning briefcase of enthusiasm, thinning hair. But there was Jordan beside me, who, unlike Daisy, was too wise ever to carry well-forgotten dreams from age to age. As we passed over the dark bridge her wan face fell lazily against my coat’s shoulder and the formidable stroke of thirty died away with the reassuring pressure of her hand.
So we drove on toward death through the cooling twilight.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: “Please, Tom! I can’t stand this any more.” Daisy was crying now, and suddenly I felt the need of more air. The room seemed to have grown smaller, closer. Tom looked at her with contemptuous interest. “Oh, in the name of God, stop crying!” he said. “Look here, you’re acting like a child. What’s the matter with you?” Daisy sobbed, burying her face in her hands. “Everything’s so confused,” she wailed. “I can’t make out anything.” Gatsby leaned forward, his face pale with anxiety. “It’s all right, Daisy,” he said softly. “Just tell him the truth – that you never loved him – and it’s all wiped out forever.” “Oh, please don’t!” cried Daisy. “I can’t stand it!” Tom’s eyes narrowed. “Never loved me!” he echoed, incredulous. “Why, you loved me most among all! You did, didn’t you?” He was forcing her hand, pushing her towards an impossible confession. The air crackled with the unspoken history between them, the years of marriage, the child, the shared life, however flawed. Gatsby watched her, his dream hanging precariously on her next words. His face was a mask of desperate hope, willing her to deny the past, to affirm only the five years they had lost. But the weight of reality, of the present, was crushing her. Her shoulders shook with sobs, and she couldn’t meet Gatsby’s pleading gaze. The moment stretched, agonizingly, until the truth, or at least a version of it, was wrung from her.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Please, Tom! I can’t stand this any more.” Her voice was strained and hysterical. She knew that Tom was safe, and her courage was gone.
“You two start on home, Daisy,” said Tom. “In Mr. Gatsby’s car.”

1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion introduces a lengthy, repetitive exchange about pearls that is not present in the original passage. This invented dialogue dominates the middle and end of the completion, displacing actual events and reflections from the source material.
- Several invented scenes and lines are included, such as references to a platform, Daisy's supposed statements about Tom, and a focus on pearls, none of which occur in the original excerpt.
- The completion omits the entire latter portion of the original, including the narrator's internal reflections, the transition to leaving the scene, and the significant thematic commentary on age and loneliness.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion lacks the depiction of the characters' emotional states and the subtle narrative distance that is present in the original, especially after Daisy and Gatsby leave.
- There is no mention of the narrator's realization about his birthday, nor the introspective thoughts about entering a new decade and the associated feelings.
- The transition to the car ride back to Long Island, the description of Tom's behavior, and the emotional distance between the characters during this ride are all missing.
- The original's closing reflection on mortality and the symbolic journey "toward death through the cooling twilight" is absent.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion attributes actions and dialogue to characters that do not occur in the original, such as Daisy's supposed statements about Tom and the repeated insistence on seeing pearls.
- The sequence of events is altered, with invented dialogue and scenes replacing the actual progression from confrontation to departure to introspection.
- The emotional tone and focus are shifted, with the completion emphasizing invented conflict and repetition rather than the original's sense of isolation, resignation, and reflection.

events.title: Michaelis's Testimony: Events Leading to Myrtle's Death
detailed_summary: Michaelis, owner of a nearby coffee shop, is identified as the primary witness.
He found Wilson sick and distressed in his office around 5 PM.
Wilson refused to rest, mentioning he had locked Myrtle upstairs.
Wilson revealed his plan to move away with Myrtle the day after tomorrow, surprising Michaelis with his newfound resolve.
Wilson became suspicious of Michaelis, questioning his whereabouts.
Michaelis left when customers arrived, intending to return later but forgot.
Around 7 PM, Michaelis heard Myrtle shouting angrily downstairs in the garage, accusing Wilson of cowardice.
Moments later, Myrtle rushed out into the road, waving her arms.
Before Michaelis could react, she was struck by a car.
The car, described later by newspapers as the 'death car,' did not stop and disappeared.
Michaelis initially told police the car was light green.
The driver of another car, heading towards New York, stopped and rushed back with Michaelis to Myrtle.
They found Myrtle obviously dead, her chest mutilated and mouth open.
