events.text_segment:
The young Greek, Michaelis, who ran the coffee joint beside the ash-heaps was the principal witness at the inquest. He had slept through the heat until after five, when he strolled over to the garage, and found George Wilson sick in his office—really sick, pale as his own pale hair and shaking all over. Michaelis advised him to go to bed, but Wilson refused, saying that he’d miss a lot of business if he did. While his neighbour was trying to persuade him a violent racket broke out overhead.
“I’ve got my wife locked in up there,” explained Wilson calmly. “She’s going to stay there till the day after tomorrow, and then we’re going to move away.”
Michaelis was astonished; they had been neighbours for four years, and Wilson had never seemed faintly capable of such a statement. Generally he was one of these worn-out men: when he wasn’t working, he sat on a chair in the doorway and stared at the people and the cars that passed along the road. When anyone spoke to him he invariably laughed in an agreeable, colourless way. He was his wife’s man and not his own.
So naturally Michaelis tried to find out what had happened, but Wilson wouldn’t say a word—instead he began to throw curious, suspicious glances at his visitor and ask him what he’d been doing at certain times on certain days. Just as the latter was getting uneasy, some workmen came past the door bound for his restaurant, and Michaelis took the opportunity to get away, intending to come back later. But he didn’t. He supposed he forgot to, that’s all. When he came outside again, a little after seven, he was reminded of the conversation because he heard Mrs. Wilson’s voice, loud and scolding, downstairs in the garage.
“Beat me!” he heard her cry. “Throw me down and beat me, you dirty little coward!”
A moment later she rushed out into the dusk, waving her hands and shouting—before he could move from his door the business was over.
The “death car” as the newspapers called it, didn’t stop; it came out of the gathering darkness, wavered tragically for a moment, and then disappeared around the next bend. Mavro Michaelis wasn’t even sure of its colour—he told the first policeman that it was light green. The other car, the one going toward New York, came to rest a hundred yards beyond, and its driver hurried back to where Myrtle Wilson, her life violently extinguished, knelt in the road and mingled her thick dark blood with the dust.
Michaelis and this man reached her first, but when they had torn open her shirtwaist, still damp with perspiration, they saw that her left breast was swinging loose like a flap, and there was no need to listen for the heart beneath. The mouth was wide open and ripped a little at the corners, as though she had choked a little in giving up the tremendous vitality she had stored so long.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The young Greek, Michaelis, who ran the coffee joint beside the ash-heaps was the principal witness at the inquest. He was one of the few people who had been present during the immediate aftermath of the tragedy, having been roused from his sleep by the sound of the crash and the subsequent commotion. His small, dingy establishment, usually a quiet refuge for weary travelers and the inhabitants of the valley of ashes, became the focal point of the initial confusion and grief. Michaelis, a man of simple habits and a gentle nature, found himself thrust into a role he was ill-equipped to handle. He had seen Myrtle Wilson only moments before her death, arguing with her husband, George, in the garage. He had heard the rising tension in their voices, the desperate edge to George's pleas for her to stay. Then came the roar of the engine, the screech of tires, and the sickening thud that echoed across the desolate landscape. He was the first to reach the scene, his heart pounding with a nameless dread. He saw the crumpled figure on the road, the pool of blood spreading on the dust. He saw George Wilson, howling like a wounded animal, cradling his dead wife's head. Michaelis tried to help, tried to offer comfort, but his words were lost in the storm of George's anguish. He stayed with Wilson through the long night, listening to his incoherent ramblings, his desperate search for meaning in the senseless violence. Wilson was convinced that Myrtle had been running away from him, that the car was her lover's. He spoke of God, of the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg watching over the valley, seeing everything. Michaelis, a man of faith himself, tried to steer Wilson away from these dark thoughts, urging him to rest, to accept the terrible reality. But Wilson was beyond reach, consumed by his grief and a growing obsession with vengeance. At the inquest, Michaelis recounted everything he had seen and heard. He described the argument between George and Myrtle, the speed of the car, the immediate aftermath. He spoke of Wilson's state of mind, his conviction that the driver was the man Myrtle had been seeing. His testimony was crucial in establishing the timeline and the emotional context of the events leading up to the accident. He painted a picture of a marriage in turmoil, of a woman desperate to escape, and a man driven to the brink by suspicion and despair. Michaelis's quiet, factual account stood in stark contrast to the sensationalism that quickly surrounded the tragedy. He was a voice of simple truth in a world increasingly distorted by rumor and speculation. He saw the raw pain, the human cost, unvarnished by the layers of wealth and deceit that characterized the lives of those involved. His small coffee shop, usually a place of mundane transactions, became a temporary stage for the unfolding of a great American tragedy, witnessed by a humble Greek immigrant who could only watch and report what his honest eyes had seen.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The young Greek, Michaelis, who ran the coffee joint beside the ash-heaps was the principal witness at the inquest. He was a husky, reserved young man, inclined to reserve even in his unreserved conversations, and what he remembered was not to be questioned about. According to Michaelis, Wilson had been "perfectly all right" up to a certain point this afternoon. "I have a way of finding out," he said. "About what?" asked Michaelis. "About the cars," he answered. "What cars?" "Their cars." He stared at Michaelis with eyes dimmed a little by many pointless days and nights. "Those days he was fine," said Michaelis. "He worked himself up into a white personal devil." About five o'clock it was all over. The man came out of the office holding a tin of lard, and Michaelis saw with a shock that he was sick—it was the first time Michaelis had ever seen him sick. He looked ghastly for a moment, dragged himself back to the couch and lay down. His wife, after attempting to laugh at him and failing, went upstairs to change her dress. "Keep your hands off the lever," snapped Wilson. "I'm getting to be a mechanic myself." "You don't have to tell me what to do," she answered fiercely. "None of us can stand the sight of you any more." "She's going to stay there till the day after to-morrow," said Wilson. "Then we're going to move away." "Why're you going to move?" "To get away from it all. They won't be able to come any more." He stared dully at Michaelis, then suddenly asserted his wife's right to buy ten dogs if she pleased. "I don't care if he buys ten dogs," interrupted Michaelis, "as long as they don't fall on the sidewalk." "An automobile passed here this afternoon and left dust all over the child." He looked out of the window at the sign of the oculist across the street. "It was a yellow car," he said, "a big yellow car. New." "That's funny," said Michaelis, after a pause, "that's very funny, because . . ." This morning he had been working around the garage, cleaning up, and had noticed that all four tires on the coupé were from the factory when they were new. "Well, it's a funny thing," he repeated. "I don't understand it. I've never seen it before." He went into the office and came out in a moment with a photograph, a small, flat picture of a woman, her face blurred by wet or dampness, pressed against the glass. "I've been here four years," muttered Wilson, "and I've never seen her before." "Where's the picture?" asked Michaelis. "In the drawer," Wilson said. "It was there this morning. I don't know how it got there." He looked at Michaelis, then at the picture. "I'm going to find out who it was," he said. "I'm going to find out who she was." simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: The young Greek, Michaelis, who ran the coffee joint beside the ash-heaps was the principal witness at the inquest. He was a husky, reserved young man, inclined to reserve even in his unreserved conversations, and what he remembered was not to be questioned about. According to Michaelis, Wilson had been "perfectly all right" up to a certain point this afternoon. "I have a way of finding out," he said. "About what?" asked Michaelis. "About the cars," he answered. "What cars?" "Their cars." He stared at Michaelis with eyes dimmed a little by many pointless days and nights. "Those days he was fine," said Michaelis. "He worked himself up into a white personal devil." About five o'clock it was all over. The man came out of the office holding a tin of lard, and Michaelis saw with a shock that he was sick—it was the first time Michaelis had ever seen him sick. He looked ghastly for a moment, dragged himself back to the couch and lay down. His wife, after attempting to laugh at him and failing, went upstairs to change her dress. "Keep your hands off the lever," snapped Wilson. "I'm getting to be a mechanic myself." "You don't have to tell me what to do," she answered fiercely. "None of us can stand the sight of you any more." "She's going to stay there till the day after to-morrow," said Wilson. "Then we're going to move away." "Why're you going to move?" "To get away from it all. They won't be able to come any more." He stared dully at Michaelis, then suddenly asserted his wife's right to buy ten dogs if she pleased. "I don't care if he buys ten dogs," interrupted Michaelis, "as long as they don't fall on the sidewalk." "An automobile passed here this afternoon and left dust all over the child." He looked out of the window at the sign of the oculist across the street. "It was a yellow car," he said, "a big yellow car. New." "That's funny," said Michaelis, after a pause, "that's very funny, because . . ." This morning he had been working around the garage, cleaning up, and had noticed that all four tires on the coupé were from the factory when they were new. "Well, it's a funny thing," he repeated. "I don't understand it. I've never seen it before." He went into the office and came out in a moment with a photograph, a small, flat picture of a woman, her face blurred by wet or dampness, pressed against the glass. "I've been here four years," muttered Wilson, "and I've never seen her before." "Where's the picture?" asked Michaelis. "In the drawer," Wilson said. "It was there this morning. I don't know how it got there." He looked at Michaelis, then at the picture. "I'm going to find out who it was," he said. "I'm going to find out who she was." He stared at the picture for a moment, then put it back in the drawer. "I'm going to find out who she was," he repeated. "And then I'm going to . . ." He broke off, and Michaelis saw that he was trembling. "I'm going to find out who she was," he repeated. "And then I'm going to . . ." He broke off, and Michaelis saw that he was trembling. events.title: Discovery of Myrtle's Body and Tom's Deflection
detailed_summary: Tom, Nick, and Jordan see the crowd and cars at Wilson's garage from a distance.
Tom initially remarks cynically that the wreck might bring Wilson some business.
The somber faces of the crowd prompt Tom to stop the car.
They hear Wilson's continuous, agonizing cries of 'Oh, my God!' from inside.
Tom pushes through the crowd into the garage.
Nick and Jordan are pushed inside shortly after.
They see Myrtle's body wrapped in blankets on a workbench.
Tom stands over the body, motionless, while a policeman takes notes.
Wilson is seen swaying in his office doorway, oblivious and crying out repeatedly.
Tom abruptly confronts the policeman, demanding to know what happened.
The policeman explains Myrtle was hit by a car that didn't stop.
Michaelis clarifies that Myrtle ran out into the road and was hit by a car coming from New York.
A bystander describes the car as a big, new, yellow car, driving very fast.
Hearing this, Wilson cries out that he knows what kind of car it was.
Tom quickly goes to Wilson, grips his arms, and tells him firmly that he just arrived from New York and the yellow car he drove earlier wasn't his.
The policeman questions Tom about his own car, which Tom identifies as the blue coupé.
Nick confirms they came straight from New York.
Tom carries the distraught Wilson into his office and asks others to sit with him.
Tom tells Nick and Jordan they should leave, avoiding looking at Myrtle's body.
They push through the crowd, passing a doctor arriving too late.
Tom drives away slowly at first, then speeds up.
Tom begins to sob, calling the driver who hit Myrtle a 'God damned coward'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We saw the three or four automobiles and the crowd when we were still some distance away.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “The God damned coward!” he whimpered.

events.text_segment:
We saw the three or four automobiles and the crowd when we were still some distance away.
“Wreck!” said Tom. “That’s good. Wilson’ll have a little business at last.”
He slowed down, but still without any intention of stopping, until, as we came nearer, the hushed, intent faces of the people at the garage door made him automatically put on the brakes.
“We’ll take a look,” he said doubtfully, “just a look.”
I became aware now of a hollow, wailing sound which issued incessantly from the garage, a sound which as we got out of the coupé and walked toward the door resolved itself into the words “Oh, my God!” uttered over and over in a gasping moan.
“There’s some bad trouble here,” said Tom excitedly.
He reached up on tiptoes and peered over a circle of heads into the garage, which was lit only by a yellow light in a swinging metal basket overhead. Then he made a harsh sound in his throat, and with a violent thrusting movement of his powerful arms pushed his way through.
The circle closed up again with a running murmur of expostulation; it was a minute before I could see anything at all. Then new arrivals deranged the line, and Jordan and I were pushed suddenly inside.
Myrtle Wilson’s body, wrapped in a blanket, and then in another blanket, as though she suffered from a chill in the hot night, lay on a worktable by the wall, and Tom, with his back to us, was bending over it, motionless. Next to him stood a motorcycle policeman taking down names with much sweat and correction in a little book. At first I couldn’t find the source of the high, groaning words that echoed clamorously through the bare garage—then I saw Wilson standing on the raised threshold of his office, swaying back and forth and holding to the doorposts with both hands. Some man was talking to him in a low voice and attempting, from time to time, to lay a hand on his shoulder, but Wilson neither heard nor saw. His eyes would drop slowly from the swinging light to the laden table by the wall, and then jerk back to the light again, and he gave out incessantly his high, horrible call:
“Oh, my Ga-od! Oh, my Ga-od! Oh, Ga-od! Oh, my Ga-od!”
Presently Tom lifted his head with a jerk and, after staring around the garage with glazed eyes, addressed a mumbled incoherent remark to the policeman.
“M-a-v—” the policeman was saying, “—o—”
“No, r—” corrected the man, “M-a-v-r-o—”
“Listen to me!” muttered Tom fiercely.
“r—” said the policeman, “o—”
“g—”
“g—” He looked up as Tom’s broad hand fell sharply on his shoulder. “What you want, fella?”
“What happened?—that’s what I want to know.”
“Auto hit her. Ins’antly killed.”
“Instantly killed,” repeated Tom, staring.
“She ran out ina road. Son-of-a-bitch didn’t even stopus car.”
“There was two cars,” said Michaelis, “one comin’, one goin’, see?”
“Going where?” asked the policeman keenly.
“One goin’ each way. Well, she”—his hand rose toward the blankets but stopped halfway and fell to his side—“she ran out there an’ the one comin’ from N’York knock right into her, goin’ thirty or forty miles an hour.”
“What’s the name of this place here?” demanded the officer.
“Hasn’t got any name.”
A pale well-dressed negro stepped near.
“It was a yellow car,” he said, “big yellow car. New.”
“See the accident?” asked the policeman.
“No, but the car passed me down the road, going faster’n forty. Going fifty, sixty.”
“Come here and let’s have your name. Look out now. I want to get his name.”
Some words of this conversation must have reached Wilson, swaying in the office door, for suddenly a new theme found voice among his grasping cries:
“You don’t have to tell me what kind of car it was! I know what kind of car it was!”
Watching Tom, I saw the wad of muscle back of his shoulder tighten under his coat. He walked quickly over to Wilson and, standing in front of him, seized him firmly by the upper arms.
“You’ve got to pull yourself together,” he said with soothing gruffness.
Wilson’s eyes fell upon Tom; he started up on his tiptoes and then would have collapsed to his knees had not Tom held him upright.
“Listen,” said Tom, shaking him a little. “I just got here a minute ago, from New York. I was bringing you that coupé we’ve been talking about. That yellow car I was driving this afternoon wasn’t mine—do you hear? I haven’t seen it all afternoon.”
Only the negro and I were near enough to hear what he said, but the policeman caught something in the tone and looked over with truculent eyes.
“What’s all that?” he demanded.
“I’m a friend of his.” Tom turned his head but kept his hands firm on Wilson’s body. “He says he knows the car that did it… It was a yellow car.”
Some dim impulse moved the policeman to look suspiciously at Tom.
“And what colour’s your car?”
“It’s a blue car, a coupé.”
“We’ve come straight from New York,” I said.
Someone who had been driving a little behind us confirmed this, and the policeman turned away.
“Now, if you’ll let me have that name again correct—”
Picking up Wilson like a doll, Tom carried him into the office, set him down in a chair, and came back.
“If somebody’ll come here and sit with him,” he snapped authoritatively. He watched while the two men standing closest glanced at each other and went unwillingly into the room. Then Tom shut the door on them and came down the single step, his eyes avoiding the table. As he passed close to me he whispered: “Let’s get out.”
Self-consciously, with his authoritative arms breaking the way, we pushed through the still gathering crowd, passing a hurried doctor, case in hand, who had been sent for in wild hope half an hour ago.
Tom drove slowly until we were beyond the bend—then his foot came down hard, and the coupé raced along through the night. In a little while I heard a low husky sob, and saw that the tears were overflowing down his face.
“The God damned coward!” he whimpered.

events.title: Gatsby's Watch and Tom and Daisy's Reconciliation
detailed_summary: They arrive back at the Buchanans' house.
Tom notes Daisy is home, seeing lights on.
Tom becomes serious and decisive, telling Nick he should have dropped him off and suggesting Nick and Jordan get supper while waiting for a taxi.
Nick declines to go inside, feeling sick and wanting distance from everyone, including Jordan.
Jordan seems to understand Nick's withdrawal and goes inside.
Nick waits outside, hearing the butler call for a taxi.
Walking down the drive, Nick encounters Gatsby hiding in the bushes.
Gatsby asks if Nick saw the 'trouble' on the road and confirms hearing Myrtle was killed.
Gatsby claims Daisy 'stood it pretty well,' focusing solely on her reaction.
He recounts taking a side road back and hiding the car, hoping they weren't seen.
Nick, disliking Gatsby intensely at this moment, doesn't correct him.
Gatsby asks who the woman was.
Gatsby starts to explain the accident, saying he 'tried to swing the wheel,' leading Nick to guess the truth.
Gatsby confirms Daisy was driving but insists he will take the blame.
He explains Daisy was nervous and wanted to drive, and the woman (Myrtle) rushed out unexpectedly as if recognizing them.
Gatsby says Daisy swerved, lost her nerve, swerved back, and he felt the impact just as he grabbed the wheel.
He says Daisy couldn't stop, so he pulled the emergency brake and drove on after she collapsed into his lap.
Gatsby declares he will wait outside all night to ensure Tom doesn't harm Daisy.
Nick, concerned Tom might discover Daisy drove, offers to check the house.
Nick walks back and peers through the pantry window.
He sees Tom and Daisy sitting intimately at the kitchen table over untouched food and ale.
Tom is talking earnestly, his hand covering hers; Daisy nods in agreement occasionally.
Nick observes they appear not happy, yet not unhappy, sharing an air of 'natural intimacy' and seemingly 'conspiring together'.
Nick returns to Gatsby, assures him all is quiet, and advises him to go home.
Gatsby refuses, determined to continue his vigil.
Nick leaves Gatsby standing alone in the moonlight, 'watching over nothing'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Buchanans’ house floated suddenly toward us through the dark rustling trees.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So I walked away and left him standing there in the moonlight—watching over nothing.

events.text_segment:
The Buchanans’ house floated suddenly toward us through the dark rustling trees. Tom stopped beside the porch and looked up at the second floor, where two windows bloomed with light among the vines.
“Daisy’s home,” he said. As we got out of the car he glanced at me and frowned slightly.
“I ought to have dropped you in West Egg, Nick. There’s nothing we can do tonight.”
A change had come over him, and he spoke gravely, and with decision. As we walked across the moonlight gravel to the porch he disposed of the situation in a few brisk phrases.
“I’ll telephone for a taxi to take you home, and while you’re waiting you and Jordan better go in the kitchen and have them get you some supper—if you want any.” He opened the door. “Come in.”
“No, thanks. But I’d be glad if you’d order me the taxi. I’ll wait outside.”
Jordan put her hand on my arm.
“Won’t you come in, Nick?”
“No, thanks.”
I was feeling a little sick and I wanted to be alone. But Jordan lingered for a moment more.
“It’s only half-past nine,” she said.
I’d be damned if I’d go in; I’d had enough of all of them for one day, and suddenly that included Jordan too. She must have seen something of this in my expression, for she turned abruptly away and ran up the porch steps into the house. I sat down for a few minutes with my head in my hands, until I heard the phone taken up inside and the butler’s voice calling a taxi. Then I walked slowly down the drive away from the house, intending to wait by the gate.
I hadn’t gone twenty yards when I heard my name and Gatsby stepped from between two bushes into the path. I must have felt pretty weird by that time, because I could think of nothing except the luminosity of his pink suit under the moon.
“What are you doing?” I inquired.
“Just standing here, old sport.”
Somehow, that seemed a despicable occupation. For all I knew he was going to rob the house in a moment; I wouldn’t have been surprised to see sinister faces, the faces of “Wolfshiem’s people,” behind him in the dark shrubbery.
“Did you see any trouble on the road?” he asked after a minute.
“Yes.”
He hesitated.
“Was she killed?”
“Yes.”
“I thought so; I told Daisy I thought so. It’s better that the shock should all come at once. She stood it pretty well.”
He spoke as if Daisy’s reaction was the only thing that mattered.
“I got to West Egg by a side road,” he went on, “and left the car in my garage. I don’t think anybody saw us, but of course I can’t be sure.”
I disliked him so much by this time that I didn’t find it necessary to tell him he was wrong.
“Who was the woman?” he inquired.
“Her name was Wilson. Her husband owns the garage. How the devil did it happen?”
“Well, I tried to swing the wheel—” He broke off, and suddenly I guessed at the truth.
“Was Daisy driving?”
“Yes,” he said after a moment, “but of course I’ll say I was. You see, when we left New York she was very nervous and she thought it would steady her to drive—and this woman rushed out at us just as we were passing a car coming the other way. It all happened in a minute, but it seemed to me that she wanted to speak to us, thought we were somebody she knew. Well, first Daisy turned away from the woman toward the other car, and then she lost her nerve and turned back. The second my hand reached the wheel I felt the shock—it must have killed her instantly.”
“It ripped her open—”
“Don’t tell me, old sport.” He winced. “Anyhow—Daisy stepped on it. I tried to make her stop, but she couldn’t, so I pulled on the emergency brake. Then she fell over into my lap and I drove on.
“She’ll be all right tomorrow,” he said presently. “I’m just going to wait here and see if he tries to bother her about that unpleasantness this afternoon. She’s locked herself into her room, and if he tries any brutality she’s going to turn the light out and on again.”
“He won’t touch her,” I said. “He’s not thinking about her.”
“I don’t trust him, old sport.”
“How long are you going to wait?”
“All night, if necessary. Anyhow, till they all go to bed.”
A new point of view occurred to me. Suppose Tom found out that Daisy had been driving. He might think he saw a connection in it—he might think anything. I looked at the house; there were two or three bright windows downstairs and the pink glow from Daisy’s room on the ground floor.
“You wait here,” I said. “I’ll see if there’s any sign of a commotion.”
I walked back along the border of the lawn, traversed the gravel softly, and tiptoed up the veranda steps. The drawing-room curtains were open, and I saw that the room was empty. Crossing the porch where we had dined that June night three months before, I came to a small rectangle of light which I guessed was the pantry window. The blind was drawn, but I found a rift at the sill.
Daisy and Tom were sitting opposite each other at the kitchen table, with a plate of cold fried chicken between them, and two bottles of ale. He was talking intently across the table at her, and in his earnestness his hand had fallen upon and covered her own. Once in a while she looked up at him and nodded in agreement.
They weren’t happy, and neither of them had touched the chicken or the ale—and yet they weren’t unhappy either. There was an unmistakable air of natural intimacy about the picture, and anybody would have said that they were conspiring together.
As I tiptoed from the porch I heard my taxi feeling its way along the dark road toward the house. Gatsby was waiting where I had left him in the drive.
“Is it all quiet up there?” he asked anxiously.
“Yes, it’s all quiet.” I hesitated. “You’d better come home and get some sleep.”
He shook his head.
“I want to wait here till Daisy goes to bed. Good night, old sport.”
He put his hands in his coat pockets and turned back eagerly to his scrutiny of the house, as though my presence marred the sacredness of the vigil. So I walked away and left him standing there in the moonlight—watching over nothing.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The Buchanans’ house floated suddenly toward us through the dark rustling trees. It was a mansion, a cheerful red-and-white Georgian Colonial house, overlooking the bay. The lawn started at the beach and ran toward the front door for a quarter of a mile, jumping over sun-dials and brick walks and burning gardens—finally when it reached the house drifting up the side in bright vines as though from the momentum of its run. My taxi halted at the curb. I got out and stood for a moment on the drive, absorbing the sheer, careless opulence of the place. There was an indefinable air of wealth about it, not just money, but old money, settled and secure, the kind that doesn't need to flaunt itself but permeates everything like a fine dust. The windows were open, letting out a soft golden light and the murmur of voices. It felt like stepping into a different world, a world of ease and privilege that I, a newcomer from the West, could only observe from the periphery. I walked up the steps and rang the bell. A butler, impossibly tall and dressed in a crisp uniform, opened the door. He had the impassive face of someone who had seen everything and was surprised by nothing. He led me through a cool, marble-floored hall into a large, sun-drenched room. The room was high-ceilinged and airy, with French windows opening onto the lawn. The furniture was heavy and expensive, covered in white dust-sheets, giving the room a temporary, almost transient feel, despite its obvious permanence. Or perhaps it was just the heat of the afternoon, shimmering through the open windows, that made everything seem slightly unreal. Two young women were buoyed up as though upon an anchored balloon. They were both in white, and their dresses were rippling and fluttering as if they had just been blown back in after a short flight around the house. I must have stood there for a moment, blinking in the sudden brightness, before one of them, the one I knew, called out. “I’m p-paralyzed with happiness.” It was Daisy. Her voice was a low, thrilling murmur, a voice that the ear follows up and down, as if each speech is an arrangement of notes that will never be played again. It was full of money—that was the inexhaustible charm that rose and fell in it, the jingle of it, the cymbals’ song of it. . . . A beautiful little fool, she had once said, that’s what I hope she’ll be. That’s the best thing a girl can be in this world, a beautiful little fool. The other girl was Jordan Baker, a famous golfer. She lay stretched out on a couch at the other end of the room, her chin raised a little, as if she were balancing something on it. She had a hard, jaunty air about her, a sort of cool, self-possessed beauty that was the antithesis of Daisy’s fragile charm. She didn’t speak, but gave me a slight nod, her eyes, bright and cynical, meeting mine for a brief moment before she looked away. “Gatsby?” demanded Daisy suddenly. “What Gatsby?” I asked, confused. “He’s a neighbor,” she explained, turning her lovely, bored face toward me. “You must know Gatsby.” I shook my head. “I live in West Egg,” I said. “Oh,” she said, and a little ripple of disappointment seemed to pass over her. “I thought you knew Gatsby. He lives in a house that looks like a hotel.” Just then, Tom Buchanan came into the room. He was a sturdy, straw-haired man of thirty with a rather hard mouth and a supercilious manner. Two shining arrogant eyes had established dominance over his face and gave him the appearance of always leaning aggressively forward. Not even the effeminate swank of his riding clothes could hide the enormous power of that body—he seemed to fill the doorway, his shoulders broad, his chest deep. He had been a national figure in a way, one of those men who reach such an acute limited excellence at twenty-one that everything afterward savors of anticlimax. His speaking voice, a gruff husky tenor, added to the impression of fractiousness he conveyed. There was a touch of paternal contempt in it, even toward people he liked—and there were fewer of them than had been the case ten years ago. “Hello, Nick,” he said, without any particular warmth. He looked me over with an appraising glance, as if measuring my worth, or perhaps just my size. “You’re here for the summer, aren’t you?” “I am,” I said. “I’ve rented a small house in West Egg.” “West Egg?” he scoffed. “That’s the less fashionable side, isn’t it?” He didn’t wait for an answer, but turned his attention back to the women. “What are you doing?” he demanded. “We’re just sitting here,” said Daisy, her voice trailing off. “You ought to be doing something,” he said, his voice booming slightly. He picked up a book from a table and looked at the title. “’The Rise of the Colored Empires’ by Goddard,” he read aloud. “This is a good book, everyone ought to read it. The idea is if we don’t look out the white race will be utterly submerged. It’s all scientific stuff; it’s been proved.” Jordan Baker sat up a little. “Tom’s getting very profound,” she remarked, with a hint of mockery in her voice. “He reads deep books with long words in them.” Tom frowned. “It’s up to us, who are the dominant race, to watch out or these other races will get control of things.” “We’ve got to beat them down,” whispered Daisy, winking at me with an absurd, charming little grin. Tom was not amused. “You’ve read it, haven’t you, Tom?” she asked innocently. “On the contrary,” said Tom, “I hate that word hulking—even in kidding.” “Hulking,” I repeated. “That’s what I am,” he said. The conversation drifted aimlessly for a while, touching on various trivialities, the heat, the latest gossip, the endless round of parties. I felt increasingly like an observer, a fly on the wall in this gilded cage. There was a restlessness about them, a sort of desperate gaiety that felt forced, brittle. It was as if they were constantly searching for something, some elusive excitement, to fill the vast emptiness of their lives. The phone rang, and Tom left the room to answer it. As soon as he was gone, Daisy leaned toward me, her eyes wide. “Did you see Tom’s eyes?” she whispered. “They’re so… intense.” Jordan Baker yawned delicately. “He’s just being Tom,” she said, her voice flat. Daisy sighed. “I don’t know what to do,” she said, her voice barely audible. “I don’t know what to do.” There was a profound sadness in her voice, a sense of helplessness that was startling. It was clear that her life, despite its outward perfection, was far from happy. The phone call seemed to be a source of tension. When Tom returned, he was visibly agitated. He paced the room, his hands clasped behind his back. “It was the garage,” he said, his voice clipped. “Something about a car.” He didn’t elaborate, but the air in the room had changed, becoming heavy with unspoken things. Daisy watched him, her face pale. Jordan Baker had closed her eyes again, retreating into her own world. I felt the awkwardness of the situation, the palpable tension between husband and wife, the silent complicity of the friend. It was a glimpse behind the glittering facade, a hint of the rot that lay beneath the surface of their privileged lives. I wanted to leave, to escape the oppressive atmosphere, but I was trapped, a guest in their elaborate, unhappy drama. The afternoon wore on, the sun sinking lower in the sky, casting long shadows across the lawn. The conversation became more strained, punctuated by long silences. I realized that I had stumbled into a world of complex, unhappy relationships, a world where wealth and privilege did not guarantee contentment. It was a world I was only beginning to understand, a world that would soon draw me deeper into its tangled web of desires, illusions, and betrayals. The house, which had seemed so cheerful and inviting from the outside, now felt like a prison, holding its inhabitants captive in their own gilded misery. The rustling trees outside seemed to whisper secrets, secrets of a past that refused to stay buried, secrets that would eventually unravel the carefully constructed lives of the people within these walls. I looked at Daisy, her face a mask of forced gaiety, and at Tom, his eyes hard and restless, and at Jordan, cool and detached. They were all searching for something, something they couldn't find, something that perhaps didn't exist. And I, the innocent bystander, was about to be caught in the crosscurrents of their desperate search.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The Buchanans’ house floated suddenly toward us through the dark rustling trees. Daisy was home. She came out on the porch in a dress of white, and stood there like an angry ghost, her eyes flashing between Gatsby and me. But she said nothing, and we went in. Tom was waiting for us in the hall. He was pale and his eyes were fixed on us with a strained, questioning expression. He said nothing, but his look was enough. He knew. He must have known all along. He led us into the drawing-room, where the others were gathered. Jordan was there, and a few other people I didn’t know. They were all talking in low voices, and the air was thick with tension. Tom went over to Daisy and spoke to her in a low voice. She nodded, her face expressionless. Then Tom turned to us. “We’d better have some supper,” he said, his voice unnaturally loud. “We’ve had a long day.” We sat down at the table, but no one ate. The food was there, but it might as well have been made of stone. The silence was broken only by the clinking of silverware and the occasional cough. After a while, Tom stood up. “I think we should all go to bed,” he said. “It’s been a trying day.” We all agreed, and we went upstairs. I said good night to Jordan at her door, and then I went to my own room. I couldn’t sleep. I kept thinking about what had happened. About Myrtle, and the accident. And about Daisy and Gatsby. I lay awake for a long time, listening to the sounds of the house. Finally, I got up and went to the window. I looked out at the dark garden. I could see the lights of Gatsby’s house in the distance. I wondered what he was doing. I wondered if he was thinking about Daisy. I wondered if he was thinking about me. I stood there for a long time, just looking out at the night. Then I heard a sound. It was a car. It was coming up the drive. I knew it was Gatsby. I went downstairs and opened the door. He was standing there, in the moonlight. He looked pale and tired. “Is she all right?” he asked. “Is Daisy all right?” “Yes,” I said. “She’s all right.” He nodded, and for a moment, he just stood there, looking at me. Then he said, “I’m going to wait here. Just in case.” “In case of what?” I asked. “In case he tries to hurt her,” he said. “Tom.” I looked at him. He was serious. He was going to stay there all night, just to make sure Daisy was safe. I didn’t know what to say. I just stood there, looking at him. Finally, I said, “All right. I’ll leave you to it.” I went back inside and closed the door. I went upstairs to my room, but I still couldn’t sleep. I kept thinking about Gatsby, standing out there in the dark, watching over Daisy. I thought about how much he loved her. And I thought about how much trouble he was in. I lay there for a long time, thinking. Finally, I drifted off to sleep.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: The Buchanans’ house floated suddenly toward us through the dark rustling trees. Tom stopped the car. “Daisy’s home,” he remarked. As we got out he thought for a moment and then added, “You two start on in to supper.” “In a minute,” I said. I wanted to get out and walk eastward down the road and disappear into the darkness. I felt an unpleasantness in the air, a pervading harshness that hadn’t been there before. Or perhaps I had felt it all the time but had too much vitality to be affected by it now. “Well, suit yourself,” Tom remarked. “Daisy’s home.” As he said it she came out to the porch. There was a light in the hall, but it was dark outside, so that they were silhouettes only, —he towering beside her. They stood there for a moment and then she turned and went inside again. “He’s not coming up,” said Jordan beside me. “Neither are you.” Jordan went up the steps and disappeared. I waited, and sure enough, in a moment I heard the familiar “Ah-h-h!” from the butler’s pantry at the sound of the electric bell. The butler came out and he and Tom talked for a moment, looking up and down the drive. I looked at the house, glowing now with reflected gold, and then I knew that Daisy was sitting in a room somewhere, alone, and that the lamp beside her glowed on a pile of unused clothes. Probably it had been twenty minutes before I could decide what to do. I wanted to go to work with my hands, scrub the floor, rake the leaves, dig a garden—any activity that promised a definite clean perspective at the end. Instead I waited until an hour had passed after we got back and then circulated among the three or four automobiles that waited in the drive outside. The night had made a sharp difference in the weather and there was an autumn flavour in the air. The chauffeur came out, carrying a blanket and the ladder, and mounted to the roof to tidy up her hair—that is, Jordan’s. She was within a hundred miles of my house, and I’d told her I would call her up. And I did. I waited outside the gates for a little while and then started on foot toward West Egg, half an hour’s walk from the village. It was dark now, and the moon was shining. I was walking along the road when I heard a car coming behind me. I stepped aside and it went by. It was a big car, a coupé. I knew it was Gatsby’s. I waited until it was out of sight and then I went on. I was almost to the village when I heard another car coming. This one was going the other way, toward West Egg. It was a small car, a roadster. events.title: Nick's Anxious Vigil and Gatsby's Despair
detailed_summary: Nick spends a sleepless night disturbed by a foghorn and troubling thoughts, feeling an urgent need to warn Gatsby.
He goes to Gatsby's house at dawn, finding the door open and Gatsby inside, looking exhausted and dejected.
Gatsby reports that Daisy came to the window briefly during the night but then turned off the light, offering no resolution.
Nick observes the immense, dusty, and unused state of Gatsby's mansion as they search for cigarettes, highlighting its emptiness.
They sit smoking by the open windows.
Nick advises Gatsby to leave town immediately, suggesting Atlantic City or Montreal, fearing Gatsby's car will be traced back to the accident.
Gatsby refuses, stating he cannot leave until he knows Daisy's decision, clinging to a final hope.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I couldn’t sleep all night; a foghorn was groaning incessantly on the Sound, and I tossed half-sick between grotesque reality and savage, frightening dreams.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He was clutching at some last hope and I couldn’t bear to shake him free.

events.text_segment:
I couldn’t sleep all night; a foghorn was groaning incessantly on the Sound, and I tossed half-sick between grotesque reality and savage, frightening dreams. Toward dawn I heard a taxi go up Gatsby’s drive, and immediately I jumped out of bed and began to dress—I felt that I had something to tell him, something to warn him about, and morning would be too late.
Crossing his lawn, I saw that his front door was still open and he was leaning against a table in the hall, heavy with dejection or sleep.
“Nothing happened,” he said wanly. “I waited, and about four o’clock she came to the window and stood there for a minute and then turned out the light.”
His house had never seemed so enormous to me as it did that night when we hunted through the great rooms for cigarettes. We pushed aside curtains that were like pavilions, and felt over innumerable feet of dark wall for electric light switches—once I tumbled with a sort of splash upon the keys of a ghostly piano. There was an inexplicable amount of dust everywhere, and the rooms were musty, as though they hadn’t been aired for many days. I found the humidor on an unfamiliar table, with two stale, dry cigarettes inside. Throwing open the French windows of the drawing-room, we sat smoking out into the darkness.
“You ought to go away,” I said. “It’s pretty certain they’ll trace your car.”
“Go away now, old sport?”
“Go to Atlantic City for a week, or up to Montreal.”
He wouldn’t consider it. He couldn’t possibly leave Daisy until he knew what she was going to do. He was clutching at some last hope and I couldn’t bear to shake him free.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I couldn’t sleep all night; a foghorn was groaning incessantly on the Sound, and I tossed half-sick between grotesque reality and savage, frightening dreams. Toward dawn I got up and dressed in the dark, and while I waited for some light I walked down to the beach and stood for a while in the water. It was dark here too, but a sliver of milky glass was building up in the east with the great drive of the earth. I went on to the house at the first gray glimmer, but the door was open and I got to him before he went to bed. He was standing in the hall, dusty in working clothes, when the door opened, but he moved just as I came in. I can’t shake the feeling that he was standing there for some time, waiting. ‘Hello, Nick,’ he said. ‘I’ve been waiting for you. I thought you’d come.’ He looked at me sideways—and I knew why. There was a strained, unfamiliar look of desperation about him. ‘It couldn’t be helped,’ he said. ‘She came to the window and stood there for a minute and then turned out the light.’ We went in and sat down. I wanted to ask him what he was going to do, but I didn’t. We sat there for a long time without speaking. The room was full of dust and cobwebs, and the furniture was covered with sheets. It looked like a tomb. We looked for cigarettes together, and finally found a carton of them in the library. We took them back to the living-room and sat down again. The windows were open, and the air was cool and damp. ‘You ought to go away,’ I said. ‘It’s time you went away.’ ‘Go away now, old sport?’ ‘Go away for a week or two. To Atlantic City, or Montreal.’ He shook his head. ‘It wouldn’t do any good. I can’t leave her, Nick. I can’t leave her until I know what she’s going to do.’

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: I couldn’t sleep all night; a foghorn was groaning incessantly on the Sound, and I tossed half-sick between grotesque reality and savage, frightening dreams. The sheet was crumpled where I had made a sudden, convulsive movement, and I lay there, staring at the ceiling, the events of the day before replaying themselves with horrifying clarity. The hot, humid afternoon, the tension in the Plaza suite, the reckless drive home, the sickening thud, the ghastly spectacle by the road, the casual cruelty of Tom, the desperate, watchful silence of Gatsby. It all swam before my eyes, a chaotic, violent tableau that mocked the carefully constructed facade of their lives. The foghorn seemed to mourn not just for ships lost at sea, but for the wreckage of human lives scattered along the shore of the Sound. I saw Myrtle Wilson’s face, or what was left of it, and the vacant, stunned look in Michaelis’s eyes. I saw Daisy’s beautiful, careless face, and Tom’s hard, possessive mouth. And Gatsby, standing guard outside the house, a solitary, pathetic figure clinging to a hope that was now surely dead. The dreams were worse, populated by distorted figures from the party, their laughter turning to screams, their elegant movements becoming clumsy, violent lurches. I felt a profound, physical nausea, a revulsion not just at the accident itself, but at the moral emptiness that had made it possible. The East, with its frantic energy and its glittering, hollow people, seemed to press in on me, suffocating me with its corruption. I wanted to shout, to wake them all up, to force them to confront the horror they had created, but I knew it would be useless. They were insulated by their money, their privilege, their utter lack of imagination. As the first grey light filtered through the window, I felt a cold certainty settle over me: this was not my world. I was an outsider, a spectator who had been drawn too close to the flame and was now scorched by its heat. The foghorn finally fell silent, but the silence was heavy with the weight of what had happened, and what was yet to come. I knew I had to do something, but I didn't know what. The morning brought no clarity, only a dull ache and the persistent, sickening smell of death that seemed to cling to the air.

events.title: Gatsby Recounts His Early Romance with Daisy
detailed_summary: Gatsby, feeling his persona shattered after the confrontation with Tom, confides in Nick about his past, specifically focusing on Daisy.
He describes Daisy as the first 'nice' girl he had ever known, encountered while he was an officer at Camp Taylor.
He was captivated by her beauty, her magnificent house, and the aura of wealth, mystery, and romance surrounding her life.
He notes the casualness with which she inhabited this world, so different from his own experience.
Gatsby found Daisy more desirable because many other men had loved her, feeling their emotional presence in her house.
He acknowledges his presence in her world was accidental; as a penniless man without a past, his uniform provided temporary cover.
He pursued Daisy intensely, taking what he could, aware he had no 'right' to her.
He admits he misled Daisy, letting her believe he belonged to her social stratum and could provide for her, though he couldn't.
Despite intending a temporary affair, Gatsby found himself deeply committed, as if following a 'grail'.
He realized the profound impact Daisy, as an extraordinary 'nice' girl, had on him, leaving him feeling empty yet married to her when she returned to her wealthy life.
He recalls their reunion two days later, feeling breathless and betrayed, yet overwhelmingly aware of the allure of her youth, wealth, and voice, which seemed to imprison and preserve her.
Gatsby confesses his surprise at falling in love and how his ambitions seemed less important than sharing his plans with Daisy.
He describes their last, tranquil afternoon together before he went to war, emphasizing their silent, profound connection and intimacy.

events.text_segment:
It was this night that he told me the strange story of his youth with Dan Cody—told it to me because “Jay Gatsby” had broken up like glass against Tom’s hard malice, and the long secret extravaganza was played out. I think that he would have acknowledged anything now, without reserve, but he wanted to talk about Daisy.
She was the first “nice” girl he had ever known. In various unrevealed capacities he had come in contact with such people, but always with indiscernible barbed wire between. He found her excitingly desirable. He went to her house, at first with other officers from Camp Taylor, then alone. It amazed him—he had never been in such a beautiful house before. But what gave it an air of breathless intensity, was that Daisy lived there—it was as casual a thing to her as his tent out at camp was to him. There was a ripe mystery about it, a hint of bedrooms upstairs more beautiful and cool than other bedrooms, of gay and radiant activities taking place through its corridors, and of romances that were not musty and laid away already in lavender but fresh and breathing and redolent of this year’s shining motorcars and of dances whose flowers were scarcely withered. It excited him, too, that many men had already loved Daisy—it increased her value in his eyes. He felt their presence all about the house, pervading the air with the shades and echoes of still vibrant emotions.
But he knew that he was in Daisy’s house by a colossal accident. However glorious might be his future as Jay Gatsby, he was at present a penniless young man without a past, and at any moment the invisible cloak of his uniform might slip from his shoulders. So he made the most of his time. He took what he could get, ravenously and unscrupulously—eventually he took Daisy one still October night, took her because he had no real right to touch her hand.
He might have despised himself, for he had certainly taken her under false pretences. I don’t mean that he had traded on his phantom millions, but he had deliberately given Daisy a sense of security; he let her believe that he was a person from much the same strata as herself—that he was fully able to take care of her. As a matter of fact, he had no such facilities—he had no comfortable family standing behind him, and he was liable at the whim of an impersonal government to be blown anywhere about the world.
But he didn’t despise himself and it didn’t turn out as he had imagined. He had intended, probably, to take what he could and go—but now he found that he had committed himself to the following of a grail. He knew that Daisy was extraordinary, but he didn’t realize just how extraordinary a “nice” girl could be. She vanished into her rich house, into her rich, full life, leaving Gatsby—nothing. He felt married to her, that was all.
When they met again, two days later, it was Gatsby who was breathless, who was, somehow, betrayed. Her porch was bright with the bought luxury of star-shine; the wicker of the settee squeaked fashionably as she turned toward him and he kissed her curious and lovely mouth. She had caught a cold, and it made her voice huskier and more charming than ever, and Gatsby was overwhelmingly aware of the youth and mystery that wealth imprisons and preserves, of the freshness of many clothes, and of Daisy, gleaming like silver, safe and proud above the hot struggles of the poor.
“I can’t describe to you how surprised I was to find out I loved her, old sport. I even hoped for a while that she’d throw me over, but she didn’t, because she was in love with me too. She thought I knew a lot because I knew different things from her… Well, there I was, way off my ambitions, getting deeper in love every minute, and all of a sudden I didn’t care. What was the use of doing great things if I could have a better time telling her what I was going to do?”
On the last afternoon before he went abroad, he sat with Daisy in his arms for a long, silent time. It was a cold fall day, with fire in the room and her cheeks flushed. Now and then she moved and he changed his arm a little, and once he kissed her dark shining hair. The afternoon had made them tranquil for a while, as if to give them a deep memory for the long parting the next day promised. They had never been closer in their month of love, nor communicated more profoundly one with another, than when she brushed silent lips against his coat’s shoulder or when he touched the end of her fingers, gently, as though she were asleep.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: It was this night that he told me the strange story of his youth with Dan Cody—told it to me because “Jay Gatsby” had broken up like glass against Tom’s hard malice, and the long secret extravaganza was played out. He came alive to me, delivered suddenly from the womb of his purposeless splendor. 'I cannot tell you how much I suffered,' he said. 'I saw the unmistakable expression of an educated person, and I knew I had found what I had been looking for—the first 'nice' girl he had ever known. She was a young girl, a year and a half older than I, and she lived in a beautiful house on the edge of the town. She was dressed in white, and her face was lovely and exciting. I don't know what it was about her—she had a way of making you feel that she was a part of you, that you belonged to her. She was the first girl I had ever known who was not afraid of me, who was not afraid of anything. She was casual, and she was rich, and she was beautiful. Her house was full of officers, and she was the most popular girl in town. There was a feverish look in her eyes, as if she had been crying, and I knew that she had been loved before. I felt the pressure of the other men's lives, their loves and their desires, in the very air of her house. He had been in America only two years, and he was a penniless young man without a past, and the uniform he wore was an accident, only the natural consequence of the unsettled times. He let her believe that he was a person from the same stratum of society as herself—that he was a man of family and of wealth. He knew that he could not provide for her, but he let her think that he could. He had intended to take what he could and go—but he had never been so deeply committed to a woman before. He felt married to her, that was all. When she went away she carried with her the seal of his approval—when she came back she was a stranger. She was an extraordinary 'nice' girl, and she had a profound effect on him. He felt empty, as if he had lost a part of himself. Two days later she was back in Louisville, and I saw her again. I was breathless, and I felt betrayed. But I was also overwhelmingly aware of her youth, her wealth, and her voice. Her voice was full of money—that was the inexhaustible charm that rose and fell in it, the jingle of it, the cymbals' song of it.... High in a white palace the king's daughter, the golden girl.... He had never expected to fall in love, and it surprised him. His ambitions seemed less important than sharing his plans with her. They spent their last afternoon together in a quiet place, and they didn't say much. But they understood each other perfectly. It was the most intimate afternoon he had ever spent with anyone.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: It was this night that he told me the strange story of his youth with Dan Cody—told it to me because “Jay Gatsby” had broken up like glass against Tom’s hard malice, and the long secret extravaganza was played out. He told it to me while we waited for the taxi, and his eyes, which had been brooding on the raw, cold night, were now turned inward upon himself. His parents were shiftless and unsuccessful farm people—his imagination had never really accepted them as his parents at all. The truth was that Jay Gatsby of West Egg, Long Island, sprang from his Platonic conception of himself. He was a son of God—a phrase which, if it means anything, means just that—and he must be about His Father’s business, the service of a vast, vulgar, and meretricious beauty. So he invented just the sort of Jay Gatsby that a seventeen-year-old boy would be likely to invent, and to this conception he was faithful to the end. For over a year he had been beating his way along the south shore of Lake Superior as a clam digger and a salmon fisher, but he knew that he was in training for something else, something big. He accepted a few chores that brought him food and a bed, but his heart was in a constant, turbulent riot. The most grotesque and fantastic conceits haunted him in his bed at night. A universe of ineffable gaudiness spun itself out in his brain while the clock ticked on the washstand and the moon soaked with wet light his tangled clothes upon the floor. Each night he added to the pattern of his fancies until drowsiness closed down upon some vivid scene, and he fell asleep with the knowledge that he was in training for one of the roles that he was creating for himself on the periphery of his imagination. Then came the man who changed his life forever. Dan Cody, a fifty-year-old pioneer debauchee, who had made a fortune in the Yukon and then restlessly dissipated it on the high seas. He was a product of the Nevada silver fields, of the Yukon, of every rush for metal since seventy-five. The transactions in Montana copper that made him many times a millionaire found him physically robust but on the verge of soft-mindedness, and, living alone in the Houseboat, he was inordinately active. He was a large, florid man, with a hard, jaunty body and a rather soft, subjectless voice. James Gatz was seventeen, and a ragged, hard-working boy who had been loafing along the beach that afternoon in a torn green jersey and a pair of canvas pants. He saw Cody’s yacht, the Tuolomee, anchored in the bay, and rowed out to warn him about an impending storm. Cody was in a temper, and he was drunk, but he took a fancy to the boy. He asked him where he came from, and what he did. James Gatz told him he was from North Dakota, and that he was a clam digger. Cody liked his spirit, and the next morning he took him on as his steward. It was at this point that James Gatz officially became Jay Gatsby. He had been waiting for a moment like this, a chance to shed his old identity and step into the one he had created in his dreams. He told Cody his name was Jay Gatsby, and Cody, perhaps too drunk or too indifferent to question it, accepted it. For five years, Gatsby traveled with Dan Cody on the Tuolomee. They sailed three times around the continent. It was a life of luxury and excess, a world of yachts, women, and heavy drinking. Cody was a heavy drinker, and Gatsby saw firsthand the destructive power of alcohol. It was a lesson he never forgot, and it was why he himself drank so little. He was there to look after Cody, to keep him out of trouble, and to learn. Cody was Gatsby’s education in the ways of the wealthy, the careless, and the powerful. He saw how money was spent, how relationships were formed and broken, and how the rich lived. He was exposed to a world far removed from the poverty of his youth. He learned about business, about the stock market, about the superficiality that often accompanied great wealth. He was Cody’s confidant, his assistant, his protector. He was everything but his son. Cody was involved with a woman named Ella Kaye, a newspaper woman who came aboard the yacht one May day in Boston and who was wherever Cody went for the rest of his life. It was Ella Kaye who inherited Cody’s money—a cool quarter of a million dollars—when he died a week later in Boston. Gatsby was left with nothing but a legacy of five thousand dollars, which he never received because Ella Kaye found a legal way to appropriate it. This experience solidified Gatsby’s determination to become wealthy himself. He had seen the money, lived the life, and then had it snatched away. He understood the power of money and the ruthlessness of those who possessed it. The five years with Cody were his apprenticeship, his preparation for the life he was determined to build. He learned how to act like a rich man, how to navigate their world, and how to pursue wealth with single-minded intensity. He didn't tell me all this in a single, coherent narrative. It came out in fragments, punctuated by long silences, as the taxi carried us through the dark streets. He spoke of Cody with a mixture of admiration and resentment, of the life on the yacht with a kind of wistful detachment. He was no longer the confident, almost arrogant host of the parties; he was James Gatz again, the boy who had dreamed of a better life and had pursued it with relentless energy. The story of Dan Cody was the missing piece, the explanation for the elaborate facade of Jay Gatsby. It showed the foundation upon which the dream was built, a foundation laid in the turbulent waters of Lake Superior and solidified over five years of restless wandering. It explained the source of his initial capital, the contacts he might have made, and the education he received in the ways of the world he so desperately wanted to conquer. It was the story of how a poor boy from North Dakota transformed himself into the enigmatic millionaire of West Egg, a transformation driven by ambition, fueled by a dream, and shaped by the mentorship of a dissolute millionaire. And now, that carefully constructed identity, built over years of effort and secrecy, had been shattered by the brutal reality of Tom Buchanan's world. The long secret extravaganza was indeed played out, leaving behind only the fragments of a broken dream and the raw, vulnerable truth of James Gatz.

events.title: War, Oxford, Daisy's Impatience, and Gatsby's Return
detailed_summary: Gatsby performed well in the war, reaching the rank of Major, but complications sent him to Oxford afterwards instead of home.
Daisy's letters became nervously desperate; she felt external pressures and needed Gatsby's reassurance.
Her world of privilege, parties, and social expectations pushed her towards making a decision about her life.
She resumed dating multiple men, caught between her feelings for Gatsby and the need for immediate security.
Tom Buchanan arrived, representing stability and wealth, flattering Daisy.
She married Tom, a decision likely involving both struggle and relief; Gatsby received her letter while at Oxford.
As dawn breaks at Gatsby's house, he insists to Nick that Daisy never loved Tom, or only briefly, claiming her confession was coerced.
Gatsby makes the enigmatic comment that the affair 'was just personal'.
After the war, penniless, Gatsby travelled to Louisville while Tom and Daisy were on their honeymoon.
He revisited places he and Daisy shared, finding the city imbued with melancholy beauty due to her absence.
Leaving Louisville by train, he felt he hadn't searched hard enough, that he was leaving her behind.
He watched the city fade, feeling he had lost the best part of his past forever.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He did extraordinarily well in the war.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But it was all going by too fast now for his blurred eyes and he knew that he had lost that part of it, the freshest and the best, forever.

events.text_segment:
He did extraordinarily well in the war. He was a captain before he went to the front, and following the Argonne battles he got his majority and the command of the divisional machine-guns. After the armistice he tried frantically to get home, but some complication or misunderstanding sent him to Oxford instead. He was worried now—there was a quality of nervous despair in Daisy’s letters. She didn’t see why he couldn’t come. She was feeling the pressure of the world outside, and she wanted to see him and feel his presence beside her and be reassured that she was doing the right thing after all.
For Daisy was young and her artificial world was redolent of orchids and pleasant, cheerful snobbery and orchestras which set the rhythm of the year, summing up the sadness and suggestiveness of life in new tunes. All night the saxophones wailed the hopeless comment of the “Beale Street Blues” while a hundred pairs of golden and silver slippers shuffled the shining dust. At the grey tea hour there were always rooms that throbbed incessantly with this low, sweet fever, while fresh faces drifted here and there like rose petals blown by the sad horns around the floor.
Through this twilight universe Daisy began to move again with the season; suddenly she was again keeping half a dozen dates a day with half a dozen men, and drowsing asleep at dawn with the beads and chiffon of an evening-dress tangled among dying orchids on the floor beside her bed. And all the time something within her was crying for a decision. She wanted her life shaped now, immediately—and the decision must be made by some force—of love, of money, of unquestionable practicality—that was close at hand.
That force took shape in the middle of spring with the arrival of Tom Buchanan. There was a wholesome bulkiness about his person and his position, and Daisy was flattered. Doubtless there was a certain struggle and a certain relief. The letter reached Gatsby while he was still at Oxford.
It was dawn now on Long Island and we went about opening the rest of the windows downstairs, filling the house with grey-turning, gold-turning light. The shadow of a tree fell abruptly across the dew and ghostly birds began to sing among the blue leaves. There was a slow, pleasant movement in the air, scarcely a wind, promising a cool, lovely day.
“I don’t think she ever loved him.” Gatsby turned around from a window and looked at me challengingly. “You must remember, old sport, she was very excited this afternoon. He told her those things in a way that frightened her—that made it look as if I was some kind of cheap sharper. And the result was she hardly knew what she was saying.”
He sat down gloomily.
“Of course she might have loved him just for a minute, when they were first married—and loved me more even then, do you see?”
Suddenly he came out with a curious remark.
“In any case,” he said, “it was just personal.”
What could you make of that, except to suspect some intensity in his conception of the affair that couldn’t be measured?
He came back from France when Tom and Daisy were still on their wedding trip, and made a miserable but irresistible journey to Louisville on the last of his army pay. He stayed there a week, walking the streets where their footsteps had clicked together through the November night and revisiting the out-of-the-way places to which they had driven in her white car. Just as Daisy’s house had always seemed to him more mysterious and gay than other houses, so his idea of the city itself, even though she was gone from it, was pervaded with a melancholy beauty.
He left feeling that if he had searched harder, he might have found her—that he was leaving her behind. The day-coach—he was penniless now—was hot. He went out to the open vestibule and sat down on a folding-chair, and the station slid away and the backs of unfamiliar buildings moved by. Then out into the spring fields, where a yellow trolley raced them for a minute with people in it who might once have seen the pale magic of her face along the casual street.
The track curved and now it was going away from the sun, which, as it sank lower, seemed to spread itself in benediction over the vanishing city where she had drawn her breath. He stretched out his hand desperately as if to snatch only a wisp of air, to save a fragment of the spot that she had made lovely for him. But it was all going by too fast now for his blurred eyes and he knew that he had lost that part of it, the freshest and the best, forever.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: He did extraordinarily well in the war. Major Jay Gatsby, as he was known then, emerged from the trenches of the Great War not just alive, but decorated, a figure of quiet competence and undeniable bravery. The novel hints at this period as a crucial turning point, a crucible that forged the man who would later build his opulent empire on West Egg. While the details are sparse, filtered through Gatsby’s own carefully constructed narrative and Nick Carraway’s piecing together of the truth, the fact of his distinguished service is presented as one of the few solid, verifiable elements of his mysterious past. He carried the proof with him – the medals, the Distinguished Service Cross from Montenegro, the Croix de Guerre from France. He showed them to Nick one afternoon, a tangible counterpoint to the wild rumors that swirled around him. These weren't the fabrications of a fantasist; they were official recognition of courage under fire, of leadership in the face of death. The war, for Gatsby, was perhaps the first time he truly felt seen, truly felt valued, not for his background or his wealth (which he didn't have), but for his inherent qualities – his resilience, his nerve, his ability to perform under extreme pressure. It was a stark contrast to the aimless drifting of his youth as James Gatz, the boy from North Dakota with grand dreams but no clear path. The military provided structure, purpose, and a brutal, undeniable reality that stripped away pretense. In the chaos and camaraderie of the front lines, social distinctions blurred. A man was judged by his actions, his courage, his ability to lead and survive. Gatsby, it seems, excelled in this environment. He rose through the ranks, a testament to his ambition and capability. The war offered him a glimpse of a different world, a world where merit could elevate a man, where heroism was recognized and rewarded. It was a world far removed from the rigid social hierarchies of the America he knew, particularly the old money circles he would later desperately try to penetrate. Following the armistice, Gatsby had the unique opportunity to attend Oxford for five months, a privilege granted to officers. This brief sojourn in the hallowed halls of one of the world's most prestigious universities further broadened his horizons. It exposed him to a level of culture and sophistication that he had only dreamed of. It was a fleeting taste of the life he aspired to, a life of ease, learning, and established status. This period, though short, likely solidified his resolve to acquire the trappings of that world, to bridge the gap between the humble origins of James Gatz and the sophisticated image of Jay Gatsby. The war and the subsequent time at Oxford were transformative experiences. They took the raw ambition of the young man and refined it, giving him a veneer of experience and accomplishment that he would later leverage. They provided him with stories, with credentials (the medals, the Oxford connection), that lent a degree of credibility to the persona he was building. Yet, the war also represented a profound disruption. It was a period of intense living, followed by a return to a world that felt both familiar and irrevocably changed. The post-war years, the Roaring Twenties, were characterized by a frantic energy, a desire to forget the horrors of the trenches and embrace pleasure and prosperity. Gatsby, like many of his generation, carried the weight of that experience, even as he threw himself into the pursuit of wealth and the past. His success in the war, his survival and decoration, must have instilled in him a powerful belief in his own capacity to achieve the impossible. If he could face down death and emerge a hero, surely he could conquer the social barriers and economic challenges that stood between him and his dream – the dream embodied by Daisy. The discipline, the strategic thinking, the sheer force of will required to succeed in combat were skills he undoubtedly transferred to his post-war endeavors. Building his vast network, orchestrating his elaborate parties, accumulating his immense fortune – these were campaigns in their own right, requiring planning, risk-taking, and a relentless focus on the objective. The war, therefore, was not just a chapter in his life; it was a foundational experience that shaped his character, fueled his ambition, and provided him with the conviction that he could, through sheer effort and will, bend reality to his desires. It was the crucible where James Gatz began to truly become Jay Gatsby, the man who believed in the green light, the future that yearned before us.

I can’t explain to you how I love that man—when I first met him it was in August, 1918, in France. He was part of the American Expeditionary Force. He was delayed in the Argonne Forest for two weeks, and when he got back to Louisville she was gone. He stayed there a week, walking the streets where their footsteps had fallen, and when he left it seemed to him that the city itself was gone, gone wherever she was.
