Then he gave his name as Mr. Lee, and I recognized the elaborate formality of a man who had been drunk all afternoon. I knew I had met him somewhere before, but couldn’t remember where. He was calling from a ditch beside the road, in a borrowed car, and he wanted to know if I’d help him get the darn thing out. I went out. The ditch was between the driveway and the road, and the car was in it, nose down, with the rear in the air. It was a new coupé which had left Gatsby’s drive not two minutes before. The owner of the coupé was an old man, his eyes dilated a little by drink. He was sitting in the rear of the car, looking with intense concentration at the wheel. “To be perfectly frank,” he said, “I don’t know who it was that drove me down here. I just got into the thing and started off.” I explained that he was in the ditch. “Ditch?” he asked blankly. “Yes, the ditch alongside the road.” “Certainly I was in the ditch,” he said, with suitable indignation. “The man with the name of Lee was driving.” “That’s me,” said the man with the name of Lee, appearing from the crowd. “I was driving. I take full responsibility for the accident.” “You were not driving,” said the owner. “You were sitting beside me. I was driving.” “I’m sorry, but I wasn’t even in the car.” “You can’t hide that old sport,” cried Gatsby, who had come out to see what the commotion was. “You were in the car. I saw you.” “I was not,” insisted the man with the name of Lee. “I was in the library all night, looking at the books. I’m Owl Eyes. I told you I was Owl Eyes.” The owner of the car looked at him blankly. “Owl Eyes? What are you talking about?” “The books!” cried Owl Eyes, waving his arms. “They’re real! I showed them to you! Remember?” The owner shook his head slowly. “I don’t remember anything,” he muttered. “I’ve been drunk for about a week now.” The crowd around the car began to laugh. It was a strange, detached laughter, as if the accident were a scene in a play they were watching. Nobody seemed particularly concerned about the car or the people in it. They were just amused by the spectacle of two drunk men arguing about who was driving a wrecked car. It was another glimpse into the bizarre, careless world that Gatsby inhabited, a world where reality seemed to bend and break under the weight of excess and indifference. I stood there, a sober observer in a sea of tipsy onlookers, feeling the familiar mix of fascination and unease that Gatsby's parties always inspired. The moon hung high, casting long shadows, and the music from the house still drifted faintly on the night air, a counterpoint to the absurdity unfolding before me.

events.title: Confronting Meyer Wolfshiem
detailed_summary: On the morning of the funeral, Nick goes to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem personally.
He finds Wolfshiem's office, marked 'The Swastika Holding Company'.
Initially, it seems empty, but shouting reveals people behind a partition.
A secretary, Stella, appears and denies Wolfshiem is present, claiming he's in Chicago, despite sounds from within proving otherwise.
Nick insists on seeing Wolfshiem, mentioning Gatsby.
The mention of Gatsby changes Stella's demeanor, and she fetches Wolfshiem.
Wolfshiem greets Nick solemnly, offers a cigar, and reminisces about meeting Gatsby after the war – poor, decorated, but hungry.
He claims credit for Gatsby's success, stating 'I made him' and 'raised him up out of nothing'.
Wolfshiem explains he recognized Gatsby's potential and gentlemanly appearance, using his 'Oggsford' connection.
He boasts of their close association.
Nick asks Wolfshiem to attend the funeral as Gatsby's closest friend.
Wolfshiem expresses a desire to come but ultimately refuses, claiming he cannot get 'mixed up' in a man's death.
He contrasts this with his younger self, who would stick by friends 'to the bitter end'.
Seeing Wolfshiem's determination, Nick prepares to leave.
Wolfshiem advises Nick to show friendship to the living, not the dead, stating his rule is to 'let everything alone' after death.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The morning of the funeral I went up to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem; I couldn’t seem to reach him any other way.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “After that my own rule is to let everything alone.”

events.text_segment:
The morning of the funeral I went up to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem; I couldn’t seem to reach him any other way. The door that I pushed open, on the advice of an elevator boy, was marked “The Swastika Holding Company,” and at first there didn’t seem to be anyone inside. But when I’d shouted “hello” several times in vain, an argument broke out behind a partition, and presently a lovely Jewess appeared at an interior door and scrutinized me with black hostile eyes.
“Nobody’s in,” she said. “Mr. Wolfshiem’s gone to Chicago.”
The first part of this was obviously untrue, for someone had begun to whistle “The Rosary,” tunelessly, inside.
“Please say that Mr. Carraway wants to see him.”
“I can’t get him back from Chicago, can I?”
At this moment a voice, unmistakably Wolfshiem’s, called “Stella!” from the other side of the door.
“Leave your name on the desk,” she said quickly. “I’ll give it to him when he gets back.”
“But I know he’s there.”
She took a step toward me and began to slide her hands indignantly up and down her hips.
“You young men think you can force your way in here any time,” she scolded. “We’re getting sickantired of it. When I say he’s in Chicago, he’s in Chicago.”
I mentioned Gatsby.
“Oh-h!” She looked at me over again. “Will you just—What was your name?”
She vanished. In a moment Meyer Wolfshiem stood solemnly in the doorway, holding out both hands. He drew me into his office, remarking in a reverent voice that it was a sad time for all of us, and offered me a cigar.
“My memory goes back to when first I met him,” he said. “A young major just out of the army and covered over with medals he got in the war. He was so hard up he had to keep on wearing his uniform because he couldn’t buy some regular clothes. First time I saw him was when he came into Winebrenner’s poolroom at Forty-third Street and asked for a job. He hadn’t eat anything for a couple of days. ‘Come on have some lunch with me,’ I said. He ate more than four dollars’ worth of food in half an hour.”
“Did you start him in business?” I inquired.
“Start him! I made him.”
“Oh.”
“I raised him up out of nothing, right out of the gutter. I saw right away he was a fine-appearing, gentlemanly young man, and when he told me he was at Oggsford I knew I could use him good. I got him to join the American Legion and he used to stand high there. Right off he did some work for a client of mine up to Albany. We were so thick like that in everything”—he held up two bulbous fingers—“always together.”
I wondered if this partnership had included the World’s Series transaction in 1919.
“Now he’s dead,” I said after a moment. “You were his closest friend, so I know you’ll want to come to his funeral this afternoon.”
“I’d like to come.”
“Well, come then.”
The hair in his nostrils quivered slightly, and as he shook his head his eyes filled with tears.
“I can’t do it—I can’t get mixed up in it,” he said.
“There’s nothing to get mixed up in. It’s all over now.”
“When a man gets killed I never like to get mixed up in it in any way. I keep out. When I was a young man it was different—if a friend of mine died, no matter how, I stuck with them to the end. You may think that’s sentimental, but I mean it—to the bitter end.”
I saw that for some reason of his own he was determined not to come, so I stood up.
“Are you a college man?” he inquired suddenly.
For a moment I thought he was going to suggest a “gonnegtion,” but he only nodded and shook my hand.
“Let us learn to show our friendship for a man when he is alive and not after he is dead,” he suggested. “After that my own rule is to let everything alone.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The morning of the funeral I went up to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem; I couldn’t seem to reach him any other way. The telephone was useless, ringing in an empty office or answered by someone who knew nothing. I felt a desperate need to find someone, anyone, who cared enough to stand beside me at Gatsby’s grave. My first thought was Wolfshiem, the man who had built Gatsby up, who must surely feel some responsibility, some shred of loyalty. His office was in the Swastika Holding Company building, a place that now seemed even more sinister and detached from the world of human feeling. I was ushered into his presence by a nervous secretary. Wolfshiem was older than I remembered, his eyes still shrewd but with a weariness around them. He greeted me with a show of surprise, as if my presence there was the most unexpected thing in the world. I told him about Gatsby, about the pool, about Wilson, about the whole ghastly business. He listened, nodding slowly, his face impassive. When I finished, there was a long silence. Then he spoke, his voice low and cautious. He explained that he couldn’t get mixed up in it. He was a man of fifty, he said, and he’d learned that when a man gets killed he should let it alone. He spoke of his business, of the need to avoid suspicion, of the dangers of association. He wouldn’t even come to the funeral. He offered condolences, a handshake, and a quick dismissal. It was clear he wanted nothing more to do with Gatsby, dead or alive. I left his office feeling colder and more alone than before. My next attempts were equally fruitless. I called Daisy, but the line was disconnected. Tom and Daisy had simply vanished, leaving no forwarding address, no trace. They had retreated back into their money, their vast carelessness, and left others to clean up the mess they had made. I tried calling other people Gatsby had known, the crowds who had frequented his parties, but no one answered or they claimed ignorance. Klipspringer, the boarder, finally called, not to offer sympathy, but to ask about a pair of tennis shoes he’d left behind. He wouldn’t come to the funeral either; he had a picnic or something. It was a stark, brutal illustration of the superficiality of Gatsby’s world, of the people who had used him and then discarded him. Only Mr. Gatz, Gatsby’s father, arrived, a simple, bewildered man from the Midwest, clutching a worn copy of Hopalong Cassidy with Gatsby’s youthful schedule written inside. He was proud of his son, proud of his house, proud of his success, utterly unaware of the dark currents that had swept him away. The funeral was a miserable affair. It rained, a cold, persistent drizzle. There were only four of us: myself, Mr. Gatz, a few servants, and the owl-eyed man who had marvelled at Gatsby’s library. No one else came. Not a single person from the hundreds who had partied at his house. We stood under umbrellas by the grave, the raw earth muddy and unforgiving. The minister mumbled through the service, his words lost in the rain. It was a lonely, desolate end for a man who had dreamed such magnificent dreams, who had built his entire life around a single, unattainable vision. The silence afterward was profound, broken only by the sound of the rain and the distant rumble of a train. It was the final, crushing realization of Gatsby’s isolation, of the emptiness behind the glittering façade. He was alone in death as he had been, in many ways, in life.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: The morning of the funeral I went up to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem; I couldn’t seem to reach him any other way. The door that led into his office was open, and she was leaning listlessly out of the window—an overworked stenographer who had waited five years in the same place for a man who didn’t know she was alive. I was relieved to find that the office itself was here; that my search had not been in vain. The name over the door was Meyer Wolfshiem, and around a corner from it was a sign, SWAS TIKA HOLDING COMPANY. I went in, and a little old man was sitting beside the door, raising his eyes slowly from a pile of papers in the wire basket he balanced on his knees. ‘Look in the drawer there,’ he said, ‘and tell me if there’s an elevator boy off duty.’ I looked. ‘No,’ I answered. ‘All right, then,’ the man ordered, ‘throw it down.’ He went on picking up papers, and I noticed that his hands, which rested on his knees in a pile of short, fat fingers, were trembling a little. I stood in the door-way, looking at him, and after a moment I had the business card he gave Gatsby in my hand. ‘I’m looking for Mr. Wolfshiem,’ I said. ‘That’s my name,’ answered the clerk, but quickly corrected himself. ‘I said I was looking for Mr. Wolfshiem.’ ‘Why aren’t you looking for him in Chicago?’ ‘He’s here.’ ‘No, he’s not.’ He looked at the card. ‘Who are you?’ ‘I’m Gatsby’s friend.’ The name seemed to impress him. He looked at me again with an interest he had not shown before. ‘Hold on,’ he said, ‘I’ll get him.’ He disappeared behind the partition, and I heard an argument ensue between him and some one within. ‘—You can’t come in here, Stella,’ said the first man; ‘get out of the way—I’m going to get Mr. Wolfshiem.’ ‘I won’t do it,’ cried the woman named Stella. ‘You can’t get in! You can’t get in!’ There was a short struggle, and then the man appeared again, followed by a stout, florid man in a dusty plum-colored coat, with not quite enough of him for the front of a vest. ‘Alright,’ he said, ‘I’m Wolfshiem. What do you want?’ ‘I’m Gatsby’s friend,’ I said. ‘I want to see you about his funeral.’ He stared at me for a moment with an expression of unutterable grief. ‘I can’t do it,’ he muttered. ‘I can’t get mixed up in it.’ ‘But he was your friend.’ ‘I can’t do it,’ repeated Wolfshiem. ‘I can’t get mixed up in it.’ He sat down at his desk and looked at me with a pained expression. ‘I made him,’ he said. ‘I raised him up out of nothing, right out of the gutter. I saw right away he was a gentleman, and when he told me he was an Oggsford man I knew I could use him. I made him. events.title: Mr. Gatz's Pride and Gatsby's Boyhood Ambitions
detailed_summary: Nick returns to West Egg amidst darkening skies and drizzle.
He finds Mr. Gatz pacing excitedly, his pride in Gatsby and his possessions growing.
Mr. Gatz eagerly shows Nick a worn photograph of Gatsby's house that Jimmy had sent him, pointing out details.
He recounts Gatsby visiting two years prior and buying him the house he currently lives in.
Mr. Gatz reflects that Gatsby's running away from home was justified by his ambition for a 'big future'.
He emphasizes Gatsby's generosity after achieving success.
Mr. Gatz then reveals an old, ragged copy of 'Hopalong Cassidy' belonging to Gatsby as a boy.
He shows Nick the back flyleaf containing a detailed daily schedule dated September 12, 1906.
The schedule includes time for exercise, study (electricity, elocution, inventions), work, and sports.
Beneath the schedule are 'General Resolves': avoiding wasted time, quitting smoking/chewing, bathing regularly, reading improving material, saving money, and being better to parents.
Mr. Gatz sees the book and its contents as proof of Jimmy's inherent drive to 'get ahead' and improve himself.
He proudly reads the items aloud, expecting Nick to be deeply impressed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When I left his office the sky had turned dark and I got back to West Egg in a drizzle.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I think he rather expected me to copy down the list for my own use.

events.text_segment:
When I left his office the sky had turned dark and I got back to West Egg in a drizzle. After changing my clothes I went next door and found Mr. Gatz walking up and down excitedly in the hall. His pride in his son and in his son’s possessions was continually increasing and now he had something to show me.
“Jimmy sent me this picture.” He took out his wallet with trembling fingers. “Look there.”
It was a photograph of the house, cracked in the corners and dirty with many hands. He pointed out every detail to me eagerly. “Look there!” and then sought admiration from my eyes. He had shown it so often that I think it was more real to him now than the house itself.
“Jimmy sent it to me. I think it’s a very pretty picture. It shows up well.”
“Very well. Had you seen him lately?”
“He come out to see me two years ago and bought me the house I live in now. Of course we was broke up when he run off from home, but I see now there was a reason for it. He knew he had a big future in front of him. And ever since he made a success he was very generous with me.”
He seemed reluctant to put away the picture, held it for another minute, lingeringly, before my eyes. Then he returned the wallet and pulled from his pocket a ragged old copy of a book called Hopalong Cassidy.
“Look here, this is a book he had when he was a boy. It just shows you.”
He opened it at the back cover and turned it around for me to see. On the last flyleaf was printed the word schedule, and the date September 12, 1906. And underneath:
Rise from bed	6:00	a.m.
Dumbell exercise and wall-scaling	6:15⁠–⁠6:30	“
Study electricity, etc.	7:15⁠–⁠8:15	“
Work	8:30⁠–⁠4:30	p.m.
Baseball and sports	4:30⁠–⁠5:00	“
Practise elocution, poise and how to attain it	5:00⁠–⁠6:00	“
Study needed inventions	7:00⁠–⁠9:00	“
General Resolves
No wasting time at Shafters or [a name, indecipherable]
No more smokeing or chewing.
Bath every other day
Read one improving book or magazine per week
Save $5.00 [crossed out] $3.00 per week
Be better to parents
“I came across this book by accident,” said the old man. “It just shows you, don’t it?”
“It just shows you.”
“Jimmy was bound to get ahead. He always had some resolves like this or something. Do you notice what he’s got about improving his mind? He was always great for that. He told me I et like a hog once, and I beat him for it.”
He was reluctant to close the book, reading each item aloud and then looking eagerly at me. I think he rather expected me to copy down the list for my own use.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: When I left his office the sky had turned dark and I got back to West Egg in a drizzle. The station platform was slick underfoot, reflecting the sparse, yellow lights like scattered jewels. I pulled my collar up against the damp chill and began the short walk home. My little house, squat and unassuming, was a dark shape against the slightly less dark sky, a humble punctuation mark between the elaborate sentences of my neighbors' estates. But it was the house next door that drew the eye, even in the gloom. Across the wide, rain-swept lawn, Gatsby's mansion loomed, a vast, incoherent pile of Gothic and Renaissance styles, its sheer size a constant, almost aggressive assertion of wealth. Tonight, the usual blaze of lights was muted by the rain, but a few windows glowed with a soft, golden warmth, suggesting life, or at least the potential for it, within its walls. The sound of the rain on the leaves and the roof was the only sound, a steady, monotonous drumming that seemed to emphasize the quiet emptiness of the street. It was a different kind of quiet than the city's, not the absence of noise, but a deliberate, almost watchful silence, as if the very air were holding its breath. I fumbled for my key, the metal cold and wet in my hand. Stepping inside, the air was cool and smelled faintly of old paper and the sea. I switched on a lamp, casting a small pool of light in the living room. The contrast between this simple, rented space and the glittering palace next door was stark, a physical manifestation of the gulf between my own modest circumstances and the fantastic, almost unbelievable world Gatsby inhabited. I stood by the window for a moment, looking out at the rain and the distant, glowing windows of the mansion. It felt like standing on the edge of a continent, looking across a dark, turbulent sea towards a land of unknown wonders and dangers. The drizzle continued, blurring the edges of the world, making everything seem a little less real, a little more like a dream. I thought of the people I had met, the tangled lives and restless desires that seemed to swirl around Gatsby like the mist around his house. There was a profound loneliness in the scene, despite the implied presence of life next door. My own house felt like a small, safe harbor, but also a place of isolation, a vantage point from which to observe the strange, compelling drama unfolding across the lawn. The rain seemed to wash away the day's events, leaving behind only a sense of weary detachment and the persistent, unanswered question of who Jay Gatsby really was, and what he was reaching for in the dark. The night settled in, thick and damp, and the world outside my window became a study in shadows and the soft, persistent sound of falling water.

events.title: The Sparse Funeral
detailed_summary: Shortly before 3 PM, the Lutheran minister arrives for the funeral.
Nick and Mr. Gatz anxiously watch for other mourners, but none arrive.
As time passes, Mr. Gatz becomes increasingly worried, commenting nervously about the rain.
The minister checks his watch repeatedly; Nick persuades him to wait half an hour longer, but it's futile.
Around 5 PM, a small procession of three vehicles (hearse, limousine with Nick, Gatz, and minister, and station wagon with servants and postman) reaches the cemetery in heavy drizzle.
As they enter the cemetery, Nick hears a car stop and sees someone approaching.
It is the 'owl-eyed man' Nick previously met in Gatsby's library.
Owl Eyes, soaked by the rain, wipes his glasses to watch the burial.
Nick momentarily tries to think of Gatsby but finds him distant, only recalling Daisy's silence.
Someone murmurs a blessing for the dead in the rain, and Owl Eyes says 'Amen'.
After the brief ceremony, the attendees quickly return to the cars.
Owl Eyes speaks to Nick at the gate, expressing surprise that no one else came, remarking how hundreds used to attend Gatsby's parties.
He wipes his glasses again and calls Gatsby 'The poor son-of-a-bitch'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A little before three the Lutheran minister arrived from Flushing, and I began to look involuntarily out the windows for other cars.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “The poor son-of-a-bitch,” he said.

events.text_segment:
A little before three the Lutheran minister arrived from Flushing, and I began to look involuntarily out the windows for other cars. So did Gatsby’s father. And as the time passed and the servants came in and stood waiting in the hall, his eyes began to blink anxiously, and he spoke of the rain in a worried, uncertain way. The minister glanced several times at his watch, so I took him aside and asked him to wait for half an hour. But it wasn’t any use. Nobody came.
About five o’clock our procession of three cars reached the cemetery and stopped in a thick drizzle beside the gate—first a motor hearse, horribly black and wet, then Mr. Gatz and the minister and me in the limousine, and a little later four or five servants and the postman from West Egg, in Gatsby’s station wagon, all wet to the skin. As we started through the gate into the cemetery I heard a car stop and then the sound of someone splashing after us over the soggy ground. I looked around. It was the man with owl-eyed glasses whom I had found marvelling over Gatsby’s books in the library one night three months before.
I’d never seen him since then. I don’t know how he knew about the funeral, or even his name. The rain poured down his thick glasses, and he took them off and wiped them to see the protecting canvas unrolled from Gatsby’s grave.
I tried to think about Gatsby then for a moment, but he was already too far away, and I could only remember, without resentment, that Daisy hadn’t sent a message or a flower. Dimly I heard someone murmur “Blessed are the dead that the rain falls on,” and then the owl-eyed man said “Amen to that,” in a brave voice.
We straggled down quickly through the rain to the cars. Owl-eyes spoke to me by the gate.
“I couldn’t get to the house,” he remarked.
“Neither could anybody else.”
“Go on!” He started. “Why, my God! they used to go there by the hundreds.”
He took off his glasses and wiped them again, outside and in.
“The poor son-of-a-bitch,” he said.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: A little before three the Lutheran minister arrived from Flushing, and I began to look involuntarily out the windows for other cars. So did Gatsby’s father. We waited half an hour for a man named Klipspringer, who thought he knew what flowers were to be sent, and at the last minute proved unable to come anyhow. And then we waited for Daisy, and while the rain poured down we waited for her patiently for half an hour. I called up the Buchanan’s house and was told that she and Tom had gone away early that afternoon – and taken baggage with them. “Did you notify Daisy by any chance?” “I phoned her yesterday and she thought she might come,” I answered automatically. “I didn’t notify you because you were so far away.” Well, the fact is that I didn’t notify anyone. It was an accident, and it happened that way. I have an idea that Gatsby himself didn’t believe it would come to a funeral at all. He looked at me with an expectant air and so did Mr. Gatz, who was just as agitated as I was. I began to have a feeling of defiance, of scornful solidarity between Gatsby and me against them all. “I think we ought to start,” said the minister. “Wait just a minute, Reverend. In my opinion, if we wait long enough, more people will come.” Mr. Gatz said nothing. For half an hour Reverend Palmetto talked to the servants and the gardener, while Mr. Gatz went over his son’s death again and again with an endless, bewildered horror. It wasn’t any use. Nobody came. About five o’clock our procession of three cars reached the cemetery and stopped in a thick drizzle beside the gate – first a hearse, then Mr. Gatz and the minister and I in the limousine, and a little later four or five servants and the postman from West Egg in a hurry in the station wagon. Just as Gatsby’s coffin started through the gate into the cemetery I heard a car stop and then the sound of someone’s feet on the soft sod. I turned in time to see a big yellow car stop and then get out a stout, middle-aged man with owl-eyed spectacles. He was shivering as he came up the walk. “Blessed are the dead that the rain falls on,” said Owl Eyes, dismally. “Amen to that,” in a brave voice. We straggled down quickly through the rain to the cars. Owl Eyes got into the hearse and waited for us. I stood beside Gatsby’s father and tried to think how Gatsby would have liked it. It occurred to me that he would have been surprised. With the single exception of the man from the Hydroplane, who was too sick to be moved, he hadn’t received a single message or a single flower. The rain poured down his thick glasses, and he wiped them again and again, to see. “See!” he cried. “It’s a triumph. What a triumph! He was a real man. The kind of man you’d like to meet. The kind of man you’d like to know.” He wiped his glasses again. “I can’t see the hearse,” he muttered. “I can’t see anything.” He put his glasses back on. “Well, I’ll be damned,” he said. “If it wasn’t for the rain, I’d have sworn it was a triumph.” He shook his head. “The poor son-of-a-bitch,” he added.

The kind of man you’d like to know.” He wiped his glasses again. “I can’t see the hearse,” he muttered. “I can’t see anything.” He put his glasses back on. “Well, I’ll be damned,” he said. “If it wasn’t for the rain, I’d have sworn it was a triumph.” He shook his head. “The poor son-of-a-bitch,” he added.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: A little before three the Lutheran minister arrived from Flushing, and I began to look involuntarily out the windows for other cars. So did the minister. We waited in the rain, which fell steadily, and by four o’clock the rain had stopped, and still no one had come. Mr. Gatz, who had arrived the day before, sat in the drawing-room, his head in his hands, a broken old man. He had brought a photograph of Gatsby’s house, taken when it was just a simple dwelling, and he showed it to me with immense pride, talking about Jimmy’s plans, his schedule, his determination to ‘get ahead’. It was heartbreaking to see the simple, earnest man who had fathered the complex, tragic figure of Jay Gatsby. The minister coughed and looked at his watch. The undertaker arrived, a small, stout man with a professional air of gloom. He conferred with the minister in low tones. It became clear that this was it. There would be no more cars, no more people. The great Gatsby, the man who had thrown open his house to hundreds, whose parties were legendary, was to be buried with only his father, the minister, and me present. A few servants stood respectfully in the background, and the postman, who happened to be passing, paused for a moment. We drove out to the cemetery in a single car. It was a small, obscure place, far from the grandeur of West Egg. The rain had left the ground muddy and slick. The minister said a few words, brief and impersonal. Mr. Gatz sobbed quietly. I stood there, feeling a profound sense of isolation and waste. This was the end of the story, the final chapter for the man who had pursued a dream with such relentless passion. The contrast between the vibrant life Gatsby had projected and the desolate reality of his death was stark and unbearable. It was a lonely business, that last ceremony, as lonely as the man himself must have been behind the glittering façade. I thought of the hundreds who had eaten his food, drunk his liquor, danced on his lawn – and not one of them had come to say goodbye. It was a testament to the superficiality of the world he had courted, a world that used him and then discarded him. The earth was shoveled onto the coffin, a dull, final sound. And that was all.

events.title: Reflections on East vs. West and Decision to Leave
detailed_summary: Nick recalls vivid memories of returning home to the Midwest from school during Christmas.
He describes the atmosphere at Chicago's Union Station, the goodbyes, and the train journey into the snowy landscape.
He reflects on the feeling of connection to his homeland experienced during those trips.
Nick defines his Midwest not by landscapes but by these youthful returns and the cozy familiarity of home.
He realizes the story he's told is fundamentally about Westerners (himself, Gatsby, Tom, Daisy, Jordan) who were ill-suited to Eastern life.
Even at its most exciting, Nick found the East possessed a 'quality of distortion'.
He envisions West Egg as a grotesque night scene, comparing it to an El Greco painting, symbolizing moral decay and indifference.
After Gatsby's death, the East feels irredeemably haunted and distorted to Nick.
As autumn sets in, he decides to leave the East and return home to the Midwest.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So when the blue smoke of brittle leaves was in the air and the wind blew the wet laundry stiff on the line I decided to come back home.

events.text_segment:
One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time. Those who went farther than Chicago would gather in the old dim Union Station at six o’clock of a December evening, with a few Chicago friends, already caught up into their own holiday gaieties, to bid them a hasty goodbye. I remember the fur coats of the girls returning from Miss This-or-That’s and the chatter of frozen breath and the hands waving overhead as we caught sight of old acquaintances, and the matchings of invitations: “Are you going to the Ordways’? the Herseys’? the Schultzes’?” and the long green tickets clasped tight in our gloved hands. And last the murky yellow cars of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul railroad looking cheerful as Christmas itself on the tracks beside the gate.
When we pulled out into the winter night and the real snow, our snow, began to stretch out beside us and twinkle against the windows, and the dim lights of small Wisconsin stations moved by, a sharp wild brace came suddenly into the air. We drew in deep breaths of it as we walked back from dinner through the cold vestibules, unutterably aware of our identity with this country for one strange hour, before we melted indistinguishably into it again.
That’s my Middle West—not the wheat or the prairies or the lost Swede towns, but the thrilling returning trains of my youth, and the street lamps and sleigh bells in the frosty dark and the shadows of holly wreaths thrown by lighted windows on the snow. I am part of that, a little solemn with the feel of those long winters, a little complacent from growing up in the Carraway house in a city where dwellings are still called through decades by a family’s name. I see now that this has been a story of the West, after all—Tom and Gatsby, Daisy and Jordan and I, were all Westerners, and perhaps we possessed some deficiency in common which made us subtly unadaptable to Eastern life.
Even when the East excited me most, even when I was most keenly aware of its superiority to the bored, sprawling, swollen towns beyond the Ohio, with their interminable inquisitions which spared only the children and the very old—even then it had always for me a quality of distortion. West Egg, especially, still figures in my more fantastic dreams. I see it as a night scene by El Greco: a hundred houses, at once conventional and grotesque, crouching under a sullen, overhanging sky and a lustreless moon. In the foreground four solemn men in dress suits are walking along the sidewalk with a stretcher on which lies a drunken woman in a white evening dress. Her hand, which dangles over the side, sparkles cold with jewels. Gravely the men turn in at a house—the wrong house. But no one knows the woman’s name, and no one cares.
After Gatsby’s death the East was haunted for me like that, distorted beyond my eyes’ power of correction. So when the blue smoke of brittle leaves was in the air and the wind blew the wet laundry stiff on the line I decided to come back home.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time. The snow was always deeper out there, the trains smelled of coal smoke and pine needles, and there was a sort of solid, enduring quality about the people and the landscape that the East, for all its frantic energy and glittering surfaces, seemed utterly to lack. It was a feeling of coming home to something real, something rooted. The air itself felt cleaner, sharper, carrying the scent of woodsmoke and frozen earth. There was a quiet dignity to the towns, a sense of community that wasn't built on shifting sands of wealth and social climbing, but on shared history and mutual understanding. The contrast was always stark. Leaving the East was like shedding a costume. The elaborate manners, the casual extravagance, the relentless pursuit of pleasure – it all seemed to dissipate the moment the train crossed the Alleghenies. Back West, people talked about the weather, about crops, about family. Their concerns felt fundamental, tied to the land and the seasons, not to the latest gossip or the fluctuations of the stock market. There was a certain earnestness, a lack of pretense that was both comforting and, after a time spent in the East's intoxicating atmosphere, perhaps a little dull. But it was a good dullness. A healthy dullness. It was the feeling of being grounded, of belonging to a place and a people who knew you, not just your current address or your bank balance. My family was there, solid and dependable, embodying the virtues I had been taught to value: honesty, reserve, a certain quiet strength. They weren't flashy or ambitious in the Eastern sense, but they possessed a moral fiber that seemed increasingly rare in the world I had chosen to inhabit. Coming back West was a reset button. It cleared the air, both literally and figuratively. It reminded me of where I came from, of the values I was supposed to uphold. It was a temporary escape from the relentless, often meaningless, churn of life on the Eastern seaboard. There, everything felt temporary, provisional. Houses were bought and sold like commodities, relationships formed and dissolved with alarming speed, and the pursuit of happiness seemed to involve an endless, restless movement from one party, one affair, one new acquisition to the next. The West, by contrast, felt permanent. The houses stood for generations, the families had roots that went deep into the soil, and the rhythm of life was dictated by the natural world, not by the artificial demands of society. There was a sense of peace there, a quiet contentment that I rarely found in the East. It wasn't exciting, perhaps, but it was stable. It was real. And yet, each time I returned to the East, I was drawn back into its current. The energy, the possibility, the sheer, dazzling spectacle of it all was hard to resist. It was a world of dreams, both beautiful and terrible, and once you had tasted it, the quiet reality of the West could seem a little pale in comparison. But those Christmas visits were a vital anchor, a reminder of a different way of being, a way that, even as I became more and more entangled in the East's complexities, I knew held a truth and a decency that the glittering world of Gatsby and the Buchanans could never truly possess. They were a breath of clean, cold air before plunging back into the humid, perfumed atmosphere of the Eggs. They were a memory of something lost, perhaps, but something that still held a powerful, quiet claim on my heart.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time. Those who went farther than Chicago would stop over for a day or two and then take the night train West. For a long time I was ashamed of being on the train with men who had nothing to do all day but sit in Pullman chairs, guarding their suitcases in the racks. Old men lost in their newspapers were oblivious to the showers of babies that splashed them in the aisles. The whole train was roaring with laughter, and everybody was having a good time. The only sad thing was the unfathomable silliness of the women, which seemed to increase as they neared Chicago. But on the third day, when we passed through Pittsburgh, and the smokestacks of the mills were turning the sky yellow, I felt that I was getting somewhere, that I was on my way at last. And then there was the smell of the snow, and the smell of the cinders, and the smell of the train itself, which was like the smell of home. simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time. Those who went farther than Chicago would stop over for a day or two and then take the night train West. For a long time I was ashamed of being on the train with men who had nothing to do all day but sit in Pullman chairs, guarding their suitcases in the racks. Old men lost in their newspapers were oblivious to the showers of babies that splashed them in the aisles. The whole train was roaring with laughter, and everybody was having a good time. The only sad thing was the unfathomable silliness of the women, which seemed to increase as they neared Chicago. But on the third day, when we passed through Pittsburgh, and the smokestacks of the mills were turning the sky yellow, I felt that I was getting somewhere, that I was on my way at last. And then there was the smell of the snow, and the smell of the cinders, and the smell of the train itself, which was like the smell of home. simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time. Those who went farther than Chicago would stop over for a day or two and then take the night train West. I remember the fur coats of the girls returning from boarding schools and the chatter of frozen breath in the station itself; and more distinctly the fresh, clean snow that always seemed to be falling in great soft flakes behind the train windows. These returns from the East hearkened back to the time when I first went to New York to work in the bond business. I was thirty. Before I came East I had been restless, as I suppose most young men are, and I had a vague idea of going out to the Pacific coast. But I drifted here and there unrestfully wherever people played polo and were rich together. This was a restless, unhappy time for me, and I can remember nothing that happened in it except that I was always alone. When I came back from the war I felt that I wanted the world to be in uniform and at a sort of moral attention forever; I wanted no more riotous excursions with privileged glimpses into the human heart. Only Gatsby, the man who gives his name to this book, was exempt from my reaction—Gatsby, who represented everything for which I have an unreserved contempt. If personality is an unbroken series of successful gestures, then there was something gorgeous about him, some heightened sensitivity to the promises of life, as if he were related to one of those intricate machines that register earthquakes ten thousand miles away. This responsiveness had nothing to do with that flabby impressionability which is dignified under the name of the “creative temperament.”—it was an extraordinary gift for hope, a romantic readiness such as I have never found in any other person and which it is not likely I shall ever find again. No—Gatsby turned out all right at the end; it is what preyed on Gatsby, what foul dust floated in the wake of his dreams that temporarily closed out my interest in the abortive sorrows and short-winded elations of men. My own house was an eyesore, but it was a small eyesore, and it had been an eyesore for three generations. I had a dog, at least I had him for a few days until he ran away, and an old Dodge and a Finnish woman, who made my bed and cooked my breakfast and muttered Finnish wisdom to herself over the stove. IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion introduces invented scenes and characters, such as men sitting in Pullman chairs, old men with newspapers, and babies in the aisles, which are not present in the original passage.
- The completion omits entire major sections from the original, including the detailed description of the train station, the social interactions, the emotional reflections on the Midwest, the symbolic imagery of the landscape, and the philosophical musings about the East and West.
- The completion contains excessive repetition of a single sensory detail, which disrupts the narrative flow and omits the progression of events and reflections found in the original.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The initial gathering at the train station, including the time of day, the atmosphere, and the presence of friends, is missing.
- Descriptions of clothing, social exchanges, and specific holiday activities are absent.
- The transition from the station to the train journey, including the changing landscape and emotional responses, is not included.
- The passage’s shift to broader reflections on regional identity, personal history, and the contrast between East and West is missing.
- The original’s use of symbolic and dreamlike imagery, as well as the concluding decision to return home, is not present.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The sequence of events is altered, with invented travel details and stops that do not match the original.
- The completion attributes actions and attitudes to characters (such as the behavior of women and old men) that are not found in the source material.
- The focus on sensory details is disproportionately repetitive and does not accurately reflect the variety and order of experiences in the original.
- The completion fails to include the original’s introspective and thematic elements, resulting in a loss of the passage’s intended meaning and structure.

events.title: Ending Affairs: Jordan and Tom
detailed_summary: Before leaving, Nick feels compelled to resolve his situation with Jordan Baker.
He meets her and discusses their relationship and its aftermath.
Jordan listens impassively, dressed for golf.
She informs Nick she is engaged to another man, which Nick doubts but accepts.
As Nick gets up to leave, Jordan confronts him, accusing him of being the one who ended things ('threw me over').
She recalls their earlier conversation about bad drivers, implying Nick was another 'bad driver' she encountered and suggesting his proclaimed honesty was a facade.
Nick responds defensively, citing his age (thirty) as being past self-deception.
Feeling angry, regretful, and still somewhat attracted to her, Nick turns away.
Later, Nick encounters Tom Buchanan on Fifth Avenue.
Tom confronts Nick about seeming unwilling to shake his hand.
Nick asks Tom directly what he told George Wilson on the afternoon of the murder.
Tom confesses he told Wilson that Gatsby owned the yellow car.
He justifies this by claiming Wilson was armed, threatening, and forced his way into the house.
Tom asserts Gatsby deserved it for running over Myrtle without stopping.
Nick recognizes he can't argue with Tom's distorted version of events.
Tom laments his own 'suffering', mentioning crying over a box of dog biscuits found in the flat he shared with Myrtle.
Nick concludes that Tom and Daisy are careless people who destroy things and retreat into their wealth, letting others clean up their messes.
He shakes Tom's hand, feeling as if dealing with a child, before Tom enters a jewelry store.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better have been let alone.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then he went into the jewellery store to buy a pearl necklace—or perhaps only a pair of cuff buttons—rid of my provincial squeamishness forever.

events.text_segment:
There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better have been let alone. But I wanted to leave things in order and not just trust that obliging and indifferent sea to sweep my refuse away. I saw Jordan Baker and talked over and around what had happened to us together, and what had happened afterward to me, and she lay perfectly still, listening, in a big chair.
She was dressed to play golf, and I remember thinking she looked like a good illustration, her chin raised a little jauntily, her hair the colour of an autumn leaf, her face the same brown tint as the fingerless glove on her knee. When I had finished she told me without comment that she was engaged to another man. I doubted that, though there were several she could have married at a nod of her head, but I pretended to be surprised. For just a minute I wondered if I wasn’t making a mistake, then I thought it all over again quickly and got up to say goodbye.
“Nevertheless you did throw me over,” said Jordan suddenly. “You threw me over on the telephone. I don’t give a damn about you now, but it was a new experience for me, and I felt a little dizzy for a while.”
We shook hands.
“Oh, and do you remember”—she added—“a conversation we had once about driving a car?”
“Why—not exactly.”
“You said a bad driver was only safe until she met another bad driver? Well, I met another bad driver, didn’t I? I mean it was careless of me to make such a wrong guess. I thought you were rather an honest, straightforward person. I thought it was your secret pride.”
“I’m thirty,” I said. “I’m five years too old to lie to myself and call it honour.”
She didn’t answer. Angry, and half in love with her, and tremendously sorry, I turned away.
One afternoon late in October I saw Tom Buchanan. He was walking ahead of me along Fifth Avenue in his alert, aggressive way, his hands out a little from his body as if to fight off interference, his head moving sharply here and there, adapting itself to his restless eyes. Just as I slowed up to avoid overtaking him he stopped and began frowning into the windows of a jewellery store. Suddenly he saw me and walked back, holding out his hand.
“What’s the matter, Nick? Do you object to shaking hands with me?”
“Yes. You know what I think of you.”
“You’re crazy, Nick,” he said quickly. “Crazy as hell. I don’t know what’s the matter with you.”
“Tom,” I inquired, “what did you say to Wilson that afternoon?”
He stared at me without a word, and I knew I had guessed right about those missing hours. I started to turn away, but he took a step after me and grabbed my arm.
“I told him the truth,” he said. “He came to the door while we were getting ready to leave, and when I sent down word that we weren’t in he tried to force his way upstairs. He was crazy enough to kill me if I hadn’t told him who owned the car. His hand was on a revolver in his pocket every minute he was in the house—” He broke off defiantly. “What if I did tell him? That fellow had it coming to him. He threw dust into your eyes just like he did in Daisy’s, but he was a tough one. He ran over Myrtle like you’d run over a dog and never even stopped his car.”
There was nothing I could say, except the one unutterable fact that it wasn’t true.
“And if you think I didn’t have my share of suffering—look here, when I went to give up that flat and saw that damn box of dog biscuits sitting there on the sideboard, I sat down and cried like a baby. By God it was awful—”
I couldn’t forgive him or like him, but I saw that what he had done was, to him, entirely justified. It was all very careless and confused. They were careless people, Tom and Daisy—they smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into their money or their vast carelessness, or whatever it was that kept them together, and let other people clean up the mess they had made…
I shook hands with him; it seemed silly not to, for I felt suddenly as though I were talking to a child. Then he went into the jewellery store to buy a pearl necklace—or perhaps only a pair of cuff buttons—rid of my provincial squeamishness forever.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better have been let alone. I had no schedule, no plan beyond getting away, but I felt a vague, persistent obligation to Jordan Baker. Our brief, tentative relationship, born out of the summer's feverish unreality, had withered and died in the aftermath of the catastrophe. It hadn't been a grand passion, not like Gatsby's for Daisy, but it had been something, a fragile connection that now felt like a loose thread I needed to snip cleanly before departing the tangled fabric of the East. We met in a tea-garden, a place of hushed voices and clinking porcelain, utterly removed from the raw, violent emotions that had consumed us all just days before. Jordan was dressed impeccably, her face a mask of cool indifference, though I thought I detected a flicker of something – resentment, perhaps, or wounded pride – in her eyes. The air between us was thick with unspoken accusations and the ghosts of shared, albeit superficial, moments. I began awkwardly, trying to explain my sudden decision to leave, to retreat from the East and everything it represented. I spoke vaguely of needing to go home, of the summer being over, of things having changed too much. It sounded weak, even to my own ears, a pale excuse for the profound disillusionment that had settled over me like a shroud. Jordan listened, stirring her tea with deliberate slowness. When I finished, she looked up, her gaze steady and unnerving. "You're leaving because of what happened, aren't you?" she said, her voice low and level. It wasn't a question, but a statement of fact. I hesitated, unsure how to answer without delving into the depths of the horror I had witnessed, the moral decay that had sickened me. "Partly," I admitted. "Everything feels... tainted." "Tainted?" She gave a short, humorless laugh. "Don't be so dramatic, Nick. People die. It happens." Her casual cruelty, the utter lack of empathy, struck me anew. It was this very quality, this careless disregard for others, that had repelled me even as I was drawn to her. "It's not just that," I said, finding my voice. "It's everything. The lies, the carelessness... the way people just use each other and then retreat back into their money or their vast carelessness, or whatever it is that keeps them together, and let other people clean up the mess." Jordan's eyes narrowed slightly. "Are you talking about me?" "I'm talking about everyone," I said, though I knew I was talking about her, about Daisy and Tom, about the whole glittering, hollow world they inhabited. "This summer... it showed me things. Things I can't unsee." "And you think you're so much better?" she challenged, her voice hardening. "You came here, you judged everyone, and now you're running away." "I'm not judging," I protested, though I knew I was. "I'm just... I don't belong here. This isn't my world." "You seemed to fit in well enough when you were having dinner at the Buchanans'," she retorted, a sharp edge to her tone. "Or when you were chasing after me." That stung. "I wasn't chasing after you," I said, perhaps too quickly. "We... we spent time together. It was nice." "Nice?" She laughed again, a brittle sound. "Is that all it was? Nice?" She leaned forward slightly, her voice dropping to a confiding, yet cutting, whisper. "You know, I thought you were rather an honest, straightforward person. I thought it was your secret pride." Her words hung in the air, heavy with accusation. My honesty, my supposed straightforwardness – the very qualities I prided myself on – were being called into question by someone whose own honesty was, at best, debatable. The irony was not lost on me. "I am honest," I said, feeling a defensive heat rise in my cheeks. "Are you?" she challenged. "You're breaking up with me, aren't you? Because you're leaving. Because you can't handle it here." "Yes," I admitted, the word feeling like a stone in my mouth. "I am. It's not fair to you to pretend otherwise." "Fair?" She scoffed. "Don't talk to me about fair. I've been in relationships before, Nick, with men who weren't... who weren't afraid to face things." "I'm not afraid," I said, though perhaps I was. Afraid of becoming like them, of losing myself in their reckless world. "I just... I can't do this anymore. This life. It's too much." She looked at me for a long moment, her expression unreadable. Then, she straightened up, her posture regaining its usual cool elegance. "Well," she said, her voice regaining its casual lilt, as if we were discussing the weather. "I'm engaged." The suddenness of the announcement took me aback. "Engaged?" I repeated, surprised. "Yes," she said, a faint smile playing on her lips. "To a man from the Middle West. He's a great big hulking physical specimen." The description was clearly a deliberate echo of Daisy's description of Tom. It was a final, subtle jab, a way of telling me that she was moving on, perhaps even replacing me with someone more substantial, more like the men she was used to. It also highlighted the cyclical nature of their world, the way they seemed to repeat the same patterns, the same careless choices. "I see," I said, feeling a strange mix of relief and a faint, lingering regret. Relief that the awkward conversation was nearing its end, regret for the potential that had been lost, or perhaps had never truly existed. "You see?" she echoed, her smile widening slightly, though it didn't reach her eyes. "I thought you were an honest, straightforward person. I thought it was your secret pride. 'I'm thirty,' I said. 'I'm five years too old to lie to myself and call it honor.'" She was quoting something I had said to her earlier in the summer, twisting my own words back at me, using my supposed virtue as a weapon. It was a masterful, if cruel, stroke. She was telling me that my decision to leave, my claim of needing honesty and escape, was just another form of self-deception, a way of avoiding responsibility. "That's not fair, Jordan," I said, feeling a weariness settle over me. "It's not?" she challenged, her eyes flashing. "You threw me over. You threw me over on the telephone. I don't give a damn about you now, but it was a new experience for me, and I felt a little dizzy for a while." Her bluntness, her admission of being "thrown over," was disarming. It revealed a vulnerability she rarely showed, quickly masked by her usual cynicism. But the hurt was real, however fleeting she claimed it was. "I'm sorry," I said, meaning it. Sorry for the clumsy way I had handled things, sorry for the pain I had caused, however unintentionally. She shrugged, a small, dismissive gesture. "It's all right. I'm used to men who break things off. I'm used to being left." Her words, delivered with a practiced air of indifference, painted a picture of a life filled with transient relationships, with men who were as careless with her as she was with others. It was a sad, lonely image, despite the glittering facade. We sat in silence for a moment, the clinking of teacups and the murmur of voices around us filling the void. There was nothing more to say. The connection, such as it was, had been severed. The awkward, unpleasant thing was done. I paid the bill, and we rose to leave. There was no handshake, no embrace, not even a lingering look. We simply walked out of the tea-garden, two strangers who had briefly intersected in the chaotic summer of 1922. As we parted on the street, she gave me a final, cool nod, and then turned and walked away, disappearing into the anonymous crowd. I watched her go, feeling a profound sense of relief mixed with a lingering sadness. The summer was truly over now. All its tangled threads – Gatsby's dream, Daisy's betrayal, Tom's brutality, Jordan's cynicism, and my own brief, ill-fated entanglement – were finally being cut. It was time to go home, back to the West, back to a world that, while perhaps less exciting, felt more real, more grounded, more honest. The East, with its glittering promise and its underlying rot, was a chapter I was eager to close forever.

events.title: Final Departure and Meditation on the Past
detailed_summary: Upon leaving, Nick notes Gatsby's house remains empty, the lawn overgrown.
He observes a local taxi driver who often points out the house, speculating the driver might have witnessed the accident and created his own narrative.
Nick avoids the driver, not wanting to hear speculative stories.
He recalls spending Saturday nights in New York, haunted by the vivid memories and sounds of Gatsby's parties.
One night, he sees a car arrive at Gatsby's house but doesn't investigate, assuming it's a late guest unaware the party is over.
On his last night, Nick visits Gatsby's house one final time.
He finds an obscene word scrawled on the steps and erases it with his shoe.
He walks down to the beach and lies on the sand, observing the closed shore houses and the Sound.
As the moon rises, the landscape seems to dissolve, leading Nick to contemplate the 'old island' as seen by the first Dutch sailors – a 'fresh, green breast of the new world'.
He reflects on the vanished trees that made way for Gatsby's house, symbols of the lost American dream.
Nick thinks of Gatsby's initial wonder at Daisy's green light, how close his dream seemed.
He concludes Gatsby didn't realize the dream was already behind him, lost in the vastness of America.
Gatsby's unwavering belief in the 'orgastic future' is highlighted – a future that constantly recedes.
Despite the elusiveness of the dream, Nick acknowledges the persistent human impulse to strive towards it ('run faster, stretch out our arms farther').
The chapter, and the book, ends with the image of humanity struggling against the current of time, constantly being pulled back into the past.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Gatsby’s house was still empty when I left—the grass on his lawn had grown as long as mine.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.

events.text_segment:
Gatsby’s house was still empty when I left—the grass on his lawn had grown as long as mine. One of the taxi drivers in the village never took a fare past the entrance gate without stopping for a minute and pointing inside; perhaps it was he who drove Daisy and Gatsby over to East Egg the night of the accident, and perhaps he had made a story about it all his own. I didn’t want to hear it and I avoided him when I got off the train.
I spent my Saturday nights in New York because those gleaming, dazzling parties of his were with me so vividly that I could still hear the music and the laughter, faint and incessant, from his garden, and the cars going up and down his drive. One night I did hear a material car there, and saw its lights stop at his front steps. But I didn’t investigate. Probably it was some final guest who had been away at the ends of the earth and didn’t know that the party was over.
On the last night, with my trunk packed and my car sold to the grocer, I went over and looked at that huge incoherent failure of a house once more. On the white steps an obscene word, scrawled by some boy with a piece of brick, stood out clearly in the moonlight, and I erased it, drawing my shoe raspingly along the stone. Then I wandered down to the beach and sprawled out on the sand.
Most of the big shore places were closed now and there were hardly any lights except the shadowy, moving glow of a ferryboat across the Sound. And as the moon rose higher the inessential houses began to melt away until gradually I became aware of the old island here that flowered once for Dutch sailors’ eyes—a fresh, green breast of the new world. Its vanished trees, the trees that had made way for Gatsby’s house, had once pandered in whispers to the last and greatest of all human dreams; for a transitory enchanted moment man must have held his breath in the presence of this continent, compelled into an aesthetic contemplation he neither understood nor desired, face to face for the last time in history with something commensurate to his capacity for wonder.
And as I sat there brooding on the old, unknown world, I thought of Gatsby’s wonder when he first picked out the green light at the end of Daisy’s dock. He had come a long way to this blue lawn, and his dream must have seemed so close that he could hardly fail to grasp it. He did not know that it was already behind him, somewhere back in that vast obscurity beyond the city, where the dark fields of the republic rolled on under the night.
Gatsby believed in the green light, the orgastic future that year by year recedes before us. It eluded us then, but that’s no matter—tomorrow we will run faster, stretch out our arms further… And one fine morning—
So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.
